original: Another week just flew by me. I drove by the new house yesterday and the front window was covered in boxes. We may get the keys at closing, i am getting so excited. If all goes well this week, we will be set for closing a week from wednesday. I was up until after 3:00am last night watching movies with bethany. There has been a lot of movie watching going on around here lately. Here's my rundown; last night we watched thirteen, a movie every mother of a teen should see. It was better then i expected. Then we watched gigli, yeah it was just as bad as the media said it was, but we had to see for ourselves.
polished: Another week has flown by. Yesterday, I drove past the new house and noticed the front window was covered in boxes. We might get the keys at closing—I’m getting really excited. If everything goes smoothly this week, we should be set to close a week from Wednesday. Last night, Bethany and I stayed up past 3:00 AM watching movies. There’s been a lot of movie-watching happening lately. Here’s the rundown: last night, we watched *Thirteen*—a film every mother of a teenager should see. It was better than I expected. After that, we watched *Gigli*—and yes, it was just as bad as the reviews claimed, but we had to see for ourselves.

original: Summer tv tv in the summer used to be a dead zone full of repeats or something. But now there are two great new shows on tv and i have been watching both religiously for the last week. Blow out the gayest concept ever that seemingly has zero gay people in sight. Hairstylist jonothan antin wants build a second location to his incredibly popular west hollywood salon but this time in beverly hills. Normally no one would care, certainly not i, but as i was flipping thru the channels i caught a glipse of jonothan, equally narcissistic and dull looking at a empty space on rodeo dr speak (in a public voice) 'i am going to build here the greatest salon in the history of the world ever!' and i was hooked. Not since rocco have i found such a moron compelling tv watching.
polished: Summer TV used to be a dead zone filled with reruns, but now there are two fantastic new shows I’ve been watching religiously for the past week. *Blow Out* has the gayest concept ever, yet somehow features zero gay people in sight. The show follows hairstylist Jonathan Antin as he attempts to open a second location of his wildly popular West Hollywood salon—this time in Beverly Hills. Normally, no one would care (least of all me), but while flipping through channels, I caught a glimpse of Jonathan—equally narcissistic and dull—standing in an empty space on Rodeo Drive, declaring (in his most theatrical voice), *"I am going to build the greatest salon in the history of the world—ever!"* And just like that, I was hooked. Not since *Rocco* have I found such a mesmerizingly clueless character so compelling to watch.

original: What a week ... My right shoulder has tendonitus. It's right under my shoulder blade. So, when i move my arm too much, mainly with a mouse on a computer .... It kills me. I can't move it much now because i was on a spree updating my website and working on other online things. I can barely get up strength to draw anything. Lack of sleep adds to my pain. I'm not too happy right now, but i'll get better. My mom's surgery went ok. Her eyesight has come back some. She can see fuzzy shapes and make out colors. Other than that she's still blind as all sin. Hopefully she'll fully regain her vision soon.
polished:
What a week... My right shoulder has tendonitis, right under the shoulder blade. Whenever I move my arm too much—especially while using a computer mouse—the pain is unbearable. I’ve overdone it lately, updating my website and working on other online tasks, so now I can barely move it. Finding the energy to draw anything feels impossible, and the lack of sleep only makes the pain worse. I’m not in the best spirits right now, but I’ll recover.  

On a brighter note, my mom’s surgery went well. Her eyesight has improved slightly—she can now see blurry shapes and distinguish colors. Still, her vision remains severely impaired. Here’s hoping she regains it fully soon.

original: Kindness of strangers... Attempted laundry today with the kids in tow and realized how very quickly the simplest things can become a freaking ordeal. I also learned how remarkably sweet total strangers can be for no reason other than because they feel like being sweet. Trust me. It wasn't like they were trying to get into my pants or anything. I had kid drool all over me and was wearing my 'wash-day' outfit... Also, i'm not surper sure i'll ever be bathing again so it's not like there was even an olefactory incentive there! i am doing two things right now. I am composing an post and i am also watching the collected no doubt videos. I am doing both of these things sitting at my desk in my room.
polished:
The kindness of strangers... Today, I attempted to do laundry with the kids in tow and realized how quickly even the simplest tasks can turn into an absolute ordeal. I also discovered just how unexpectedly sweet complete strangers can be—for no reason other than their own goodwill. Trust me, it wasn’t as if they had ulterior motives. I was covered in kid drool and sporting my "laundry day" attire... Besides, I’m not entirely sure I’ll ever bathe again, so there wasn’t even an olfactory incentive!  

Right now, I’m multitasking: composing this post while watching No Doubt’s greatest hits. Both activities are happening from the comfort of my desk in my room.

original: So it is 11:14pm mst, and here i sit in my bedroom fixing the personal computer of the personnel director from my job. Not that i mind doing it, but i wonder sometimes at how often i find myself fixing someone else's computer as a favour. I'm glad to be able to love and minister to people this way, but where is the line drawn where it comes to the point that you are being taken advantage of? the last couple of weeks, i've been staying up late reading and such, so i was looking forward to hitting the sack early, until i realized it would be more prudent to get this computer out of my bedroom and back into its owner's hands. *laugh* no rest for the weary, right? so i found myself watching joe schmo 2 again tonight.
polished:
It's 11:14 PM MST, and here I sit in my bedroom repairing the personal computer of my workplace's personnel director. Not that I mind helping, but I sometimes wonder how frequently I end up fixing someone else's computer as a favor. I'm happy to show care and support in this way, but where do you draw the line between helping and being taken advantage of?  

The past few weeks, I've been staying up late reading and such, so I was looking forward to turning in early—until I realized it made more sense to finish this repair and return the computer to its owner. *Laughs* No rest for the weary, right? So instead, I found myself rewatching *Joe Schmo 2* tonight.

original: Remind me, what did i write about before this? or, a continuation in the 'is this a date?' saga so, after the weird lunch, my confidence shook, i forgot to tell you guys an important piece of the story. Before pat shows up to lunch, dustin starts talking about what a nice guy pat is and how he's trying to find a girlfriend for him. I'm listening and nodding and realizing that we're talking more about finding dustin's best friend a girl, than discussing whatever it is you discuss with a stranger over pink lemonade. I excused myself to the bathroom, looked in the mirror and then silently asked myself: am i being pawned off to the other guy? is this what happens now?
polished: Remind me—what was I writing about before this? Or rather, let’s continue the 'Is this a date?' saga. After that awkward lunch, my confidence was shaken, and I realized I left out a key detail. Before Pat arrived, Dustin started talking about what a great guy Pat is and how he’s trying to find him a girlfriend. I listened and nodded, slowly realizing the conversation was more about matchmaking for Dustin’s best friend than whatever small talk you’d normally have with a stranger over pink lemonade. I excused myself to the bathroom, stared into the mirror, and silently wondered: Am I being passed off to the other guy? Is this really happening?

original: I would like everyone to think before they act. Actually.. I'd like each and every single person in the world to think before they get out of bed in the morning, and make a commitment to keep thinking all day, and if they're not prepared to, i'd like very much that they'd hop the fuck back in bed, and drift off to an eternal slumber. I'm sick to death of stupid people. No i'm not the smartest motherfucker in the world... But i'm not talking about things that take a lot of brain power, so i think its fair to persecute the inanely stupid. Lets see if i can keep this particular rant to a few particular types, and we'll save some for another day, sound good? great.
polished: I wish everyone would pause and reflect before acting. In fact, I’d love it if every single person in the world took a moment to think before getting out of bed each morning—and then made a conscious effort to keep thinking throughout the day. And if they’re unwilling to do even that, I’d strongly prefer they just stay in bed and slip into an endless sleep. I’ve had enough of mindless behavior. Now, I’m not claiming to be the sharpest tool in the shed—but I’m not talking about complex intellectual feats here, so I believe it’s fair to call out sheer stupidity. Let’s focus this rant on just a few specific types for now, and save the rest for another time. Sound good? Great.

original: Two problems with the scenario outlined in my previous post: 1. True, bush is stimulating the economy, but in the wrong way. Urllink robert rubin told npr's marketplace today that bush could have achieved the same stimulus effect without the long term debt hangover by enacting different tax cuts, temporary tax cuts that would benefit low and middle income persons. Ah, robert rubin. The sound of his name is music to our ears. Quick: name one bush administration cabinet official on the domestic side with rubin's gravitas. Still thinking? it'll come to you... 2. We can't give the republicans control only in wartime because they've ingeniously concocted an endless, global 'war on terrorism.'
polished:
The scenario outlined in my previous post presents two key issues:  

1. While Bush is indeed stimulating the economy, his approach is misguided. As Robert Rubin noted on NPR's *Marketplace* today, the same economic stimulus could have been achieved without incurring long-term debt by implementing temporary tax cuts targeted at low- and middle-income earners. Ah, Robert Rubin—his very name carries a reassuring weight. Try naming a single domestic cabinet official in the Bush administration with Rubin's stature. Struggling? It might take a moment...  

2. Granting Republicans exclusive control during wartime is untenable, given their creation of an endless, global "War on Terror." Their strategy ensures perpetual conflict, making this concession unwise.

original: 'she's saying i'm on the run, i'm chasing guys for fun' ~the offspring umm haven't updated in awhile but not much to say.. Went to the cove to see supernothing, they were good as usual, got to chill with tiago :-).. Sat. Went to work and then out w/ joe and rach, met up with steve, tiago and tom.. Came home at like quarter to 12 and woke up the next morning at quarter to 7 for a meet.. Got there a little late but it's all good, i did my full on floor and didn't fall, second on floor and vault and third on beam, 29.45 all around which isn't bad bc my meets get better as the season goes on..
polished:
She's saying I'm on the run, I'm chasing guys for fun" — The Offspring.  

Haven’t updated in a while, but there’s not much to say. Went to The Cove to see Supernothing—they were great as usual, and got to hang out with Tiago.  

On Saturday, I worked, then went out with Joe and Rach. Later met up with Steve, Tiago, and Tom. Got home around 11:45 PM and woke up the next morning at 6:45 AM for a meet.  

Arrived a little late, but it was fine. I did my full floor routine without falling, placed second on floor and vault, and third on beam. Scored 29.45 all-around, which isn’t bad since my meets usually improve as the season progresses.

original: Do you ever have one of those moments when you begin to reflect on life? like you're sitting in math class bored out of your skull, and you wonder what exactly goes on in your brain that makes you understand math? and you realize that you exist and you are in math class and you wonder why. Then you realize how amazing existing is. And suddenly it hits you-the fact that you are going off on this random train of thought is incredibly pathetic. Ever had that happen? i hate that. You know what else i hate? block schedules. Who would ever come up with that idea? anyone can see that sitting through a two and a half hour class in any subject is cruel and unusual punishment.
polished:
Have you ever had one of those moments when you start reflecting on life? Like when you're sitting in math class, utterly bored, and you begin to wonder what exactly happens in your brain that allows you to comprehend math? Then it dawns on you—you exist, you're in math class, and you question why. Suddenly, you're struck by how incredible existence is. And just as quickly, it hits you—the fact that you're spiraling into this random train of thought is downright pitiful. Ever experienced that? I despise it.  

You know what else I hate? Block schedules. Who in their right mind thought that was a good idea? It’s obvious that enduring a two-and-a-half-hour class in any subject is nothing short of cruel and unusual punishment.

original: I think that monpoly has run it's course in my life and i vow to never lay my hands on that damn iron (not a hot one but the piece in the game) again. Tonight andy beat me by a few small dollars and won the farquin game, or maybe i let him win on account of him leaving in a few short hours and me wanting him to feel good on his last night here. Well how ever the story goes it can't compare to this texas sized headache i have at the moment, i've taken some aleve and i must say that they are doing the trick, all i need now is some well deserved r&r your telephone's the one that helped me wrap the cord around your neck... At the drive in
polished:
I believe Monopoly has run its course in my life, and I vow never to lay my hands on that cursed iron piece (not the hot one, but the game token) again. Tonight, Andy beat me by just a few dollars and won the frustrating game—or perhaps I let him win, considering he’s leaving in a few hours and I wanted him to feel good on his last night here. However the story unfolds, it pales in comparison to this Texas-sized headache I’m dealing with right now. I’ve taken some Aleve, and I must say it’s doing the trick. All I need now is some well-deserved rest and relaxation.  

*Your telephone’s the one that helped me wrap the cord around your neck...* — At the Drive-In

original: Well... Today's been a long day. We had to drive home from indiana. I guess i'm gonna sort of have to be choosy what i write about because i could really take up a lot of time and space and i just don't have enough energy. First off i have to say that camp was awesome and even better than i could have expected. God's been doing so much stuff in my life lately and it's just awesome. I've sort of turned over a new leaf i guess, but anyway's back to the beginning. We arrived at the twiggs' house on friday evening and we stayed until we left for camp on monday. Most of what we did was go to the fair, church, a parade, walmart and watched movies.
polished: Well… today has been a long day. We drove back home from Indiana, and I suppose I’ll need to be selective about what I write since I could easily go on for too long, and I’m just too tired. First, I have to say that camp was incredible—even better than I imagined. God has been working in my life so much lately, and it’s truly amazing. I feel like I’ve turned over a new leaf, but anyway, back to the start. We arrived at the Twiggs’ house on Friday evening and stayed until we left for camp on Monday. Most of our time was spent at the fair, church, a parade, Walmart, and watching movies.

original: Today is my last day of summer vacation! waaaaaa! and i have a dentist appointment at 9. I hate that, but i'd rather get it over with than try to schedule it during the first month of my surgery rotation. I'm definitely nervous, scared, jittery, and any other words you can think up for 'hell's no, me's don wanna go' to school. This is going to be a whole new ball game for me. As a perfectionist, i love excelling at everything i do. But starting new things is a bitch. I hate being a pawn (like i told cassie: 'i'm going to be the only pawn on the chessboard who insists on moving like a knight'), and i hate not knowing what's going on.
polished:
Today is the final day of my summer vacation—waaaaaa! I have a dentist appointment at 9, which I’m dreading, but I’d rather get it done now than try to schedule it during the first month of my surgery rotation. Honestly, I’m a bundle of nerves—scared, jittery, and every other synonym for "absolutely not, I don’t want to go" when it comes to school.  

This is going to be an entirely new challenge for me. As a perfectionist, I thrive on excelling in everything I do, but starting something unfamiliar is tough. I despise feeling like a pawn (as I told Cassie: *"I’ll be the only pawn on the chessboard insisting on moving like a knight"*), and I can’t stand not knowing what’s coming next.

original: Arun shourie talks about how, the present governor of uttar pradesh had warned, as far back as 1996, about the impending threat of the rise of a urllink ' third islamic state ' in the subcontinent . T v rajeswar, the former head of the intelligence bureau and the present governor of uttar pradesh had predicted this dire threat in a series of articles published in the hindustan times, way back in 1996. Shourie raises a valid point when he says, does the fact that you now know that he, and not i, to say nothing of mr advani, wrote all that make the warnings ring true? or do you conclude that because he wrote in this refrain, t v rajeswar is a closet communalist and should not be allowed to continue as governor of uttar pradesh?
polished: Arun Shourie discusses how the current Governor of Uttar Pradesh had warned, as early as 1996, about the looming threat of a potential 'third Islamic state' emerging in the subcontinent. T.V. Rajeswar, the former head of the Intelligence Bureau and the incumbent Governor of Uttar Pradesh, had foreseen this grave danger in a series of articles published in *The Hindustan Times* back in 1996. Shourie raises a pertinent question: Does the revelation that Rajeswar—and not he or Mr. Advani—authored those warnings lend them greater credibility? Or does one dismiss the concerns, labeling Rajeswar a closet communalist for his repeated assertions, and argue that he should no longer serve as Governor of Uttar Pradesh?

original: Attitude: bored mood: indifferent, looking forward to tonight been a long hard day in the trenches here today folks, almost no time to write anything for you readers. However it's good to see tigger(now akcron) taking up the reigns herself and making an appearance and talking about things :) not much to say about things, yesterday was shakespeare on the green, was a lovely play, but i had to leave before closing curtain, which kinda sucked, hopefully someday i'll see the entirety of a shakespeare play. But i digress. Akcron is right about the problems with the shower, it sucks, in terms of laughing at her in the shower, you have to admit, the look people get when committing self torture can be pretty entertaining.
polished:
**Polished version:**  

"Attitude: bored. Mood: indifferent, though looking forward to tonight. It’s been a long, hard day in the trenches here today, folks—almost no time to write anything for you readers. Still, it’s good to see Tigger (now Akcron) stepping up and making an appearance, sharing her thoughts. Not much to report otherwise. Yesterday was Shakespeare on the Green—a lovely play, though I had to leave before the final curtain, which was disappointing. Hopefully, someday I’ll see a full Shakespeare performance. But I digress. Akcron is right about the shower issues—it’s terrible. As for laughing at her in the shower, you have to admit, the expressions people make while enduring self-torture can be pretty amusing.

original: All of a sudden, for the past two days, i have been overcome with terrible bouts of exhaustion. Bone dead exhaustion. Last evening, i went home, and just slept off, and only got up when my mother called me around eight thirty. And when i woke up, it was all dark, and i hadn't switched the lights on, so i could not figure out what time or date it was, for a few seconds, it was just my mother's voice in the darkness and me grappling with reality. Wonder why i'm feeling so drained... Nice weather this morning. It was drizzling when i came. Although in calcutta i hear it's been raining for the past three days.
polished:
Suddenly, over the past two days, I’ve been overwhelmed by intense waves of exhaustion—utterly bone-deep fatigue. Yesterday evening, I went home and simply collapsed into sleep, only waking when my mother called me around eight-thirty. When I opened my eyes, the room was pitch black—I hadn’t turned on the lights—and for a few disoriented moments, I couldn’t tell the time or even the date. There was just my mother’s voice in the darkness and me struggling to grasp reality. I wonder why I’ve been feeling so drained…  

The weather was pleasant this morning—a light drizzle as I arrived. Though I hear it’s been raining nonstop in Calcutta for the past three days.

original: Last night was the worst. I threw away the sweater i was knitting. I only had about 14 inches. I lost probably $10 worth of yarn (it's $8 a skein). But it had too many stitches by the time i got to the arm holes and the mohair was knotting itself together as i knitted, so frogging (ripping out rows) didn't work well. The yarn broke a lot. I didn't even swear, which is unusual for me. I just morosely ripped and listened to season two of sex and the city (way to go, library!). And then i got sick of it and threw it away. I suppose i could say i learned a lot while trying to do this sweater.
polished: Last night was truly dreadful. I ended up discarding the sweater I’d been knitting, even though I’d already completed about 14 inches. It was a waste of roughly $10 worth of yarn (at $8 per skein), but by the time I reached the armholes, the stitch count was off, and the mohair kept tangling as I worked. Frogging—undoing rows—was nearly impossible because the yarn kept snapping. Oddly enough, I didn’t even curse, which is rare for me. Instead, I just gloomily unraveled it while binge-watching season two of *Sex and the City* (thanks, library!). Eventually, frustration won out, and I tossed it. I guess you could say I learned a lot from this sweater attempt.

original: Last night in class, we were discussing that week’s assigned reading, urllink getting back into place: toward a renewed study of the place-world, by edward s. Casey . The first chapter deals with “implacement” and the second, “displacement.” in the first chapter, casey makes the distinction that our contemporary world and culture revolves around time as the situating force: we are running out of time, we have saved time, we are just in time. He is trying to make the case that using place as the center of culture gives a more grounded community. (that is a very rough summation, a disclaimer just in case my professor or any other classmate happens to read this post.) so far, this book is the first reading that has grabbed me by the proverbial shoulders.
polished: Last night in class, we discussed the week’s assigned reading: *Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World* by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter examines "implacement," while the second explores "displacement." In the opening chapter, Casey argues that contemporary culture prioritizes time as the central organizing force—evident in phrases like "running out of time," "saving time," or "just in time." He proposes, instead, that centering culture around place fosters a more grounded and connected community. (This is a rough summary—disclaimer in case my professor or classmates come across this post.) So far, this book is the first assigned reading that has truly captivated me.

original: Whatever it is they put into freeze pops to make them those colours, there should be some sort of warning: may make your life a bit bizarre. And whilst giggling is good, one wonders if we would have found ourselves up that fire escape drinking beer in the fierce wind had we not been eating them earlier. Finding ourselves in a doorway to a bar sadly closed for business, we stopped to examine an office-supplies catalogue that had arrived in the post. Lucky we did. Who could possibly have guessed that within these pages were the special offers of a lifetime? not i, for certain. I list but a few: buy 36 permanent marker pens, get a stunt kite. Buy 30 lever arch files, get a barbecue.
polished: Whatever they put in freeze pops to create those vibrant colors should come with a warning: may induce delightful absurdity. Laughter is welcome, of course—but would we have ended up on that fire escape, sipping beer in the howling wind, had we not eaten them earlier? Later, pausing in the doorway of a sadly shuttered bar, we flipped through an office-supplies catalog that had arrived in the mail. Thank goodness we did. Who could have predicted that its pages held the deals of a lifetime? Certainly not me. Just a few highlights: purchase 36 permanent markers, receive a stunt kite. Buy 30 lever-arch files, score a barbecue.

original: Currently listening to: the little drummer boy by stevan pasero ...and now my post... Senate republicans okay, hands up - who watched the 39-hour judicial nominations wankathon last week? i know i didn't. Well, okay - i did tune in once or twice. The entire colossal waste of time was perpetrated by republicans who, pissed off that democrats wouldn't roll over and nominate four of bush's nutjob justices, were trying to score political points by holding a multi-day cry-fest. Never mind the fact that the democrats have already approved 168 of bush's judicial nominees - nooo, that's not good enough for the power-mad republicans who are for some reason laboring under the misapprehension they have a huge mandate for this kind of nonsense.
polished: Currently listening to: *The Little Drummer Boy* by Stevan Pasero... Now, onto my post. Senate Republicans—okay, hands up—who actually watched the 39-hour judicial nominations marathon last week? I’ll admit I didn’t... well, maybe I tuned in briefly. This entire spectacle was orchestrated by Republicans who, frustrated that Democrats refused to rubber-stamp four of Bush’s controversial judicial picks, staged a days-long political tantrum to score points. Never mind that Democrats have already confirmed 168 of Bush’s nominees—apparently, that’s not enough for power-hungry Republicans who somehow believe they have a sweeping mandate for such theatrics.

original: This was a good weekend. I did a lot of god's green leaf, after a long time, i listened to a lot of nevermore (something i should have started doing much earlier) and read a lot. I finished three books over the weekend - bruce sterling's heavy weather, larry niven's world of ptavvs and octavia butler's parable of the sower. Heavy weather was a good cyberpunk romp through a near-future usa, devastated by global warming and general anarchy. While it was clever, well-paced and altogether very convincing, i must confess that i failed to come away with any really significant sensations about the story or the characters. Not that both aren't well constructed and vividly etched - it's a good book, but not a great one, i guess.
polished:
This was a great weekend. I indulged in quite a bit of God’s green leaf, and after far too long, I finally listened to a lot of Nevermore—something I really should have started doing much sooner. I also read extensively, finishing three books over the weekend: Bruce Sterling’s *Heavy Weather*, Larry Niven’s *World of Ptavvs*, and Octavia Butler’s *Parable of the Sower*.  

*Heavy Weather* was an engaging cyberpunk adventure set in a near-future USA ravaged by global warming and societal collapse. While it was clever, well-paced, and thoroughly convincing, I have to admit that neither the story nor the characters left me with any profound impressions. That’s not to say they weren’t well-crafted or vividly portrayed—it’s a solid book, just not an exceptional one, in my opinion.

original: Coz' this is the aftermath the first week back from practicum was a struggle but it is only in the second week that the smoke has really started to clear. Post-practicum trauma was a hidden epidemic that is only now coming to light. I was stricken but with the eventual meeting with the course co-ordinator allowed me to release my burden and by doing so i have prevented another person being stuck with such a pedagogically deficit practicum school. Yesterday (monday) i bumped into another agrieved classmate who was quite determined to go to the student who was due to go to her school in the next practicum and tell him how terrible it will be. I calmed her down and said that we should go to the administrator first.
polished:
Because this is the aftermath—the first week back from practicum was a struggle, but only in the second week has the smoke truly begun to clear. Post-practicum trauma was a hidden epidemic, one only now coming to light. I was affected, but meeting with the course coordinator eventually allowed me to unburden myself, and in doing so, I’ve prevented another person from being stuck in such a pedagogically deficient practicum school.  

Yesterday (Monday), I ran into another aggrieved classmate who was determined to warn the next student assigned to her school about how terrible it would be. I calmed her down and suggested we approach the administrator first.

original: Well, things are incredibly busy here at times...but there's always time for supposed stress relieving activities. I've found that i really suck at 8-ball and ping pong! rick(the canuck) beats my ass on a regular basis - we have a ping pong table in the front lobby of our building, always time for a 'quick round'. Last night i participated in an 8-ball tournament over at the hot spot (our recreation tent - complete with popcorn machine, numerous tv's, jukebox, dvd rental, pool table, dart board, and ever present ping pong table). Anyway, i was doing pretty well throughout my one entire game - until i scratched on the eight ball ;( i still had a fairly good time - the most fun was the two dutch soldiers that joined in the tournament.
polished: Well, things can get incredibly busy here at times...but there’s always room for stress-relieving activities. I’ve discovered that I’m really not great at 8-ball or ping pong! Rick (the Canuck) regularly beats me—we have a ping pong table in the front lobby of our building, so there’s always time for a 'quick round.' Last night, I joined an 8-ball tournament at the Hot Spot (our recreation tent, complete with a popcorn machine, multiple TVs, a jukebox, DVD rentals, a pool table, dartboard, and the ever-present ping pong table). I was actually doing pretty well throughout my entire game—until I scratched on the eight ball. Still, I had a great time—the highlight was the two Dutch soldiers who joined the tournament.

original: Fall 1974: i was attempting for what felt like the 13th time to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then nor am i now a math person. I hate math. I am math phobic. You get the picture. So as i struggled to make sense out of algebra the doorbell rang. I put down my book and went to open the door. No one was there. Great. I returned to my studies and just as i was finding a little glimmer of understanding buried in my sub conscious the doorbell rang again. Bam, just like that my breakthrough disappeared. I went to the door and once again no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs, an uninvited practical joker.
polished:
Fall 1974: I was attempting—for what felt like the thirteenth time—to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then, nor am I now, a math person. I despise math. I am math-phobic. You get the idea.  

As I struggled to make sense of algebra, the doorbell rang. I set my book aside and went to answer it. No one was there. Perfect.  

I returned to my studies and, just as a faint glimmer of understanding began to surface in my subconscious, the doorbell rang again. *Bam*—just like that, my breakthrough vanished. I went to the door, and once more, no one was there. Exactly what a struggling math student needs: an uninvited prankster.

original: This past week has been nothing short of exhausting. I spent tuesday-thursday finishing the move to my new classroom. The new room is bigger and closer to my grade level team, these are the things i need to consider as i spend hours upon hours preparing my room for this year. Had i known i was going to move prior to the end of my school year, i would have discarded much of the books and supplies i no longer use. Unfortunately, it all came with me. So this week was spent moving, unpacking, and purging profusely. I have to thank my teammate jill for helping with all of this. You see, she was still teaching this month, in my old room. So she and her lovely students moved almost my entire room for me!
polished: The past week has been utterly exhausting. From Tuesday through Thursday, I was busy completing the move to my new classroom. While the new space is larger and conveniently closer to my grade-level team—both important factors as I invest countless hours preparing for the year—I couldn’t help but wish I’d known about the move before the school year ended. Had I been aware, I would have discarded many of the unused books and supplies that ultimately came with me. Instead, this week was consumed by moving, unpacking, and aggressively purging unnecessary items. I’m incredibly grateful to my teammate Jill, who—despite still teaching in my old classroom this month—managed to move nearly my entire room for me with the help of her wonderful students!

original: You can't help it, you can't evade it: a piece of you will always live in me. Even if i never carried you child, even if i was never married to you, even if i was never an official pair to you ... I loved you immensely, and to this day the feeling carries an echo through my heart. Forever will i always be reminded of the very few nights we spent together, hearts and limbs entwined in a soul-embrace, drenched in the salty darkness of an evening by the beach ... Or a kiss under the rain. Whenever i get the feeling of a dark glass puncturing my heart, you will be there. That piece of you... Bleeding the eternal love that once lived in me ... And still remains. .. For heri
polished: You cannot escape it, nor deny it: a part of you will always dwell within me. Even if I never bore your child, even if we were never wed, even if we were never bound by title... I loved you deeply, and to this day, that feeling lingers like an echo in my heart. Forever, I will be haunted by the fleeting nights we shared—our hearts and limbs entwined in a soulful embrace, bathed in the salty darkness of a seaside evening... or a kiss beneath the rain. Whenever I feel the sharp sting of sorrow piercing my heart, you will be there. That fragment of you... still bleeding with the eternal love that once flourished within me... and endures. ... For her.

original: I'm uncomfortable. Investigative reporting seems very wrong to me. Or let me rephrase that, the article i'm doing and it's consequences is not exactly something i'm comfortable with. Perhaps it is because i don't believe in it enough, that i cannot really get the complete feel for it. The angst behind it. The full-out passion towards it to question. I've grown up in a country where you don't ask questions. Really, you just don't. They shoot you for that shit. They put you in jail with all these internal security acts. I am not used to this freedom of speech...not used to questioning out loud. Sure, i am not the easiest person to get along with.
polished: I feel uneasy. Investigative reporting strikes me as deeply problematic—or rather, the article I'm working on and its potential repercussions don’t sit well with me. Perhaps it’s because I lack conviction in it, unable to fully grasp its essence—the underlying urgency, the relentless drive to question. I was raised in a country where asking questions wasn’t just discouraged—it was dangerous. They’d shoot you for that. Lock you up under internal security laws. This freedom of speech, this open questioning—it’s unfamiliar to me. Admittedly, I’ve never been the easiest person to get along with.

original: We had an outing yesterday with my co-employees at the bank. We went to guintubdan, la carolota. It was the first time for most of us. We trekked for the falls. It was a 30 minute or so walk. We were all catching our breaths. Whew! but we made it. The water was chilly ice. You can feel your body getting numb because of the coldness. We only stayed less than an hour because we headed for the nearby waterfalls. Another 30 minutes of trekking. But the trip was worth it because the falls looked calming and the whole scene is indeed breathtaking. Its like you can hear yourself being one with nature. Soaking myself in the cold water was like communing with mother earth. The cold air and water were enough to make you be lulled to sleep.
polished: Yesterday, my colleagues from the bank and I went on an outing to Guintubdan in La Carlota. For most of us, it was our first time visiting the place. We trekked to the waterfalls, which took about 30 minutes—a challenging hike that left us all catching our breath. But we made it! The water was icy cold, so chilly that it made our bodies go numb. We didn’t stay long, though, as we moved on to explore another nearby waterfall after less than an hour. Another half-hour trek awaited us, but the effort was worth it—the falls were serene, and the view was truly breathtaking. It felt like being one with nature, as if you could hear your own harmony with the surroundings. Soaking in the cold water was like communing with Mother Earth, and the crisp air and icy streams were so soothing they could lull you to sleep.

original: Well i am sure my sisters are drunk off their butts. Today was pride in san diego. I know my sisters and when it is drinking time, it is drinking time. It is the one thing i didn't get from the buenviajes, the want to drink. There are few times i don't mind drinking but let's just say they are very rare times. So we have a month left before ed leaves. I think it is starting to sink in with ed and with all of us. I think it sunk in with me a long time ago. I just hope that ed will be here for bailey's surgery. We have been keeping an eye on his swelling and there definitely is quite a bit of swelling.
polished:
Well, I’m sure my sisters are completely drunk by now. Today was Pride in San Diego, and I know my sisters—when it’s time to drink, it’s time to drink. That’s one trait I didn’t inherit from the Buenviajes: the desire to drink. There are very few occasions when I don’t mind having a drink, but let’s just say they’re exceptionally rare.  

We have one month left before Ed leaves, and I think it’s finally sinking in—for Ed and for all of us. Honestly, it sank in for me a long time ago. I just hope Ed will still be here for Bailey’s surgery. We’ve been monitoring the swelling, and there’s definitely quite a bit of it.

original: Saturday we took connor to firemans park, thinking that the fireman's easter egg hunt was to start at 11am. It turned out it was on the friday. Thank goodness i brought a bag of eggs with me just incase. So connor had a great time finding eggs out in the park. Sunday morning when he woke up he was so excited that the easter bunny had come. There is nothing better then to see the excitement on your childs face. After egg hunting, we all went to church. Even though the 'easter bunny' is fun and all. We do make sure our kids know the true meaning of the holidays. This was megan's first easter, she looked so cute dressed in her jean dress and stockings :)
polished:
On Saturday, we took Connor to Fireman's Park, assuming the fireman's Easter egg hunt would start at 11 AM. However, we later realized it had actually taken place on Friday. Thankfully, I had brought a bag of eggs just in case, so Connor still had a wonderful time hunting for them in the park.  

When he woke up on Sunday morning, he was thrilled to discover the Easter Bunny had visited. There’s truly nothing more heartwarming than seeing the joy on your child’s face. After the egg hunt, we all attended church. While the Easter Bunny is fun, we always ensure our kids understand the true meaning of the holiday.  

This was Megan’s first Easter, and she looked absolutely adorable in her denim dress and stockings!

**Friday, November 22, 2002**  

Woohoo! My boots are at the house! I forgot and had them delivered to my place instead of work, so now I have to wait another four hours to get them. Argh! These are the Face boots and Tredair Flame boots. I rock!

original: I know in a previous post i protected parents, almost even taking their side, well here's my little change of mind. Parents don't know anything. They think they know you soooo well, maybe even to the point where they can read emotions off your face. They can't. Parents know nothing about us. And when i go upstairs after arguing with nicole about kelli, like i just did a few minutes ago, and they want me to tell them what's wrong. Yeah, how about you shut the fuck up!? i don't have to tell you what's wrong all the time. Here's the situation with nicole and kelli. Kelli and nicole don't like each other. At all.
polished: I defended parents in a previous post, even siding with them to some extent, but I’ve had a slight change of heart. Parents don’t actually know anything. They believe they understand you completely—maybe even to the point of reading your emotions—but they can’t. They know nothing about us. So when I come upstairs after arguing with Nicole about Kelli, like I just did moments ago, and they demand to know what’s wrong—honestly, how about just staying quiet? I don’t owe them an explanation every single time. Here’s the deal with Nicole and Kelli: they can’t stand each other. At all.

original: Pears and peanut butter attempt #2. I have hard pears this time, and my own jar of peanut butter which i can dip the pears into, but it is still crunchy peanut butter not smooth and i definitely think it makes a difference. I am also slightly perturbed as i thought this was a healthy snack and have just noticed that per 5th of a jar (and our jars are way smaller) as in per 100g there are 614 calories!!!!!!!!!! don't think about it. polished:
Pears and peanut butter attempt #2. This time, I have firm pears and my own jar of peanut butter to dip them in—though it's still crunchy rather than smooth, and I truly believe that makes a difference. I’m also a bit unsettled because I initially thought this was a healthy snack, only to realize that per 100g (our jars are much smaller), there are a staggering 614 calories! Best not to dwell on it.  

I just returned from an evening at my old music teacher’s house—who’s also a dear friend. Yes, I know... I missed her for that, but I did record it! I also discovered they’re airing reruns of Series 9 every morning at 9:55. It was lovely catching up with my friend—unusual but nice.

original: Urllink some people are jumping to connect urllink this dot : the urllink organization for security and cooperation in europe was invited to monitor the election by the state department. The observers will come from the osce's office for democratic institutions and human rights. It will be the first time such a team has been present for a u.s. Presidential election. With urllink this dot : a baker's dozen of congressional democrats, among them four new yorkers, has petitioned u.n. Secretary- general kofi annan to dispatch international observers to florida to oversee this year's presidential balloting there. I humbly disagree. Based on the info available, the osce seems to be coming here to learn from the u.s. Election process, not to oversee it, which was the original partisan and childish call for u.n.
polished:
Some people are quick to connect the dots: The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) was invited by the State Department to monitor the election. The observers will come from the OSCE's Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights. This marks the first time such a team will be present for a U.S. presidential election.  

Meanwhile, a group of congressional Democrats—including four New Yorkers—has petitioned U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan to send international observers to Florida to oversee this year's presidential voting there. I respectfully disagree. Based on available information, the OSCE appears to be coming to learn from the U.S. election process, not to oversee it—unlike the initial partisan and immature call for U.N. involvement.

original: My heinous mood has passed. Forthcoming period + forgetting to take prozac until late in the day = very sad, prone to tears kristin. But surprise of boyfriend at my doorstep + ice cream sundae + holding boyfriend's hand after i had a terribly scary dream in which people started shooting machine guns at the news bureau = kristin feeling better. And i don't have to work this morning la la la la la but i do have to call a man at kmiz to get his rate card. And tonight i get to see two of my best girls, amy and kate (hopefully with time to study in between). And tomorrow maybe i will see someone i haven't seen for quite awhile for our ww date.
polished:
My dark mood has lifted. The combination of an upcoming period and forgetting to take my Prozac until late in the day left me feeling deeply sad and tearful. But then my boyfriend surprised me at my doorstep with an ice cream sundae, and later, after I woke from a terrifying dream about people shooting machine guns at the news bureau, he held my hand—which helped me feel better.  

This morning, I don’t have to work—la la la—though I do need to call someone at KMIZ to request their rate card. Tonight, I’ll get to see two of my closest friends, Amy and Kate (hopefully with some time to study in between). And tomorrow, I might finally reunite with someone I haven’t seen in a long time for our WW date.

She had everything—saucers, teapots, coffee cups, wine goblets, water glasses, seven different types of forks and spoons, dinner plates, salad plates, dessert plates, soup bowls, side bowls... original: Gop gets scolded on recruitment naturalization ceremonies in jacksonville are to be relocated after complaints that gop activists registered new citizens as republicans. By gary fineout and alfonso chardy the citizenship ceremony in jacksonville seemed to go off as usual, with a crowd of nearly 200 people going home as new americans. Just before the new citizens left the june 29 event, an immigration official directing the swearing-in urged them to stop by a voter registration table -- a not uncommon sight at naturalization ceremonies. But this table was unusual: those handing out forms were republican volunteers -- and the party affiliation box had been checked off ahead of time to make all of the new voters members of the gop. All of it was suspicious to linda cross, who was there to watch her husband, dario cruz, take his citizenship oath.
polished:
The GOP Faces Criticism Over Recruitment Tactics at Naturalization Ceremonies in Jacksonville  

Naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville are set to be relocated following complaints that GOP activists improperly registered new citizens as Republicans.  

By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy  

The citizenship ceremony in Jacksonville appeared to proceed as usual, with nearly 200 individuals departing as newly minted Americans. However, just before the event concluded on June 29, an immigration official overseeing the swearing-in encouraged attendees to visit a voter registration table—a common practice at such ceremonies.  

This table, however, stood out: the volunteers distributing forms were Republican activists, and the party affiliation box had been pre-checked, automatically enrolling new voters as GOP members.  

The situation raised suspicions for Linda Cross, who attended to witness her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath.

So it’s not exactly playing hooky, but I’ve been saving up some vacation days and decided to use one today—Wednesday the 10th here in Japan (though the post timestamp shows the U.S. date, so technically it’s not accurate). Now I can just relax for a couple of days. There’s nothing like 48 hours of daydreaming to recharge your creative energy.  

I’m lucky as a foreigner, and my timing worked out well too. The illustration gig is just the cherry on top—I’d probably complain more if that hadn’t fallen into my lap. Still, I know I’m getting underpaid; I’m not oblivious to that.  

Starting to feel hungry. Might head over to Speak Easy, that “American-style” diner across from the post office in my little prefecture, and grab some Mexican food.

original: I have always prided myself in making anyone that frequents casa pescatore as comforable as possible. I want them to make sure they feel at home as they will feel in their prospective residence. Yesterday- i hope i succeeded. The masses all congregated on perry ave with what many consider ' extreme prejudice'. 4:30pm was the time my best friend eric and his son nunu came over with a huge pan of baked ziti. The tables were set and i had all the food that i cooked and the bells were ringing crazy. Before i could blink - my best friend from florida walked through the door and that made me smile. I missed that motherfucker so much. The bonus was him bringing his wife along. She is expecting and this is the closest i could get to being an uncle. I spoiled that girl with tray after tray of food and tiramisu.
polished: I’ve always taken pride in ensuring that everyone who visits Casa Pescatore feels as comfortable as possible. My goal is to make them feel at home, just as they would in their own residence. Yesterday—I hope I succeeded. The crowd gathered on Perry Avenue with what many might call 'extreme enthusiasm.' At 4:30 PM, my best friend Eric and his son Nunu arrived with a massive pan of baked ziti. The tables were set, the food I prepared was ready, and the atmosphere was electric. Before I knew it, my best friend from Florida walked through the door, and that brought a huge smile to my face. I’d missed that guy so much. The cherry on top was him bringing his wife along—she’s expecting, and this is the closest I’ve come to being an uncle. I spoiled her with tray after tray of food and tiramisu.

original: I liked the idea of that as an offence - maybe that could've been a way out of being burned as a witch. As a non-american blogger i've been a little reluctant to get involved in some of these discussions, particularly the bits about flags, but since i started it (the subject, not the flag-burning) i suppose i'd better say something. Firstly, i think that the idea of having a law against flag-burning is completely nuts. The moment you start according a symbol - any symbol - that kind of automatic reverence and protection, you've taken a small but important step towards totalitarianism. Symbols are kind of fickle - they don't a priori represent anything in themselves; it's what they are perceived as meaning or made to represent that's important.
polished: I liked the idea of treating that as an offense—perhaps it could have been a way to avoid being condemned as a witch. As a non-American blogger, I’ve been somewhat hesitant to engage in certain discussions, especially those involving flags. But since I initiated the topic (the subject, not the flag-burning), I suppose I ought to weigh in. First, I believe the notion of criminalizing flag-burning is utterly absurd. The instant you grant a symbol—any symbol—that kind of unquestioning reverence and legal protection, you’ve taken a small yet significant step toward totalitarianism. Symbols are inherently unstable—they don’t inherently represent anything; their meaning lies in perception and the significance we assign to them.

1. Everyone has that one movie or series they're obsessed with—what's yours? For me, it's the *Evil Dead* series (in case it wasn't obvious). I even have one of the largest collections of memorabilia from those films.  

2. Do you play any instruments? If so, which one? Bass guitar—and yes, I absolutely rock out on it.  

3. What’s your biggest money-wasting vice? Either my compulsive DVD purchases or my weakness for the latest tech gadgets.  

4. Any phobias, allergies, or compulsive behaviors? None, none, and—well, I *must* arrange all the bills in my wallet from smallest to largest at all times.  

5. How much wood could a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could chuck wood? Because I said so.

original: Holla so i saw troy tonight with my family...i was not impressed. I'm too tired to go way into specifics, but i do think it had potential. However, i think too much energy was spent on the set (which was magnificent) and not enough on creating a solidifying tone, theme, etc. It retold the story, but it was not particularly gripping, and i don't feel like i gained anything from watching it. The character development was rather weak. Additionally, i thought the score was poor, and was basically a knock-off of the gladiator. The gladiator used the background music of a moaning woman and it worked b/c it backed up and complemented a genuinely gripping narrative.
polished: Hey, so I watched *Troy* tonight with my family... and I wasn’t impressed. I’m too tired to go into detail, but I do think it had potential. However, it felt like too much effort went into the set (which was stunning) and not enough into crafting a cohesive tone or theme. It retold the story, but it wasn’t particularly engaging, and I didn’t feel like I gained much from watching it. The character development was weak. Also, I thought the score was lackluster—basically a cheap imitation of *Gladiator*. *Gladiator* used that haunting female vocal in the background music effectively because it supported and enhanced a truly compelling narrative.

original: Urllink lets all give a big hello to the newest atom/rdf/rss reader on the block, urllink pulpfiction 1.0 from urllink freshly squeezed software . It looks like it has a lot of native app goodness. It should be noted that it is not free or free, since that seems to be a 'hot topic' on the interweb again. You can try it for 15 days and then go back to something else, or pony up $25 if you like it. A feature that jumps out at me right away is how each post is its own entity, and can be moved around, stored, labeled, and even deleted. I could easily see how this would make some news tracker type people very happy. It imports and exports opml, as you might expect.
polished: Urllink invites everyone to welcome the latest Atom/RDF/RSS reader on the scene: Urllink PulpFiction 1.0, developed by Urllink Freshly Squeezed Software. This app appears to deliver a robust native experience. It’s worth noting that it isn’t free—a point of frequent discussion online. You can test it for 15 days before deciding whether to switch back or purchase it for $25. One standout feature is how each post functions as an independent unit, allowing you to move, store, label, or delete it with ease. This could be a game-changer for news trackers. As expected, it supports OPML import and export.

original: Today... I miss my sister terribly - it just seems strange not to have her hanging around, irritating me (just joking...). Even though it was only for a week, she really made her presence felt, and i mean that in a good way. Just doing the scrapbook for our trtip to tasmania brings fond memories of a time past recently - last week in fact. Maybe it's just the thought that i won't see her for quite a while - with her going to bristol in sept/oct and all. She represented, on a deeper level, a link to my family back home. Oh how i miss them all. Tomorrow is the start of a new term. How did the holidays fly by so quickly?
polished: Today, I miss my sister terribly—it feels strange not having her around, even if she could be a bit irritating at times (just kidding, of course). Though she was only here for a week, her presence left a lasting impression, and I mean that in the best way. Working on the scrapbook from our trip to Tasmania brings back such warm memories—memories that, honestly, feel so recent, as they were just last week. Perhaps it’s the realization that I won’t see her for quite some time, especially with her move to Bristol in September or October. On a deeper level, she was my connection to family back home, and now… I just miss them all so much. Tomorrow marks the start of a new term. How did the holidays pass by in the blink of an eye?

original: Ever have one of those days when you just don't know what the... What the... Anything? no? well then you should skip the rest of this because it won't make any sense to you. To those of you choosing to continue on i offer the following observation. ' sometimes i wish i'd been given the manual .' manuals, if done correctly at least, let you know: what things are for, what they can do, how they do the things they do, what happens if you push button x or y, what to do if things aren't doing what they're supposed to the phone number and email address of the omniscient guru who can solve every problem very useful information. Unfortunately i didn't get a manual with me.
polished:
Ever had one of those days when you just don’t know what the... what the... anything? No? Well, then you might as well skip the rest of this—it won’t make much sense to you. For those still reading, here’s an observation: *Sometimes I wish I’d been given the manual.*  

Manuals, if done right, tell you exactly what things are for, what they can do, and how they work. They explain what happens when you press button X or Y, what to do when things go wrong, and even provide the phone number and email of an all-knowing guru who can fix any problem—extremely useful stuff.  

Too bad I didn’t come with one.

original: And there's nothing wrong with pcs -- if i were a full-bore gamer with time to do such a thing, i'd certainly have a pc system for the wealth of available games. Though except for a few unique products, that huge wall of games at compusa starts getting repetetive after a while -- at first i'm envious, then i start noticing that it's really just a lot of different flavors of the same soda...first-person shooters, mystery games, strategy games, simulations. There are so many variations of age of empires it becomes comical. Aoe -- with orcs! aoe -- with spaceships! aoe -- with fuzzy wombats! it's like the endless movie trailers that begin with the line: 'in a world...'
polished: There’s nothing wrong with PCs—if I were a dedicated gamer with the time for it, I’d absolutely own a PC system for the sheer abundance of available games. Yet, aside from a few standout titles, that massive wall of games at CompUSA begins to feel repetitive after a while. At first, I’m envious, but then I start noticing it’s mostly just different flavors of the same soda—first-person shooters, mystery games, strategy titles, simulations. The sheer number of *Age of Empires* variations borders on absurdity. *AOE—with orcs! AOE—with spaceships! AOE—with fuzzy wombats!* It’s like those endless movie trailers that all start with the same line: *"In a world..."*

original: Lblair (non-privileged).pst -----original message----- from: threet, kay sent: thursday, june 28, 2001 11:08 am to: blair, lynn cc: stevens, bob; neville, sue; cabrera, reyna subject: nsp powerpac issues lynn, following our discussion yesterday afternoon, reyna and i came back and reviewed the nsp powerpac agreement. We were specifically looking for language in this agreement which may require us to true up for the customer regardless of whether or not we were allocating storage on a given gas day. We couldn't put our finger on any language in the current agreement (dated april 1, 2001) that requires us to true up for them, but perhaps we overlooked or misinterpreted something.
polished:
**Subject:** NSP PowerPac Issues  

**From:** Threet, Kay  
**Sent:** Thursday, June 28, 2001, 11:08 AM  
**To:** Blair, Lynn  
**CC:** Stevens, Bob; Neville, Sue; Cabrera, Reyna  

**File:** LBlair (Non-Privileged).pst  

Lynn,  

Following our discussion yesterday afternoon, Reyna and I reviewed the NSP PowerPac agreement. We specifically examined the language to determine whether it requires us to reconcile adjustments for the customer, irrespective of storage allocation on a given gas day.  

While we couldn’t identify any explicit provision in the current agreement (dated April 1, 2001) mandating such reconciliation, it’s possible we may have overlooked or misinterpreted certain clauses.  

Best regards,  
Kay

original: Jdasovic.nsf monday, december 11, 2000 to: all px market participants from: john yurkanin chief operating officer re: loss of continuity in px day ahead auction due to iso rule changes the emergency tariff filing by the california iso last friday has had a negative effect on the px day ahead auction market. The mixture of soft and hard caps results in a complete disconnect and unacceptable risk to all of our participants and will probably not provide the iso with its sought after reduction in real time energy sales and procurement. The overall effect will be that supply will still defer to the higher realized price opportunity the iso offers. The px is petitioning terry winter of the iso to immediately allow for adjustment bids on any submitted schedule at any price relevant.
polished:
**Polished Version:**  

*Jdasovic.nsf*  
Monday, December 11, 2000  

**To:** All PX Market Participants  
**From:** John Yurkanin, Chief Operating Officer  
**Re:** Loss of Continuity in PX Day-Ahead Auction Due to ISO Rule Changes  

The emergency tariff filing by the California ISO last Friday has adversely impacted the PX day-ahead auction market. The combination of soft and hard caps creates a complete disconnect, introducing unacceptable risk for all participants. Furthermore, it is unlikely to achieve the ISO’s intended reduction in real-time energy sales and procurement.  

The broader consequence will be that supply will continue to favor the higher realized price opportunities offered by the ISO. In response, the PX is petitioning Terry Winter of the ISO to promptly permit adjustment bids on any submitted schedule at any relevant price.

original: Mark guzman 6-28-02.nsf just wanted to make sure you saw this from les rawson concerning grays harbor and willamette. -bill beginning immediately enron has purchased control area reserves service from bpa. The allows services to sell unit contingent energy as hourly firm since bpa is suppling reserves for up to 60 minutes. If grays harbor paper notifies rt of a unit derate or outage rt should notify bpa dispatch immediately and make the reduction in the schedule during the next ramp. For example should grays unit trip as 1333 rt would notify bpa and the sink that across the top of the hour for 1400 the schedule would be taken to zero for he 1400. The bottom line is that 60 minutes is the maximum time bpa will carry the schedule.
polished:
Mark Guzman 6-28-02.nsf – Just wanted to confirm you received this note from Les Rawson regarding Grays Harbor and Willamette.  

-Bill  

Effective immediately, Enron has secured control area reserves service from BPA. This arrangement enables services to sell unit-contingent energy as hourly firm, given that BPA is providing reserves for up to 60 minutes.  

If Grays Harbor Paper notifies RT of a unit derate or outage, RT must promptly inform BPA Dispatch and adjust the schedule during the next ramp. For instance, if Grays Harbor’s unit trips at 13:33, RT should notify BPA and the sink that, by the top of the hour (14:00), the schedule will be reduced to zero for the 14:00 interval.  

The key takeaway is that BPA will maintain the schedule for a maximum of 60 minutes.

original: Cstclai.nsf ---------------------- forwarded by carol st clair/hou/ect on 05/05/2000 04:11 pm --------------------------- carol st clair 04/26/2000 04:41 pm to: rod nelson/hou/ect@ect cc: subject: deutsche bank rod: here are their credit issues: 1. In the cross-default language that want to add language that basically says that even if a cross-default occurs, unless the non-defaulting determines in good faith that performance by the defaulting party of its obligations under the master is "endangered", then no cross default is triggered. 2. In credit event upon merger we had commented that instaed of the "materially weaker" standard we wanted to specify that it meant being rated below bbb- by s&p. Do you feel strongly about this?
polished:
---  
**Forwarded by Carol St. Clair/HOU/ECT on 05/05/2000 04 11 PM**  

**From ** Carol St. Clair  
**Sent ** 04/26/2000 04 41 PM  
**To ** Rod Nelson/HOU/ECT@ECT  
**Cc **  
**Subject ** Deutsche Bank  

Rod,  

Here are their credit-related concerns   

1. **Cross-default language** – They propose adding wording stating that even if a cross-default occurs, no default is triggered unless the non-defaulting party determines in good faith that the defaulting party’s ability to perform its obligations under the master agreement is "endangered."  

2. **Credit event upon merger** – We previously suggested replacing the "materially weaker" standard with a specific requirement that the entity be rated below BBB- by S&P. Do you have strong objections to this change?  

---

original: Khyatt (non-privileged).pst el paso tests market for mainline expansion el paso natural gas apparently got the message when its last open season for 1.2 bcf/d of firm transportation capacity attracted bids for 14.4 bcf/d. The pipeline has announced an open season to test market interest in a mainline expansion and to satisfy regulatory concerns that something needs to be done to relieve the apparent capacity constraint at the california border. El paso has been under significant pressure from regulators and shippers to expand because of enormous demand and skyrocketing prices in california. In a jan. 3 letter to the pipeline, daniel m. Adamson, director of ferc's office of energy projects, urged el paso to consider modifying its line 2000 project to "assist the difficult situation" now facing the california gas market.
polished:
Khyatt (non-privileged).pst  

El Paso tests market for mainline expansion.  

El Paso Natural Gas clearly took note when its last open season for 1.2 Bcf/d of firm transportation capacity drew bids for 14.4 Bcf/d. The pipeline has now launched an open season to gauge market interest in a mainline expansion and address regulatory concerns about relieving the apparent capacity constraints at the California border.  

El Paso has faced mounting pressure from regulators and shippers to expand its system, driven by surging demand and soaring gas prices in California. In a January 3 letter to the pipeline, Daniel M. Adamson, Director of FERC’s Office of Energy Projects, urged El Paso to consider modifying its Line 2000 project to help alleviate the "difficult situation" currently impacting California’s gas market.

original: Sscott5.nsf ahimsa (uh-him-sah) noun the principle of noninjury to living beings. [sanskrit ahimsa : a-, not + himsa, injury (from himsati, he injures).] "as my conception of ahimsa went on maturing, i became more vigilant about my thought and speech. The lines in the anthem: scatter her enemies and make them fall; confound their policies, frustrate their knavish tricks particularly jarred upon my sentiments of ahimsa." m.k. Gandhi, the story of my experiments with truth, 1927. Today is october 2, the day mohandas karamchand gandhi was born in the year 1869. A man born some two centuries ago may appear irrelevant to our age, but in reality his life and message are still applicable to our lives today.
polished:
**Polished Text:**  

*Ahimsa* (uh-him-sah) *noun*: The principle of nonviolence toward all living beings. [Sanskrit *ahimsa*: *a-*, not + *himsa*, injury (from *himsati*, he injures).]  

*"As my understanding of ahimsa deepened, I grew more mindful of my thoughts and words. The lines in the anthem—'Scatter her enemies and make them fall; confound their policies, frustrate their knavish tricks'—particularly clashed with my commitment to ahimsa."* —M.K. Gandhi, *The Story of My Experiments with Truth*, 1927.  

Today, October 2, marks the birth anniversary of Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi in 1869. Though born over a century ago, his life and teachings remain profoundly relevant to our world today.

original: Mgrigsb.nsf ? over the weekend, gov. Davis and senate polance made an informal agreement whereby senate polance has agreed to sponsor the socal mou bill. Polanco is a democrat and is currently suffering through a personal scandal and as a result, it is reported that his political career is essential dead. Polance is planning to run for mayor of los angeles rather than run for another senate term. ? the bill is expected to be introduced in the new extraordinary session, beginning today or tomorrow. The bill would first go to the senate energy committee. Sen. Bowen, the chair of the committee, strongly opposes the mou, so the bill is expected to remain in committee hearings for some time. The longer the bill is involved in committee politics and changes are made, the likelihood of a socal bankruptcy increases.
polished:
Mgrigsb.nsf — Over the weekend, Gov. Davis and Sen. Polanco reached an informal agreement in which Polanco has agreed to sponsor the SoCal MOU bill. Polanco, a Democrat, is currently embroiled in a personal scandal, and reports suggest his political career is effectively over. Instead of seeking another Senate term, Polanco plans to run for mayor of Los Angeles.  

The bill is expected to be introduced in the new extraordinary session, starting today or tomorrow. It would first go to the Senate Energy Committee, where Sen. Bowen, the committee chair and a staunch opponent of the MOU, is likely to delay its progress. The longer the bill remains in committee hearings and undergoes revisions, the greater the risk of a SoCal bankruptcy.

original: Sshackle.nsf notice no. 00-338 october 3, 2000 memorandum to: all nymex and comex members from: neal l. Wolkoff, executive vice president date: october 3, 2000 re: notice of cftc approval of new nymex rule 6.40c: ("average price calculations by futures commission merchants") please be advised that the cftc has approved new nymex rule 6.40c ("average price calculations by futures commission merchants"), which is attached and is now in effect. New nymex rule 6.40c, which is consistent with a recent cftc "advisory," permits fcms, under certain conditions specified in the rule, to use their own internal, proprietary systems to generate average price ("ap") calculations when multiple prices are received on an order or series of orders.
polished:
**Memorandum**  

**To:** All NYMEX and COMEX Members  
**From:** Neal L. Wolkoff, Executive Vice President  
**Date:** October 3, 2000  
**Re:** Notice of CFTC Approval of New NYMEX Rule 6.40C ("Average Price Calculations by Futures Commission Merchants")  

Please be advised that the CFTC has approved new NYMEX Rule 6.40C ("Average Price Calculations by Futures Commission Merchants"), which is attached and is now in effect.  

This rule, consistent with a recent CFTC advisory, permits FCMs—under specified conditions outlined in the rule—to utilize their own internal, proprietary systems to generate average price (AP) calculations when multiple prices are received on an order or series of orders.

original: Sshackle.nsf as of this week enrononline has just started offering us/canadian dollar swaps online. As part of my review in determining whether a counterparty can transact these products online i look at the financial trading agreement database to see if there are any restrictions indicated, check the master swap agreement, and i am also looking at any board resolutions we might have received when we got the master agreement executed. What i am finding is that in the old days when we asked for resolutions evidencing the authority to enter into the master agreement/derivative transactions frequently the resolutions do not allow the counterparies to enter into currency transactions. Since transacting these currency transactions with our energy customers is a new area of business for us i just wanted us all to be mindful to check these old resolutions and not to rely solely on the "restrictions" contained in lotus notes.
polished:
As of this week, EnronOnline has begun offering US/Canadian dollar swaps online. As part of my review process to determine whether a counterparty can transact these products online, I examine the Financial Trading Agreement database for any indicated restrictions, verify the Master Swap Agreement, and review any board resolutions received upon execution of the master agreement.  

What I’ve observed is that in the past, when we requested resolutions authorizing counterparties to enter into the master agreement or derivative transactions, these resolutions often did not permit currency transactions. Since engaging in currency transactions with our energy customers represents a new business area for us, I wanted to remind everyone to carefully review these older resolutions rather than relying solely on the restrictions listed in Lotus Notes.

original: Dhyvl.nsf dave, i will be glad to generate the form of transaction agreement; however, i have a number of questions. 1. Relationship of delivery point and the use of interruptible transport on northwest pipeline. Is the transport upstream or downstream of the delivery point? if downstream, why isn't it being contracted for by eweb. 2. What volume is being sold each day. You use the term dcq and you also talk about a 20% tolerance above or below the estimated quantity. Normally their would be no tolerance with a dcq transaction. 3. Is this envisioned to be a requirements transaction. Is the price the same for volumes in excess of the estimated quantity up to an additional 20%.
polished:
Dear Dave,  

I’d be happy to draft the transaction agreement, but I have a few questions for clarification:  

1. **Delivery Point and Interruptible Transport**: What is the relationship between the delivery point and the use of interruptible transport on the Northwest Pipeline? Is the transport upstream or downstream of the delivery point? If downstream, why isn’t EWEB contracting for it?  

2. **Daily Volume and DCQ**: You mentioned a daily contract quantity (DCQ) along with a 20% tolerance above or below the estimated quantity. Typically, a DCQ transaction wouldn’t include such a tolerance—could you clarify this?  

3. **Requirements Transaction**: Is this intended to be a requirements transaction? Also, will the price remain the same for volumes exceeding the estimated quantity, up to an additional 20%?  

Looking forward to your response so I can proceed accordingly.

original: Jdasovic.nsf the spreadsheet below gives the implicit commodity based on the effective date of four different rates for the same rate schedule (schedule dr). The rate schedule effective august 2000 through september 2000 yields a much larger commodity charge because sdg&e customers will receive a lump sum reimbursement from sdg&e over those two months. Sdg&e customers will expect lower electric bills. Assuming that the lump sum reimbursement is not included in the implicit energy component, the average for june 2000 through january 2001 is 6.2 cts and the implicit commodity average from february 2001 through december 2001 is 7.3 cts. The average implicit commodity from june 2000 through december 2001 is 6.9 cts for deliveries starting september 1, 2000, the average would still be 6.9 cts.
polished:
The spreadsheet "Jdasovic.nsf" below outlines the implicit commodity rates based on the effective dates of four different rate schedules (Schedule DR). The rate schedule effective from August 2000 through September 2000 results in a significantly higher commodity charge because SDG&E customers will receive a lump sum reimbursement from SDG&E during those two months. Consequently, SDG&E customers can anticipate lower electric bills.  

Assuming the lump sum reimbursement is excluded from the implicit energy component, the average rate from June 2000 through January 2001 is 6.2 cents, while the implicit commodity average from February 2001 through December 2001 is 7.3 cents. The overall average implicit commodity rate from June 2000 through December 2001 is 6.9 cents. For deliveries starting September 1, 2000, the average remains unchanged at 6.9 cents.
