original: Tdonoho (non-privileged).pst this has been a tough couple of weeks. I hope that these daily communications on new developments are helping you understand what's happening with our company. Here's a rundown of events from last week: we executed a commitment letter with jpmorgan and salomon smith barney that will provide us with additional secured credit lines worth $1 billion. Our northern natural gas company and transwestern pipeline company will support these assets. We now have received a total of $4 billion in credit lines, which we will use to pay off short-term commercial debt and maintain liquidity. Our board of directors elected a new member to the board - william powers, jr., the dean of the university of texas school of law in austin, texas.
polished:
To whom it may concern (non-privileged),  

It has been a challenging few weeks. I hope these daily updates on new developments are helping you stay informed about our company's situation. Below is a summary of last week's key events:  

We finalized a commitment letter with JPMorgan and Salomon Smith Barney, securing additional credit lines totaling $1 billion. These assets will be supported by our Northern Natural Gas Company and TransWestern Pipeline Company. With this, we now have access to $4 billion in total credit lines, which we will use to repay short-term commercial debt and ensure liquidity.  

Additionally, our Board of Directors welcomed a new member—William Powers, Jr., Dean of the University of Texas School of Law in Austin, Texas.

original: Skean.nsf i am attaching the ferc order and staff recommendations. The order provides for $69 million in "potential" refunds (either pay up or provide cost justification). Enron was not named as one of the 13 overcharging parties, but pge was ($3.18 million). It's not over yet, though. The order deals only with jan 01 and promises further orders regarding dec 00 and benchmark prices through april 01. The prices used to determine refunds were fairly high ($273/mwh based on gas prices, emissions costs and an assumed heat rate of over 16000). With respect to sales to california, we have concluded at least one short term sale and have talked with cal dept of water resources about longer term deals, but we were still struggling with credit issues, last i heard.
polished:
"I am attaching the FERC order and staff recommendations in the file 'skean.nsf.' The order outlines $69 million in 'potential' refunds (requiring parties to either pay or provide cost justification). While Enron was not listed among the 13 overcharging parties, PG&E was named (with $3.18 million in refunds). However, this is not the final resolution—the order only addresses January 2001, with further rulings expected for December 2000 and benchmark prices through April 2001.  

The refund calculations were based on relatively high prices ($273/MWh, factoring in gas prices, emissions costs, and an assumed heat rate exceeding 16,000). Regarding California sales, we have finalized at least one short-term agreement and have discussed longer-term deals with the California Department of Water Resources. However, as of the latest update, credit-related challenges remain unresolved.

original: It puts the ball in the net or it gets the hose again. Absolutely amazing, have nothing negative to say about this game as it's exceeded my expectations and will probably exeed yours too. Fluid movement, bug/crash free, lots of story/content to put you through, options for each and every day such as multiple practices, events (sponsorships) and even games. This review is purely based on playing mycareer, and so far it's 10/10. Facescan worked really well for me (used it two times, first one made me have a downsyndrome forehead though..). Keep in mind, using the mynba2k17 app will allow for you to facescan for free and allow you to earn daily vc. #sellout
polished: It sinks the ball in the net—or it gets the hose again. Absolutely incredible; I have no complaints about this game as it’s surpassed my expectations and will likely exceed yours too. Smooth movement, no bugs or crashes, plenty of story and content to keep you engaged, with daily options like multiple practices, events (including sponsorships), and even games. This review focuses solely on MyCareer mode, and so far, it’s a perfect 10/10. The face scan worked well for me (though my first attempt gave me an oddly shaped forehead—fixed on the second try). Pro tip: Using the MyNBA2K17 app lets you scan your face for free and earn daily VC. #WorthIt

original: Magic fans beware... Wizards is afraid to make a decent digital game. At its core magic the gathering is a social game. A game to enjoy with your friends (or frenemies) laughing, talking smack, and dropping game winning bombs. Wizards of the coast seems to have forgotten this. If you choose to play with friends you cant earn gold, and gold is important. Gold is so important that they have implemented a daily cap, understandable considering gold unlocks everything in game. But get ready for a long and boring 1v1 grind against the computer or random oponents, whom you can't even speak to. If you choose to play for free, it will take you roughly 4 hours a day for upwards of a month, by yourself, to unlock the cards.
polished: Magic fans, be warned... Wizards seems hesitant to create a truly engaging digital game. At its heart, Magic: The Gathering is a social experience—a game meant to be shared with friends (or frenemies), filled with laughter, playful banter, and game-changing plays. Unfortunately, Wizards of the Coast appears to have lost sight of this. If you opt to play with friends, you miss out on earning gold, which is crucial in-game. Gold is so vital that they’ve even imposed a daily cap—understandable, since it unlocks nearly everything. But brace yourself for a tedious, solitary grind in 1v1 matches against AI or silent strangers. If you’re playing for free, expect to spend roughly four hours daily for over a month, alone, just to unlock the cards.

original: Being the 3rd installment in the trilogy i'll get the bad stuff out of the way first. I quite hate pre-quals as it's technically going backwards in a story and not forwards (this is an issue for every pre-qual). Granted it offers more storywise. The combat feels sloppy and doesn't feel as sharp as arkham city managed to make it. As of writing this recommendation (26/10/2013) there is a game breaking bug that stops a side mission from ever being completed (main story not effected). Some gadgets are put at a rediculous hotkey that makes your hand have to travel the whole keyboard to get to it. It might sound like nothing, but while in combat it could potentially break your combo.
polished: As the third installment in the trilogy, I’ll address the drawbacks first. I’ve never been fond of prequels, as they inherently move a story backward rather than forward—a common issue with the genre. That said, it does expand the narrative in meaningful ways. The combat lacks precision and feels less refined compared to the tight mechanics of *Arkham City*. At the time of writing this review (26/10/2013), there’s a game-breaking bug that prevents a side mission from being completed (though the main story remains unaffected). Some gadgets are assigned to awkward hotkeys, forcing your hand to stretch across the entire keyboard—a minor annoyance in theory, but one that can disrupt your combat flow and break combos.

original: They basically fixed shadow warrior (2013) i.e. The bossfights are awesome, weapons feel very nice (maybe not as good as d44m's ones, but still solid), enemies aren't too spongy (if you're not too much of a retard with handling elemental and upgrade stuff). The upgrade system is really balanced and once you get around it, it's not too tedious. The elemental stuff and limited ammo softly forces you to use different weapons. Lots of cool unique (being the important word here while comparing sw2 to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ borderlands' formula of 'rng' weapons) weapons that stay viable through most of the game. The music is great, especially the main theme and of course stan bush's stuff.
polished: They’ve effectively improved *Shadow Warrior (2013)*—the boss fights are fantastic, the weapons feel great (maybe not quite as refined as *DOOM 2016*'s, but still solid), and enemies aren’t overly tanky (unless you mishandle elemental and upgrade mechanics). The upgrade system is well-balanced and becomes intuitive without feeling tedious. The elemental mechanics and limited ammo gently encourage experimenting with different weapons. There’s also a variety of genuinely unique weapons (a key distinction from *Borderlands*’ reliance on RNG-based loot) that remain useful throughout most of the game. The soundtrack is excellent, particularly the main theme and, of course, Stan Bush’s contributions.

original: So many things was made wrong. I even dont know how to start this review. This all is refered to mycareer. My player is an outside scorer, pg, 1.71m, has maxed stats and got already all necessary perks. Ok, and now tell me, why the shooting skill depends to a person's hight? why a person who has 1.74m can not became so good in shooting as a person with 1.71m? i'm 1.87m in rl, made my first player with this hight and noticed then i can not reach a higher skill than 89. Why? thats a pure discrimination! and why the game does not tell me that before i create a char and not even then when i reach the skill limit after weeks of playing?!?
polished: So many things were done wrong. I don’t even know where to begin with this review. This all relates to my career mode. My player is an outside scorer, a point guard, standing at 1.71m, with maxed stats and all the necessary perks. Now, explain to me why shooting skill depends on a player’s height? Why can’t someone who is 1.74m be as good at shooting as someone who is 1.71m? In real life, I’m 1.87m tall, so I initially created my player at this height—only to later discover I couldn’t exceed an 89 skill rating. Why? That’s pure discrimination! And why doesn’t the game warn me about this before I create my character, or even when I hit the skill cap after weeks of playing?!

original: I think this assassin's creed nailed the mechanics down on all fronts (ship battles, sailing, hunting (fish), parkour, etc). I felt much more attached to this character as well. The story starts out extremely rough but does get much much better as you play (i think this is with every ac game personally). Edward was quite the interesting character and so was all the side characters. I felt like all the collectables actually meant something in this ac game that i never got from any of the previous ones and maybe its because i felt like they had a bigger purpose in the game. They def were not required but they were fun to get and you got rewarded in a very balanced way.
polished: I believe this Assassin's Creed installment perfected the mechanics across all aspects—ship battles, sailing, fishing, parkour, and more. I also felt a deeper connection to the protagonist. While the story begins somewhat uneven, it improves significantly as you progress (a trend I’ve noticed in most AC games). Edward was a compelling character, as were the supporting cast. The collectibles in this game felt more meaningful than in previous entries, perhaps because they served a greater purpose within the world. They weren’t mandatory, but they were enjoyable to pursue, offering well-balanced rewards.

original: While i personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn't absolutely terrible. The gunplay is alright, so long as you have the money to purchase gun parts, which would be my main complaint with this game: it's pay-to-win. If i could get past that, the game would be enjoyable, as the hardsuit is fun to use and hrv is an excellent idea. I'd take this game over any call of duty title any day, but its pay-to-win microtransanction format is off-putting for me. If you are alright with this model, then by all means, have fun. But if you're like me and dislike pay-to-win games, just let this one slide; it's not our cup of tea.
polished: While I personally can't recommend this game, it wasn't completely awful. The gunplay is decent, provided you have the funds to buy gun parts—which brings me to my primary criticism: it's pay-to-win. If I could overlook that aspect, the game would actually be enjoyable, as the hardsuit is a blast to use and HRV is a brilliant concept. I'd choose this over any Call of Duty title without hesitation, but its pay-to-win microtransaction system is a dealbreaker for me. If you're fine with this model, then by all means, enjoy it. But if you share my distaste for pay-to-win mechanics, it's best to pass—this one just isn't for us.

original: While not perfect, this game has been greatly enjoyable. The save system and possibility of sudden death leads to some frustration. I'm on my first playthrough and i lost my main character around hour 10 of 20ish. Would have really liked a save to reload at that point. I've since picked up a 3rd party mod/save tool to avoid catastrophic failures. Plus the aiming reticule is on the small side and zoom is underpowered. With all that said, its been a blast. I'm not normally a zombie fan, but the combination of strategy, missions, first person shooter/beat em up is great. I've been playing it as often as i can get away... Just one more mission, just one more supply run - or i'm running away and want to get safe before shutting the game down.
polished:
While not flawless, this game has been incredibly enjoyable. The save system and risk of sudden death can lead to occasional frustration—during my first playthrough, I lost my main character around the 10-hour mark of a roughly 20-hour campaign, and I really wished for a reloadable save at that point. Since then, I’ve started using a third-party mod/save tool to prevent catastrophic failures. Additionally, the aiming reticle is a bit small, and the zoom feels underpowered.  

That said, it’s been an absolute blast. I’m not usually a fan of zombie games, but the mix of strategy, missions, and first-person shooter/brawler mechanics is fantastic. I’ve been playing whenever I can—always telling myself, "Just one more mission," or "One more supply run," or fleeing to safety before quitting. It’s hard to put down.

original: An absolute great stragtegy game! having played every single other wargame (european escalation, and alb), i have to say this one fits well. The number of units are great. Not sure exactly how many units there are, but there's a crap ton!!! graphics are just beautiful, sounds are great, and the gameplay overall is epic. The ingame chat box at the main menu is very entertaining as well, no i am not kidding. However, if anyone thinking this game is 'easy', or if you are new to the strategy genre, it could take you quite some time to get it nailed down. Do not get upset, you will lose a lot of units. Just make sure you plan ahead, always have anti-air, and anti-tank.
polished: An absolutely fantastic strategy game! Having played every other wargame in the series (European Escalation and ALB), I can confidently say this one stands out. The sheer number of units is impressive—I’m not sure of the exact count, but there’s a ton! The graphics are stunning, the sound design is excellent, and the gameplay is truly epic. Even the in-game chat box on the main menu is surprisingly entertaining—no joke. That said, if you think this game is 'easy' or you're new to the strategy genre, be prepared for a steep learning curve. Don’t get discouraged; you’ll lose plenty of units along the way. Just remember to plan ahead, always keep anti-air and anti-tank units ready, and you’ll get the hang of it.

original: I was negatively biased towards this game before i played it. Wasn't even sure about buying. I dunno, the whole portal gun and portals thing seemed weird to me even though i like science fiction. Boy was i wrong. The jokes and voice acting in this game is phenomenal. Just amazing. It's not cheesy (ok it's sometimes cheesy). And different story characters have all their own sense of humour. Those different characters do really have different personalities. And the level design; it's just rad. Btw i never played the first portal game. One of these days, i'm planning to if i can spare the time. I would never have played it if i hadn't played the sequel.
polished: I had a negative bias toward this game before playing it—I wasn’t even sure about buying it. For some reason, the whole portal gun and portal mechanics seemed odd to me, despite being a fan of science fiction. Boy, was I wrong. The humor and voice acting in this game are phenomenal—just amazing. It’s not cheesy (well, maybe a little at times). Each story character has their own distinct sense of humor, and they truly feel like unique personalities. And the level design? Absolutely brilliant. By the way, I never played the first *Portal* game, but I plan to someday if I find the time. Honestly, I wouldn’t have touched this sequel if I hadn’t played it first.

original: Ok lets start on the pros(+) and cons(-) then my thoughts on this game. +some of the best charecters +good story +lods of content +customisible charecter ( you can be male or female whatever you like) +you can have a relationship with most of your companions(yes fangirls you can have a love intrest) -bad graphics ( i dont think graphics really matter anyway) -weird and akward love scenes -invisible walls -theirs one mission in my opinion was boring but everyone has different tastes -+ um this isnt really bad or good but for those who care your protaginist you made cant talk okay know for my thoughts. I love this game. This game is probubly one of the best rpgs or games in general i have ever played.so if your a rpg fan you proubly already have this game.
polished:
Here’s the polished version of your text:  

---  

**Pros (+)**  
- Some of the best characters  
- Engaging story  
- Lots of content  
- Customizable character (you can choose to be male or female)  
- Ability to form relationships with most companions (including romantic options)  

**Cons (-)**  
- Outdated graphics (though graphics aren’t everything)  
- Awkwardly executed love scenes  
- Invisible walls  
- One mission felt boring (though preferences vary)  

**Neutral Note**  
- Your protagonist is silent—neither good nor bad, but worth mentioning for those who care.  

**Final Thoughts**  
I absolutely love this game. It’s easily one of the best RPGs—or even games in general—that I’ve ever played. If you’re an RPG fan, you’ve probably already tried it.  

---

original: Yes, this is a nostalgia trip for thirty-somethings who remember (at least in the uk) watching the ever-irritating timmy mallet just for the five minute transformers cartoon. The voice actors for optimus, megatron, bumblebee, and many others are back, and instantly recognisable. The distinctive cartoon transformation sound is there. Graphically, the cell-shaded presentation is perfect, and very, very generation one. But aside from that, it's actually a very fun game. The combat mechanics are extremely well done. Transforming mid-fight is often a necessity, and woven seamlessly into combos, making it quite unlike high moon's excellent war for/fall of cybertron games. Another distinction is the heavy focus on melee combat, but some enemies (e.g. Seekers) require a switch to a ranged blaster.
polished:
Certainly! Here's the polished version of your text with slight major refinements while preserving the original meaning:  

---  

Yes, this is a nostalgia trip for thirty-somethings who remember—at least in the UK—enduring the ever-irritating Timmy Mallet just to catch the five-minute *Transformers* cartoon. The original voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and many others return, instantly recognizable. The iconic cartoon transformation sound is faithfully recreated. Graphically, the cel-shaded art style is flawless, capturing the essence of Generation One perfectly. Beyond nostalgia, however, it's also a genuinely enjoyable game. The combat mechanics are exceptionally well-executed, with mid-fight transformations often essential and smoothly integrated into combos—setting it apart from High Moon's excellent *War for Cybertron* and *Fall of Cybertron* games. Another standout feature is the strong emphasis on melee combat, though certain enemies (like Seekers) demand a swift switch to ranged weaponry.  

---  

Let me know if you'd like any further refinements!

original: So i downloaded the game and played it for a little while, and it was nothing special. I spent more time trying to log in though than actually playing the game. There is a bug where it says that there was an update to the terms of service or whatever and whenever you clicked 'accept' it would just pop up again. You have to restart the client for it to work. Now that isn't that bad but why do i need to link my steam and gface accounts? they say it is for dlc but why is that even necessary? it is also not reversable so now i know that a company i don't care about has access to my steam information. Now the game itself is so so. It is easily recognisable as a cod clone, except somehow they made the gunplay worse... How is that even possible?
polished:
I downloaded the game and played it briefly, but it wasn’t particularly impressive. Ironically, I spent more time trying to log in than actually playing. There’s a persistent bug where the game prompts you to accept updated terms of service, but clicking "accept" just makes the pop-up reappear—forcing you to restart the client to proceed.  

While that’s inconvenient, the bigger issue is the mandatory linking of Steam and GFace accounts. The justification is DLC access, but why is that necessary? Worse yet, the process is irreversible, meaning a company I have no interest in now has access to my Steam data.  

As for the game itself, it’s mediocre at best. It’s clearly a Call of Duty clone, yet somehow the gunplay feels even worse—which is baffling. How do you manage that?

original: 4k+ at 60fps (gtx 970), dual audio options and includes neptune gear. What's not to love? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo excellent port and a great entry point if new to the series. Just keep in mind there is lots of (skip-able) talking. As usual would suggest using a gamepad but personally i had no problems with a keymouse/mouse setup, both completely rebindable. Price is about right and wouldn't have been unhappy about a purchase. More then half the dlc is included free, which is still plenty to play with. Recommended game to all jrpg/anime/visualnovel fans, provided you don't mind long breaks between the action. Cheers. No commentary playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plslfvijaupszez9af395mvnk63xnhsj1_
polished:
4K at 60fps (GTX 970), dual audio options, and includes Neptune gear—what's not to love? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo  

This is an excellent port and a great entry point for newcomers to the series. Just be aware there’s a fair amount of (skippable) dialogue. As usual, a gamepad is recommended, but I had no issues with a keyboard/mouse setup—both are fully rebindable.  

The price is fair, and I wouldn’t regret the purchase. Over half the DLC is included for free, offering plenty of content. Highly recommended for JRPG, anime, and visual novel fans—as long as you don’t mind breaks between action sequences.  

Cheers.  

No-commentary playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plslfvijaupszez9af395mvnk63xnhsj1_

original: I experienced no performance problems even at release, and after all these patches it plays really well. Imo, this is a really great and fun game in truth, although the format may be somewhat annoying (where the free-roam city area repopulates with new enemies every time you progress the story). I particularly enjoyed the 'dual play' segments (where you can play batman + 1 more), and the ability to use the controller for most segments of the game but the mouse and keyboard for the tank combat segments was greatly appreciated. Driving your batmobile around the free-roam city, including when chasing the apc commanders, is actually quite enjoyable once you figure out how to use the breaks to skid around corners (and when you master that, driving around the city is really quite enjoyable!)
polished: I encountered no performance issues even at launch, and with all the subsequent patches, the game now runs exceptionally well. In my opinion, it’s genuinely a fantastic and enjoyable game, though the format can be slightly frustrating at times—particularly how the free-roam city repopulates with enemies after each story progression. The 'dual play' segments, where you control Batman alongside another character, were a standout highlight. I also appreciated the flexibility of using a controller for most gameplay while switching to mouse and keyboard for tank combat sections. Navigating the Batmobile through the open city—especially during APC chases—becomes incredibly satisfying once you master using the brakes to drift around corners. Once you get the hang of it, cruising through Gotham is an absolute delight!

original: Damn fine aaa fps shooter - that's the bottom line. It's looks, sounds and plays great - great fps mechanics, nice story, cool characters, flawless voice acting, and a badass soundtrack. Not for the faint hearted though - some of those cutscenes were pretty darn cruel and vivid. But when a game overall is so great, it's easier to spot the flaws, and here they are as i saw 'em: - no sli support - wtf? i had to put the game away until i upgraded my card, as it ran too poorly on my old dual gpu gtx 590. Make sure you have a fairly decent single gpu card. - stupidly small obstacles are often unclimbable.
polished:
An absolutely outstanding FPS shooter—that sums it up perfectly. It looks, sounds, and plays brilliantly, with excellent mechanics, a compelling story, memorable characters, flawless voice acting, and an incredible soundtrack. That said, it’s not for the faint of heart—some cutscenes are brutally intense and graphic.  

When a game is this good, however, its flaws become more noticeable. Here’s what stood out to me:  
- No SLI support—seriously? I had to shelve the game until I upgraded my GPU, as performance was terrible on my old dual-GPU GTX 590. A solid single-GPU card is a must.  
- Frustratingly, even tiny obstacles are often impossible to climb.

original: English is not my native language. I am dutch. So please ignore any typing/grammatical mistakes in my review of this fantastic game. I will break down this review in a few categories: - graphics - controls - sound - gameplay - replayability - graphics: the game has been set in a comic-like style. The graphics are very slick: no unnecussery details. Nice colour-scemes. It totally works for this game. The graphics can be set on 'high' without stressing your system. I run this game on an i5 pentium processor, with nvidia geforce 710m card - 8gb memory and it runs like clockwork (windows 8.1). - controls: the game can be played with keyboard and mouse, but also with an x-box controller.
polished:
English is not my native language—I am Dutch—so please excuse any typing or grammatical errors in my review of this fantastic game. I’ll break down my thoughts into a few key categories:  

- **Graphics**  
- **Controls**  
- **Sound**  
- **Gameplay**  
- **Replayability**  

**Graphics:** The game features a comic-like art style. The visuals are sleek, avoiding unnecessary clutter, and the color schemes are well-chosen. This aesthetic perfectly suits the game. Even on higher settings, the graphics don’t strain your system. I run it on an Intel i5 processor with an NVIDIA GeForce 710M card, 8GB RAM (Windows 8.1), and it performs flawlessly.  

**Controls:** The game supports both keyboard and mouse as well as an Xbox controller.

original: You can see by the hours i put into this game that i enjoy it. This is everything i wished a search game from cod would be. But dont buy this game thinking its like cod, battlefield, or any other shooter game. Its a game in its own class and should be treated as such. Cant tell you how many times i hear new players ♥♥♥♥♥ and complain about getting killed really fast. Oh god forbid you get shot in the face and ♥♥♥♥ing die. It's not like that doents happen in real life or anything. Edit:ok so ive been playing this game for awhile now. Thrown all kinds of money at it. One of the best mp games around. A good thing to play when your your not feeling cs:go.
polished:
You can tell by the hours I’ve put into this game that I truly enjoy it. This is everything I hoped a tactical shooter from Call of Duty would be. However, don’t buy this game expecting it to play like COD, Battlefield, or any other mainstream shooter. It stands in a league of its own and should be appreciated as such. I can’t count how many times I’ve heard new players complain about dying too quickly. Seriously—god forbid you get shot in the face and actually die. It’s not like that never happens in real life, right?  

Edit: Okay, so I’ve been playing this game for a while now and have invested quite a bit into it. It’s one of the best multiplayer experiences out there—perfect for when you’re not in the mood for CS:GO.

original: I'm 2 hours in and am dying from this game. So funny. Gameplay is also solid, art design is beautiful, music is surprisingly high quality and appropriate, the story/world has me interested, and the puzzles are fun. But the best thing about this game beyond all that is the comedy. If you've played any rpg since the dawn of video game rpgs you will laugh at the various jokes, parodies, and references; if you've never played an rpg before then you should still enjoy the game for its humor. If you played final fantasy 7 or x you absolutely need to play this game, without giving too much away... I had to actually stop playing after 2 hours to give my cheeks a break from laughing and smiling so much. What a delight so far.
polished: I'm two hours in and this game is killing me—in the best way possible. It's hilarious. The gameplay is solid, the art design is stunning, and the music is unexpectedly high-quality and perfectly fitting. The story and world have me hooked, and the puzzles are genuinely enjoyable. But what truly sets this game apart is its comedy. Whether you're a seasoned RPG player who'll appreciate the jokes, parodies, and references spanning the genre's history, or a newcomer who just enjoys great humor, this game delivers. If you've ever played *Final Fantasy VII* or *X*, this is a must-play—trust me, I had to pause after two hours just to let my cheeks recover from laughing and smiling so much. What an absolute delight so far.

original: I'm really sorry, i try to be supportive of free-to-play games and indie developers, but i really didn't enjoy this game. The description sounded right up my alley, but the execution has done nothing for me. I love puzzle and exploration games, but i found this game to be completely unintuitive, and even after looking up how to progress i still just simply didn't find the gameplay itself fun. It also completely lacks a pause button, or if it does have one i never found it. Considering that a lot of sequences in the game are timed, this seems like a critical oversight. I also feel like this game is a lot more cut scene than it is game, and i end up just sitting around drumming my fingers a lot.
polished: I genuinely appreciate free-to-play games and indie developers, but unfortunately, this one didn’t resonate with me. While the concept seemed perfect for my tastes, the execution fell flat. As someone who enjoys puzzle and exploration games, I found this title unintuitive—even after consulting guides, the gameplay simply wasn’t engaging. The absence of a pause button (or its obscurity) feels like a significant flaw, especially given the timed sequences. Additionally, the experience leans heavily into cutscenes, leaving me waiting more than playing.

original: This game.... Phew where to even start. It was absolutely beautiful, from story to graphics i was hooked. The story wasnt just some story but actually felt like i was that person, trying to figure out what came next in the story that my character was telling. Gameplay was great and i learned alot about myself through this game (mainly my fear of hights which i never had a problem with until the ice caverns). My gut churned the whole time, but i kept through for uncle fred! if you guys made a dlc or second game, i would be the first to buy it and recomend it to everyone i know. Thanks to everyone who was involved making this, you made a absolutely beautiful game.
polished: This game... wow, where do I even begin? It was absolutely stunning, from the story to the graphics—I was completely hooked. The narrative wasn’t just a story; it felt like I *was* the protagonist, unraveling each twist as my character lived it. The gameplay was fantastic, and I even discovered things about myself along the way (like my previously unknown fear of heights, thanks to the ice caverns). My stomach was in knots the entire time, but I pushed through—for Uncle Fred! If you ever release a DLC or sequel, I’d be the first in line to buy it and recommend it to everyone I know. To everyone involved in creating this masterpiece: thank you. You crafted something truly beautiful.

original: Sid meier's civilization beyond earth is a turn-based game in which you build your civilization to a certain goal or 'victory'. In previous games you were set on the earth's timeline going through periods like the stone age, medieval age, and the modern age; however, in this game you are set in the future on a mission to colonize a new planet. What i enjoy about this game is 2k took a new approach to the game and added some new mechanics such as the affinity system and orbital layer. What i didn't enjoy was that with these new mechanics the game could be overwhelming at times. What think could be improved on this game is that they could maybe incorperate some new artwork in the game such as the enviroment you experience when communicating with another leader.
polished:
*Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth* is a turn-based strategy game where you develop your civilization toward a specific goal or "victory." Unlike previous entries in the series, which followed Earth's historical timeline—spanning eras like the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and Modern Age—this installment takes place in the future, tasking players with colonizing a new planet.  

What I appreciate about this game is how 2K introduced fresh mechanics, such as the affinity system and orbital layer, offering a unique twist on the classic formula. However, these additions can occasionally feel overwhelming.  

One area I believe could be improved is the artwork—particularly the environments seen during leader interactions, which could benefit from more visual variety and polish.

original: Great game ! tons of replayability and very fun zombie survival game ! def. In my top 5 zombie games ever played. Edit: after playing 60+ hours i can honestly say this is one of the better more ''realistic'' zombie games. It's very much designed like a survival horror as you must save up your ammo, heal your own wounds when you bleed out, take pills when youre infected, etc. Also, i find zombies to feel very natual to be well animated for a free to play game. P.s. : i would recomend getting 1 or 2 friends to play with, but the community is super friendly and you can usually make friends/talk with the people in the chat or over voice comms.
polished:
Great game! It offers tons of replayability and delivers a very fun zombie survival experience. Definitely ranks in my top five zombie games of all time.  

**Edit:** After playing for 60+ hours, I can confidently say this is one of the better, more 'realistic' zombie games out there. It’s designed like a survival horror—you need to conserve ammo, treat your wounds when bleeding, take pills for infections, and more.  

The zombies feel surprisingly natural and are well-animated for a free-to-play title.  

*P.S.:* I’d recommend playing with one or two friends, but the community is incredibly friendly. You can easily make new friends or chat with others via text or voice comms.

original: 02/07/2014 - it's a shame i can't thoroughly recommend/enjoy this game as from the short time i've played it,i know i'd be addicted if it didn't have the following 2 game breakers. . No aussie servers - one red bar puts you at a severe disadvantage,and creates unbearable lag. Mind you,i played through the offline training mode and it was stuttering/lagging as well (how does that even happen?). Couple that with the poor ping,and it just ruins the game. . Everything artifacts like crazy - the menu's,backgrounds,training and in-game. I've never had this happen before with this card and thought it might not like my oc. Set my gpu back to stock and sure enough,it didn't make a difference.
polished:
**Polished Version:**  

*February 7, 2014* – It’s a shame I can’t fully recommend or enjoy this game because, from the short time I’ve played, I know I’d be hooked if not for two major issues:  

1. **No Australian servers** – A single red bar puts you at a severe disadvantage, causing unbearable lag. Even the offline training mode stuttered and lagged (how does that even happen?). Combined with the poor ping, it completely ruins the experience.  

2. **Excessive artifacting** – The menus, backgrounds, training, and in-game visuals are plagued by artifacts. I’ve never encountered this issue before with my GPU and initially suspected my overclock. However, resetting to stock settings made no difference.

original: Very late last night i finished this. The story is not very deep or interesting but what makes it stand out is the story-telling. The atmosphere is filled to the brim and the many collectibles do a great job at fleshing it out. I did learn a lot about the world of batman so it was a little disappointing that so few bosses were in the game. Oh well, there's enough future games to rectify that. The combat is the right amount of challenge but it's more on the easy side. Leveling up batman wasn't very satisfying. It's the gadgets you upgrade and acquire during the campaign which add for nice new gameplay mechanics. Getting access to previously unreachable places makes for a nice sense of progression.
polished: Very late last night, I finally finished this. While the story itself isn’t particularly deep or compelling, its storytelling truly sets it apart. The atmosphere is richly immersive, and the numerous collectibles do an excellent job of expanding the world. I learned a great deal about Batman’s universe, though it was a bit disappointing how few boss fights the game included. Still, future installments can easily address that. The combat strikes a good balance in difficulty, leaning slightly toward the easier side. Leveling up Batman didn’t feel especially rewarding, but upgrading and unlocking gadgets throughout the campaign introduced enjoyable new mechanics. Gaining access to previously inaccessible areas provided a satisfying sense of progression.

original: 'to the moon' is no mere game... Nay, it is a veritable experience, and it was one of the best of my life at that. Think telltale's the walking dead is sad? hohoho! well, it's no match for to the moon! never before have i been so depressed yet fulfilled over something purely fictional. This masterpiece represents the pinnacle of storytelling in my opinion, and the soundtrack is a gorgeously charming and perfect accompaniment. Yes, the controls are a bit finicky and the gameplay is not the strong point, but the story is so fantastic that i did not care one bit. Plus, the humor of the game is great as well and it definitely does not intrude upon the distinguished nature of the story... And the doctor who references are endless.
polished:
To the Moon" is no ordinary game—far from it. It is a profound experience, and one of the finest I’ve ever had. You think Telltale’s *The Walking Dead* is sad? Well, it doesn’t even come close to *To the Moon*! Never before has something purely fictional left me so deeply moved yet strangely fulfilled. This masterpiece stands, in my opinion, as the pinnacle of storytelling, complemented by a soundtrack that is utterly charming and flawless.  

Admittedly, the controls can feel a bit clunky, and gameplay isn’t its strongest suit—but the story is so extraordinary that none of that mattered to me in the slightest. The humor, too, is brilliantly woven in, never detracting from the story’s emotional weight. And, of course, the endless *Doctor Who* references are just the icing on the cake.

original: Bastion is a bloody brilliant game, with a really great storyline. Set after some calamity happened, you start to rebuild on the bastion. There's quite a lot of choice in the game, with the choice of what to build to give you an advantage, what weapons to use and what power ups to have on those weapons as well as what drinks to use to give you a bonus effect. The art style and music in the game is fantastic, everything looks so colourful at times, who says the apocolypse has to be dull. Best of all, the game has narration based on what you, the player do. So if you end up picking up a weapon then switch it for another in the armoury, the narration would say something of you taking along the new weapon.
polished: Bastion is an outstanding game, featuring a truly captivating storyline. Set in the aftermath of a catastrophic event, your journey revolves around rebuilding the world from the bastion. The game offers a wealth of choices, from deciding which structures to construct for strategic benefits, to selecting weapons, customizing them with power-ups, and choosing drinks that grant bonus effects. The art style and soundtrack are exceptional, with vibrant visuals that prove the apocalypse doesn’t have to be bleak. One of its finest features is the dynamic narration, which reacts to your actions—whether you pick up a weapon or swap it in the armory, the narrator seamlessly comments on your decisions, adding depth to the experience.

original: I had originally bought this game in early development, when the only currency was spacebux, and there was no 'tech tree'. This was when the game was good. All of the guns at this point were equally overpowered, so there was no problems with imbalance; everyone could kill everyone at any time. Also, the game used to give you unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. You would think that for a game with 'bajillions of guns', they would at least give you more than 6 weapon slots and 3 loadouts before you have to pay to get more. At one point, i had about 3 pages worth of guns, and was planning on new ideas for more, because personally, that's where i found it fun.
polished:
I originally purchased this game during its early development phase, back when the only currency was SpaceBux and there was no 'tech tree' to speak of. That was when the game was at its best. At that time, all the guns were equally overpowered, so balance wasn't an issue—everyone could take down anyone at any moment.  

The game also used to grant unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. You'd think that for a title boasting 'bajillions of guns,' they'd offer more than six weapon slots and three loadouts before locking the rest behind a paywall. At one point, I had around three pages' worth of guns and was brainstorming new ideas for even more because, for me, that was where the real fun lay.

original: This game was a surprising gem. One often sees rave reviews of certain products that are often misleading. In this case, the reviews reflect the fun of this neat little game. It is an odd mix between a classic 2d platformer and an moba, and does it with style. I found myself enjoying characters that i wouldn't enjoy in other moba games. I had expected this trait to continue, but decided to give a melee tank a go anyway. I was pleasantly surprised with the outcome and ended up trying out more as they were unlocked from playing games. The art style and interface is oddly charming. As such, i now use one of the characters as my avatar and a wallpaper from creating a card set for the game.
polished: This game turned out to be a delightful surprise. While glowing reviews for products can often be misleading, in this case, they truly captured the enjoyment of this clever little game. It blends a classic 2D platformer with MOBA elements in a stylish and unique way. I unexpectedly found myself drawn to characters I wouldn’t typically enjoy in other MOBAs. Though I initially hesitated, I decided to try a melee tank—and was pleasantly surprised by how much fun it was, leading me to experiment with more characters as they unlocked through gameplay. The art style and interface have a quirky charm, so much so that I’ve adopted one of the characters as my avatar and even use a wallpaper from the game’s card set creator.

original: I just started playing, but i love this game. I put on my headphone and lose myself in the game for hours at a time. It's been awhile since a game has had that effect on me. The music sets the mood, the sound effects are right on, and the controls are perfect. I look forward to every combat, and they've optimized combat extremely well. I had my doubt about the navel combat system, but it is so much fun to lay waste to multiple fleets at a time! the only way to lose in this game is to fail to retreat. If the combat looks overwhelming just get outta there, regroup, and counter-assault. Thanks, devs, for an awesome experience!
polished: I just started playing, but I already love this game. I put on my headphones and lose myself in it for hours at a time. It's been a while since a game has captivated me like this. The music sets the perfect mood, the sound effects are spot-on, and the controls are flawless. I eagerly anticipate every combat encounter—they've optimized the battles exceptionally well. I initially had doubts about the naval combat system, but it's incredibly satisfying to decimate multiple fleets at once! The only way to lose is by failing to retreat. If the fight seems overwhelming, just withdraw, regroup, and strike back. Thank you, devs, for this incredible experience!

original: The reboot of the devil may cry franchise has brought about many changes for the series, particularly for series’ protagonist, dante. While fans of the original series may be upset at the change to their beloved character, it’s certainly for the better; and this new game by ninja theory proves it. Dmc serves as the perfect point for newcomers to jump into the series. It shows the origins of an arrogant, cynical dante, and it chronicles his journey from cynicism to selflessness. Throughout, the game weaves a clear, narrative arc for the new dante, making him a compelling character to watch.image the story follows dante as he’s introduced into the corrupt world he willfully chose to ignore.
polished: The reboot of the *Devil May Cry* franchise has introduced significant changes to the series, especially for its protagonist, Dante. While longtime fans may initially resist these alterations to their beloved character, the improvements are undeniable—and Ninja Theory’s new game demonstrates this masterfully. *DmC* offers the ideal entry point for newcomers, tracing the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante and documenting his transformation from self-interest to selflessness. The game crafts a clear, engaging narrative arc for this reimagined Dante, making him a captivating figure to follow. The story unfolds as Dante is thrust into the corrupt world he once deliberately turned away from.

original: Where do i start on this absolutely beautiful game. It's story, is absolutely charming. It has so much detail put into it, and it is a bundle of happiness, bad puns, annoying dogs, secrets. It is serious when it needs to be, but isn't a stranger to funny moments. The character design is on point, with there being various characters with various personailities and secrets to them. It sticks out from other rpg's because you don't have to kill anyone, which is an unused concept in rpg's. With lots of inspiration from earthbound, one of the best rpg's i have seen, you can tell that it is going to be good. It easily has the best soundtrack i've heard in forever.
polished: Where do I even begin with this absolutely beautiful game? Its story is utterly charming, packed with meticulous detail, and brimming with joy—bad puns, pesky dogs, and hidden secrets included. It knows when to be serious but never shies away from humor. The character design is impeccable, featuring a diverse cast with unique personalities and intriguing backstories. What sets it apart from other RPGs is its rare approach: you don’t have to kill anyone, a refreshing twist in the genre. Drawing heavy inspiration from *EarthBound*, one of the finest RPGs I’ve ever played, its quality is undeniable. And the soundtrack? Easily the best I’ve heard in years.

original: I am recommending this solely because it's free, and might be a more 'enjoyable' experience for others. As for my experience, the 'game' did nothing for me. Half the story relies on shock factor. I was not shocked nor emotionally moved in any way by this. Maybe i'm desensitized, or maybe it was too simple to warrant a reaction out of me. As for the other half of the game, it tries to paint a picture (literally) of a person in mental decline. It deals with obsession, hallucination, depression and a few other things. In theory it is a cool idea. But the 'game' took me 10 minutes to complete, and that is with reading and taking in every little bit of information i could.
polished: I recommend this solely because it's free and might offer a more 'enjoyable' experience for some. Personally, the 'game' did nothing for me. Half of the narrative relies on shock value, but I felt neither shocked nor emotionally affected—perhaps I’m desensitized, or maybe it was too simplistic to evoke a reaction. The other half attempts to depict mental decline, exploring themes like obsession, hallucination, and depression. In concept, it’s an interesting idea. However, the 'game' took me just 10 minutes to finish, even while carefully reading and absorbing every detail.

original: Do i even need to explain why portal is amazing? portal is a puzzle game, it gives you a concept then gets out. It is an amazing way to test your mind while still being fun. Although this game isn't as story heavy, it did give birth to one of the most good popular games of 2011. I still play this game and beat it when i am feeling bored and i love to come back and to see what gave birth to a legend and what is a legend. Gameplay: portal's gameplay is quite simple, to explain at least. You use portals to your advantage, along with buttons that activate a part of the puzzle. Two buttons are in the game, one that you press and one that you need a cube to put on.
polished:
Do I even need to explain why *Portal* is amazing? It's a puzzle game that introduces a concept and then lets you run with it. This brilliant approach challenges your mind while keeping the experience enjoyable. Though not heavily story-driven, it spawned one of the most beloved and popular games of 2011. I still revisit this game when I'm bored, completing it time and again—returning to witness the origins of a legend and the legend itself.  

**Gameplay**: *Portal*'s mechanics are deceptively simple to describe. You manipulate portals to solve puzzles, aided by buttons that trigger parts of the environment. There are two types: one you press directly and another that requires placing a weighted cube on it.

original: If you can overlook the bugs (which i personally only had two: one minor and the other quite annoying) edit: both bugs are resolved one fix increased my fps from 60-90 to 80-120 and are looking for a space exploration game, i can definitely recommend this. Since most of these reviews are about specs, i'll include mine: i5 6600k (~200€) radeon rx480 (~200€) z170 pro - gaming (~150€) 16gb ddr4 ram (~70€) ~650€ is definitely within the medium price range though, granted, this rig is quite new. Almost constant 60+ fps on high settings vsync enabled i genuinely can't believe 90% of the comments saying they're rocking an overkill setup and get 20fps.
polished:
If you can overlook the bugs (I personally encountered only two—one minor and the other quite annoying—*edit: both have since been resolved, with one fix boosting my FPS from 60-90 to 80-120*) and are looking for a space exploration game, I can wholeheartedly recommend this. Since most reviews focus on specs, here are mine:  

- **CPU:** i5 6600k (~€200)  
- **GPU:** Radeon RX 480 (~€200)  
- **Motherboard:** Z170 Pro-Gaming (~€150)  
- **RAM:** 16GB DDR4 (~€70)  

Totaling around €650, this setup falls squarely in the mid-range price bracket—though admittedly, it’s fairly new. I maintain a near-constant 60+ FPS on high settings with V-Sync enabled. Frankly, I’m baffled by the 90% of comments claiming their overkill rigs struggle to hit 20 FPS.

original: Remember age of mythology? yeah, it's been that long since there's been an rts game of such quality. Divinity: dragon commander reaches awfully close to these borders of my personal most favourite rts game. Combine this with a huge risk-like grand strategy mode and there, it hit the spot. I am not (read: try not to be) overly biased due to the fact that this game allows you to turn into a dragon, aiding your troops by supporting, attacking and even commanding unit production, direction and spawning at the very same time. Honestly, i do like the complicated rts games nowadays. Think of civ v and so on. However, such games attempt to cram complex mechanics, charts and resources all into one complicated game mode.
polished:
Remember Age of Mythology? Yeah, it’s been that long since we’ve seen an RTS game of such high quality. Divinity: Dragon Commander comes awfully close to being one of my personal favorites in the genre. Combine that with a grand strategy mode reminiscent of Risk, and it truly hits the mark. I’ll admit—I try not to be overly biased—but the fact that this game lets you transform into a dragon, supporting your troops, attacking enemies, and even managing unit production and deployment simultaneously is hard to ignore.  

These days, I do appreciate complex RTS games like Civ V and others. However, many of them tend to cram intricate mechanics, charts, and resource systems into a single overwhelming experience.

original: Undertale comes together to make something greater than the sum of its parts. The graphics are solid for a retro title and the music is nice, but paired together they make some truly beautiful and impacting moments. The script runs the gammut from comedic to dramatic to heartbreaking to hopeful, sometimes all at once, and does this while turning rpg tropes on their head. And all of this without touching on the world, characters, story, gameplay... I could write whole pages about it. But instead, i'll just say this: if you like rpgs, play this game. If you like video games, play this game. If you have seven free hours between now and your death, play this game.
polished: *Undertale* blends its elements into something far greater than their individual parts. The graphics hold up well for a retro-style game, and the soundtrack is pleasant, but when combined, they create moments of genuine beauty and emotional impact. The writing spans a wide range—from comedy to drama, heartbreak to hope, often simultaneously—all while subverting classic RPG tropes. And that’s without even delving into the world, characters, story, or gameplay... I could go on for pages. But instead, I’ll keep it simple: if you enjoy RPGs, play this game. If you love video games, play this game. If you have even a few spare hours in your lifetime, play this game.

original: If you liked witcher 1 and 2, witcher 3 is must to get. I would give normally for this game 10/10 but unfortunatly after 1.03 this game turned into buggy ♥♥♥♥ + random crashes, so remember to save really often. When i played version 1.00 -> 1.03 my game never crashed, i didnt see any bugs. Also i have noticed that after 1.03 patch drawing distance sometimes is horrible, starting to draw objects when youre really close, sometimes even people. But if forgetting all these bugs, crashes and drawdistance 'bugs', this is really fantastic game, they made huge effort on quests, some of them really emotional and deep, lots of side quests, and the fact that your decision effects a lot in this game. I have played over 50 hours now and still going on.
polished:
If you enjoyed *The Witcher 1* and *2*, then *The Witcher 3* is an absolute must-play. Normally, I would rate this game a perfect 10/10, but unfortunately, after patch 1.03, it became plagued with bugs and random crashes—so remember to save frequently. When I played versions 1.00 to 1.03, my game never crashed, and I encountered no bugs. I also noticed that post-1.03, the draw distance sometimes suffers, with objects—and even NPCs—only rendering when you're uncomfortably close.  

However, setting aside these technical issues, *The Witcher 3* remains a fantastic game. The developers put tremendous effort into crafting rich, emotional quests—some of which are deeply impactful—alongside a wealth of meaningful side content. Your choices truly shape the world, adding immense replay value. I’ve already sunk over 50 hours into it and still can’t put it down.

original: I have only had this game for a few months, but in just that short amount of time, two dlc's have come out, along with patches that have made an already great game into an excellent one. The devs are very active in the community, and it really shows in the various discussion forums and dev diaries. There is a fairly steep learning curve to the game's mechanics of which i am still trying to learn; however, this breadth of strategy allows you a myriad of ways to reach goals and take advantage of certain situations. The game, in my mind, is almost infinitely replayable. I find myself sucked into every session i play regardless of how the play-through is going.
polished: I've only owned this game for a few months, yet in that brief period, two DLCs have already been released alongside patches that transformed an already outstanding game into something truly exceptional. The developers are highly engaged with the community, evident through their active presence in discussion forums and detailed dev diaries. While the game's mechanics present a reasonably steep learning curve—one I'm still mastering—this depth of strategy offers countless approaches to achieving objectives and capitalizing on opportunities. In my opinion, the game boasts near-endless replayability. Every session draws me in completely, regardless of how my current playthrough unfolds.

original: Warframe is a fun game for the first few hours of play. After those few enjoyable hours you'll begin to see that the only thing left the game has to offer is repetition in it's combat, enemies and game play. The one major high point for the game is that the developers are working hard and do semi-frequent updates that generally include a lot of content from sweeping changes to some of the game's systems, new warframes and other tweaks/features. It's a good game to play casually. Though i doubt it will hold your attention beyond a few months unless you just really like grinding. The upside to all of this is that the game is free so i'd recommend trying it out. If you're looking for a quick fix, try it out.
polished: Warframe is an enjoyable game for the initial few hours of gameplay. However, after that brief period of fun, you'll quickly notice that the game largely revolves around repetitive combat, enemies, and mechanics. The standout positive aspect is the developers' dedication—they release semi-frequent updates that often introduce substantial content, ranging from major system overhauls to new Warframes and various tweaks or features. It's a solid choice for casual play, though it's unlikely to hold your interest for more than a few months unless you genuinely enjoy grinding. The best part? It's free, so I’d still recommend giving it a try. If you're after a quick gaming fix, go ahead and dive in.

original: This game is so.. Very.. Boring. I bought this game because i believed it was a pc version of 'katamari damacy', a popular and nice ps 2 game. Sadly it's far from it. In this game you go about, absorbing ever bigger things to grow bigger and absorb bigger things. But the gameplay isn't as smooth as it could be, the levels not inventive and what is in it is a surreal horror show. I don't mean an entertaining horror show but, one that makes you rather depressed and rethink whether being alive is all it should be. Every 'living' creature in this game from small pets to human beings makes me wonder if the creators of this game had an interest in taxidermy.
polished: This game is... incredibly dull. I purchased it thinking it would be a PC version of *Katamari Damacy*, a beloved and charming PS2 title. Unfortunately, it falls far short. The core mechanic involves growing larger by absorbing progressively bigger objects, but the gameplay feels clunky, the levels lack creativity, and the overall tone is a surreal horror experience—not the entertaining kind, but one that leaves you feeling bleak and questioning existence. Every "living" creature in this game, from tiny pets to humans, makes me suspect the developers had an unsettling fascination with taxidermy.

original: Alright. Let me explain a few things, as a person very intrested in politics, i was very interested in this game when i first heard about it. I thought, 'oh wow! a simulator of the road to becoming president! that sounds fun!' well, it really wasn't. The game starts you off and says you need to pick a side: republican or democrat, there is no independent, or third party. A little dissapointed, but still optimistic, i carried on to see what i could do. I will give the game credit, the character customization, although limited, is pretty fun to mess around with. It's the only time its an option to wear your head or not in a campaign. Literally.
polished:
Alright, let me explain a few things. As someone deeply interested in politics, I was genuinely excited when I first heard about this game. I thought, *Wow! A simulator about the journey to becoming president? That sounds amazing!* Well, it really wasn’t.  

The game starts by forcing you to pick a side—Republican or Democrat—with no option for an independent or third-party candidate. That was a bit disappointing, but I stayed optimistic to see what else it had to offer.  

I will give the game some credit: the character customization, though limited, is pretty fun to experiment with. It’s the only time you get the choice to wear your head—or not—during a campaign. Literally.

original: Fallout 3 story was better. Settlements get in the way of the story to the point you'll hate baby sitting them instead of playing the story. Some keys are hard coded and cannot be rebound. Bugs galore. My pipboy disappeared permanently at one point and had to research console commands to get it back. You don't have to work for power armor it's basically given to you from the beginning of the game and power cores are everywhere in trader shops. Value of power armor diminished greatly from previous fallout games. Story is medicore, everything about this game is mediocre except it doesn't crash every 10 mins like fallout 3. Very stable compared to fallout 3. Is it better than fallout 3 no. Is it better than new vegas? no. This title was so overhyped for how bad it actually is.
polished: Fallout 3 had a superior story. The settlement system disrupts the narrative so much that managing them feels like tedious babysitting rather than enjoying the main plot. Certain keys are hardcoded and can't be remapped. The game is riddled with bugs—at one point, my Pip-Boy vanished permanently, forcing me to dig through console commands to restore it. Power armor lacks the prestige of earlier games; it's handed to you almost immediately, and fusion cores are overly abundant in shops. The story is mediocre, and while the game is more stable than Fallout 3 (which crashed constantly), it still falls short. It doesn't surpass Fallout 3 or New Vegas. Despite the hype, this installment disappoints in nearly every aspect.

original: My stats (at the time of writing this review): - 8.6 hrs to get to the end - 10 collectibles found out of 25 - zero achievements out of 15 what i liked: - visuals up until the last level (ice caves) - story is not that great, but the ending (after the closing credits) kind of made me not regret so much spending my time playing this game what i disliked: - visuals in the last level are uninteresting - gameplay in the last level gets much harder making it become a frustrating experience of having to do a lot of things over and over again until you get it right - achievements are too hard. There are 13 (out of 15) that only less than 2,1% of players achieved!
polished:
**My stats (as of writing this review):**  
- **8.6 hours** to reach the end  
- **10/25 collectibles** found  
- **0/15 achievements** unlocked  

**What I liked:**  
- The **visuals** were impressive until the final level (ice caves).  
- While the **story** wasn’t outstanding, the post-credits ending somewhat redeemed the time I spent playing.  

**What I disliked:**  
- The **last level’s visuals** were underwhelming.  
- The **gameplay** there became excessively difficult, turning into a frustrating cycle of repetition.  
- The **achievements** are overly challenging—**13 out of 15** have been earned by fewer than **2.1% of players**.

original: Pros: +graphic cons: -bugs(especially the environment, you may get stuck or your shots may hit a invisible wall despite having clear line of sight of the enemy) -game is handholding/ babysitting you -dumb ai -enemies always seem to know where you are when you are spotted -godlike accuracy by the enemy which is frustrating like the first ghost warrior. -terrible checkpoints and saves. -boring story that i couldn't care less about will not recommend it unless its 90% off even then i find playing this game to be an extremely boring chore, just playing for the sake of finishing it to move unto the next game in my library. Considering the time i wasted on the first ghost warrior (which was equally boring and i feel liberated when i finished it), i probably won't play it until the end.
polished:
**Pros:**  
+ Impressive graphics  

**Cons:**  
- Numerous bugs, particularly in the environment (e.g., getting stuck or shots hitting invisible walls despite clear line of sight)  
- Excessive handholding, making the gameplay feel like babysitting  
- Poor AI behavior  
- Enemies instantly track your location once spotted  
- Frustratingly high enemy accuracy, reminiscent of the first Ghost Warrior  
- Awful checkpoint and save system  
- Unengaging story that fails to hold interest  
- Not worth recommending unless heavily discounted (90% off), and even then, it feels like a tedious chore  
- Playing merely to finish and move on to the next game in the library  
- Given the wasted time on the equally dull first Ghost Warrior (which felt like a relief to complete), this one likely won’t be played to the end either.

original: Review for 29/11/2015 do not buy this game, servers offline. You can't play. No compres este juego, servidores offline. No puedes jugar. While i could play it, i enjoyed it. polished:
**Polished Version:**  

*Review for November 29, 2015*  

Do not buy this game—servers are offline, so you can't play. *No compres este juego, servidores offline. No puedes jugar.*  

When I *could* play, I enjoyed it. As the Steve Miller Band song goes: *"Go on, take the money and run—uh huh, uh huh!"* (*[Listen here](https://youtu.be/-wcfugcollu?t=54)*)
