original: Who wouldn't want to wear a fez? :d this puzzle platforming game stars a little guy with a fez who goes around collecting little bits to form a cube and navigating through a fairly large branching map. This game is quite amusing and running through it to complete the game was quite a bit of fun. ^_^ it can become semi-frustrating if you want to get all the cubes and achievements though. To get all the cubes you'll need to crack codes that you'll have to decipher. These can take a few seconds or frustrate you into looking into a guide (*raises hand* i gave up. -_-). The guide, 'a complete guide to fez!!!'
polished: Who wouldn’t love wearing a fez? :D This charming puzzle-platformer features a small character in a fez, exploring a vast, branching map while collecting fragments to assemble a cube. The game is delightfully entertaining, and progressing through it is genuinely enjoyable. ^_^ However, it can get a bit frustrating if you aim to collect every cube and unlock all achievements. To find them all, you’ll need to decode various puzzles—some may take mere seconds, while others might push you to consult a guide (*raises hand*—I admit, I gave up. -_-). Speaking of which, "A Complete Guide to FEZ!!!" can be a lifesaver.

original: It's not hard for me to see why other people like this game, but it wasn't for me. For one thing i have a vive and i'm much more interested in playing room sized games with the controllers. Beyond that, the game is initially awe inspiring in the scale of its universe, but i also felt that same scale was a hinderence to my enjoyment. The learning curve and the amount of time to do anything interesting at the beginning were both too large for me. Perhaps if i were more patient and had more time for gaming this would be compelling to me. But i don't have either and there are plenty more vr games i'd rather spend my time on.
polished: I can easily understand why others enjoy this game, but it just wasn’t for me. For one, I own a Vive and prefer playing room-scale games with motion controllers. Beyond that, while the game’s vast universe is initially awe-inspiring, I found its sheer scale to be more of a hindrance than a benefit. The steep learning curve and the time required to reach anything engaging early on were simply too much for me. Maybe if I were more patient and had more time for gaming, I’d find it compelling—but I lack both, and there are plenty of other VR titles I’d rather invest my time in.

original: Hands down my favorite first person shooter of all time. Run and gun rambos need not apply. Recoil and ballistics are realistic. Single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle caliber weapons almost always result in death unless it just grazes you. Rounds drop over distance and short, controlled bursts are required if you wish to remain on target. There is no magical ammunition pool. If you reload half-way through your magazine all the time then you will have a pouch full of half full mags. You can't run forever. If you sprint for a while your aim will suffer as you gasp heavily until you have caught your breath. Rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window sill to steady your aim. Accuracy suffers when standing.
polished: Without a doubt, this is my all-time favorite first-person shooter. It’s not for run-and-gun Rambo types. The recoil and ballistics are incredibly realistic—rifle-caliber shots to the chest, neck, or head are almost always fatal unless they barely graze you. Bullets drop over distance, and short, controlled bursts are essential for staying on target. There’s no unlimited ammo here; if you constantly reload mid-magazine, you’ll end up with a pouch full of half-empty clips. Stamina matters too—sprint too long, and your aim wavers as you struggle to catch your breath. For steadier shots, rest your weapon on your elbows when prone or on a window ledge. Standing shots? Expect less accuracy.

original: Let me start off by saying i did not purchase eu when it first came out and that i got it on sale which included ew so i never experienced the issues that some people claim to have had with that game. I loved that game however, it was unforgiving in the early stages but rewarding when you did things right. As for xcom2 i love it, the game plays pretty well for me on medium and i am running a gtx560 with 2gb of vram. At first the game set it to high and it was running a bit sluggishly but not to the point of being unplayable but when i dropped it down to medium it smoothed on out. Not sure if i am just lucky when it comes to having issues with games or what but it seems that most of the negative reviews sound like they are coming from some really entitled people.
polished:
Let me begin by saying I didn’t purchase *XCOM: Enemy Unknown* when it first released—I bought it later on sale, which included *Enemy Within*, so I never encountered the issues some players reported. That said, I thoroughly enjoyed the game. It was challenging early on but incredibly rewarding when executed well.  

As for *XCOM 2*, I’m loving it. The game runs smoothly for me on medium settings, even with a GTX 560 (2GB VRAM). Initially, it defaulted to high settings and had some minor sluggishness, though still playable. Switching to medium improved performance noticeably.  

I’m not sure if I’ve just been fortunate with game performance, but many negative reviews come across as overly entitled to me.

original: +rpg levelling +wide-variety of ship types +physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missles +easy-to-learn resource management +dark humored -grind intensive (if under utilizing the civvy station types) -sub-par ai teammates -low variety of equipment types -low variety of levelling skills (that is, no branching) listen, this game is fun as hell. Despite my minuses up there, there is still some variety and strategy to be had. It starts off fast and still really picks up. Even though there's a low variety of equipment, it still feels like there's always another ship to unlock or skill to level up. The best way to increase the life of this game is the mods. Fight for universe is easily the star, but big fight for beef is also very good.
polished:
+ RPG leveling  
+ Wide variety of ship types  
+ Physics-based movement for ships and projectiles/missiles  
+ Easy-to-learn resource management  
+ Dark humor  
- Grind-heavy (if not utilizing civilian stations effectively)  
- Subpar AI teammates  
- Limited equipment variety  
- Linear skill progression (no branching paths)  

Listen, this game is an absolute blast. Despite the drawbacks I mentioned, there's still plenty of variety and strategic depth. It kicks off fast and only gets more intense. Even with the limited equipment options, there’s always a new ship to unlock or skill to upgrade. To really extend the game’s lifespan, mods are the way to go—*Fight for Universe* is the standout, but *Big Fight for Beef* is also excellent.

original: World leaders gather to face uncertainty more than 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe are arriving in the swiss mountain resort davos for the annual world economic forum (wef). For five days, they will discuss issues ranging from china's economic power to iraq's future after this sunday's elections. Uk prime minister tony blair and south african president thabo mbeki are among the more than 20 government leaders and heads of state leaders attending the meeting. Unlike previous years, protests against the wef are expected to be muted. Anti-globalisation campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. The brazilian city of porto alegre will host the rival world social forum, timed to run in parallel with the wef's ritzier event in davos.
polished:
World leaders convene to address global uncertainty as over 2,000 business and political figures from across the world arrive in the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). Over five days, they will deliberate on pressing issues spanning China's economic influence to Iraq's post-election future following this Sunday's polls. Among the attendees are UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki, joining more than 20 other heads of state and government leaders.  

Unlike in past years, protests against the WEF are anticipated to be subdued, with anti-globalization activists canceling a planned weekend demonstration. Meanwhile, the Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the alternative World Social Forum, deliberately scheduled to coincide with the WEF's more exclusive gathering in Davos.

original: Deadline nears for fiat-gm deal fiat and general motors (gm) have until midnight on 1 february to settle a disagreement over a potential takeover. The deadline marks the point at which fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to gm, part of an alliance agreed in 2000. Gm, whose own european operations are losing money, no longer wants to own the unprofitable fiat unit. Reports of deadlocked talks sent fiat shares down 1.2% on tuesday, after monday's 4% gain on hopes of a payoff. The us firm is thought to be offering about $2bn (£1.06bn) to extricate itself from the arrangement. It has argued the deal was voided by fiat's decision to sell off fiat's finance arm and halve gm's stake via a capital-raising effort. The 2000 deal resulted from a race between gm and daimlerchrysler to ally with fiat.
polished: The deadline for the Fiat-GM deal is approaching, with Fiat and General Motors (GM) having until midnight on 1 February to resolve their dispute over a potential takeover. This deadline signifies the point at which Fiat gains the right to sell its automotive division to GM, as stipulated in their 2000 alliance agreement. GM, facing financial losses in its European operations, no longer wishes to retain the unprofitable Fiat unit. Reports of stalled negotiations caused Fiat shares to drop 1.2% on Tuesday, following a 4% rise on Monday fueled by hopes of a settlement. The US automaker is reportedly offering around $2 billion (£1.06 billion) to exit the arrangement. GM contends that the deal was invalidated when Fiat sold its finance arm and diluted GM's stake through a capital increase. The original 2000 agreement emerged from a competitive bid between GM and DaimlerChrysler to partner with Fiat.

original: Cardinal criticises iraq war cost billions of pounds spent on conflict in iraq and in the middle east should have been used to reduce poverty, cardinal cormac murphy-o'connor has said. The head of the catholic church in england and wales made the comments on bbc radio 4 and will re-iterate his stance in his christmas midnight mass. The cardinal used a christmas message to denounce the war in iraq as a "terrible" waste of money. He and the archbishop of canterbury have both spoken out about the war. Speaking on bbc radio 4's thought for the day slot, he criticised the fact that "billions" have been spent on war, instead of being used to bring people "out of dire poverty and malnourishment and disease". The cardinal said 2005 should be the year for campaigning to "make history poverty".
polished:
Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales, has criticized the Iraq War, stating that the billions spent on conflicts in Iraq and the Middle East should have been used to alleviate poverty. He made these remarks on BBC Radio 4 and will reiterate his position during his Christmas Midnight Mass.  

In his Christmas message, the Cardinal denounced the war in Iraq as a "terrible" misuse of resources. Both he and the Archbishop of Canterbury have publicly opposed the conflict. During his appearance on BBC Radio 4’s *Thought for the Day*, he lamented that vast sums had been devoted to warfare rather than lifting people "out of dire poverty, malnourishment, and disease." The Cardinal urged that 2005 should be a year dedicated to the campaign to "make poverty history.

original: British stars denied major oscars british hopes of winning major oscars were dashed as uk stars failed to win acting and directing prizes. Despite three nominations, mike leigh's vera drake failed to take the director or screenplay awards and there was no prize for star imelda staunton. Kate winslet also lost to best actress hilary swank, while clive owen and sophie okonedo failed to win best supporting actor awards. The uk's andrea arnold won the short film award for her gritty drama wasp. Arnold, who presented children's television shows number 73 and motormouth in the 1980s, said it was "totally overwhelming" to win. Wasp tells the story of a single mother living on the breadline, beating films by fellow uk nominees gary mckendry and ashvin kumar.
polished: British stars were denied major Oscars as UK hopes of winning top awards were dashed, with actors and directors missing out on prizes. Despite three nominations, Mike Leigh's *Vera Drake* failed to secure the director or screenplay awards, and its lead, Imelda Staunton, also went unrecognized. Kate Winslet lost the Best Actress category to Hilary Swank, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo were unsuccessful in the Best Supporting Actor and Actress races. The UK's sole victory came from Andrea Arnold, who won the Short Film award for her raw drama *Wasp*. Arnold, formerly a presenter on children's shows *Number 73* and *Motormouth* in the 1980s, described the win as "totally overwhelming." *Wasp*, which portrays the struggles of a single mother living in poverty, triumphed over films by fellow British nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

original: Halloween writer debra hill dies screenwriter and producer debra hill, best known for her work on the 70s horror classic halloween, has died in los angeles aged 54. Hill, who had been suffering from cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, which starred jamie lee curtis as a babysitter terrorised by a psychopath. Directed by john carpenter, it made over $60m (£31.3m) worldwide - a record for independent film at that time. Hill also worked with carpenter on escape from new york and the fog. Born in new jersey, hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way through the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before she began collaborating with carpenter. She was regarded by many as a pioneering woman in film, taking on jobs in the 70s that were more commonly taken by men.
polished:
Renowned screenwriter and producer Debra Hill, celebrated for her contributions to the 1970s horror classic *Halloween*, has passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film starring Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter hunted by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, the movie grossed over $60 million (£31.3 million) worldwide—a record for independent cinema at the time. Hill also collaborated with Carpenter on *Escape from New York* and *The Fog*.  

A New Jersey native, Hill started her career as a production assistant and steadily rose through the ranks, serving as an assistant director and second-unit director before partnering with Carpenter. Widely regarded as a trailblazer for women in film, she took on roles in the 1970s that were predominantly held by men, leaving a lasting legacy in the industry.

original: Broadband fuels online expression fast web access is encouraging more people to express themselves online, research suggests. A quarter of broadband users in britain regularly upload content and have personal sites, according to a report by uk think-tank demos. It said that having an always-on, fast connection is changing the way people use the internet. More than five million households in the uk have broadband and that number is growing fast. The demos report looked at the impact of broadband on people's net habits. It found that more than half of those with broadband logged on to the web before breakfast. One in five even admitted to getting up in the middle of the night to browse the web. More significantly, argues the report, broadband is encouraging people to take a more active role online.
polished: Broadband is accelerating online expression, as fast internet access inspires more individuals to share their thoughts and creations online, according to research. A study by UK think tank Demos reveals that a quarter of broadband users in Britain frequently upload content and maintain personal websites. The report highlights that constant, high-speed connectivity is transforming how people engage with the internet. With over five million UK households now on broadband—a figure rapidly increasing—the study examined its influence on online behavior. Findings show that more than half of broadband users access the web before breakfast, while one in five confesses to waking up at night to browse. Most notably, the report suggests broadband is empowering users to participate more actively in the digital space.

original: Yukos heading back to us courts russian oil and gas company yukos is due in a us court on thursday as it continues to fight for its survival. The firm is in the process of being broken up by russian authorities in order to pay a $27bn (£14bn) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the us, hoping to use international business law to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, yuganskneftegas. The unit was however sold for $9.4bn to state oil firm rosneft but only after the state auction had been disrupted. Yukos lawyers now say the auction violated us bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to go after any company that buys its assets, using all and every legal means.
polished:
Yukos Returns to US Courts  

The Russian oil and gas company Yukos is set to appear in a US court on Thursday as it persists in its battle for survival. The company is currently being dismantled by Russian authorities to settle a $27 billion (£14 billion) tax debt.  

Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the US, aiming to leverage international business law to prevent the forced sale of its crucial oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. However, the unit was ultimately sold for $9.4 billion to state-owned oil firm Rosneft, though only after disruptions during the state auction.  

Yukos’ legal team now contends that the auction violated US bankruptcy law. The company and its principal shareholders have pledged to pursue any firms acquiring its assets, employing every available legal recourse.

original: Voters flock to blog awards site voting is under way for the annual bloggies which recognise the best web blogs - online spaces where people publish their thoughts - of the year. Nominations were announced on sunday, but traffic to the official site was so heavy that the website was temporarily closed because of too many visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, from the top regional blog, to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a huge year, with a top us dictionary naming "blog" word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs and says that more than 12,000 are added daily. A blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to us research think-tank pew internet and american life, but less than 40% of the total are updated at least once every two months.
polished:
Voters are flocking to the Blog Awards site as voting begins for the annual Bloggies, honoring the best web blogs—online platforms where individuals share their thoughts—of the year. Nominations were unveiled on Sunday, but the surge in traffic to the official site was so overwhelming that it temporarily crashed due to excessive visitors. Weblogs have earned nominations across 30 categories, ranging from top regional blogs to the best-kept-secret blogs.  

Blogs had a monumental year, with a leading U.S. dictionary declaring "blog" the word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, monitors approximately six million blogs and reports that over 12,000 new ones are created daily. According to the U.S. research think tank Pew Internet and American Life, a new blog emerges every 5.8 seconds—yet fewer than 40% of all blogs are updated at least once every two months.

original: Chinese dam firm 'defies beijing' the china three gorges project corp is refusing to obey a government order to stop construction of one of its giant dams, the chinese state press has said. The builder of the three gorges dam is continuing work on the sister xiluodu dam, said the beijing news. The xiluodu dam is one of 30 such large-scale construction projects called to a halt because of a lack of proper environmental checks. The beijing news said the company may instead choose to pay a fine. The firm has also ignored orders to stop construction at two of its other projects - the three gorges underground power plant and the three gorges project electrical power supply plant. So far, only 22 of the 30 construction projects targeted by china's state environmental protection agency (sepa) for having not carried out mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with its shutdown order.
polished:
**Polished Text:**  

A Chinese dam firm appears to be defying Beijing’s orders, as the China Three Gorges Project Corp. continues construction on one of its massive dams despite a government directive to halt work, according to state media reports. The builder of the Three Gorges Dam is reportedly proceeding with the Xiluodu Dam project, as stated by *The Beijing News*. The Xiluodu Dam is among 30 major construction projects suspended due to insufficient environmental reviews.  

*The Beijing News* noted that the company may opt to pay a fine rather than comply. Additionally, the firm has disregarded stoppage orders for two other projects—the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Project Electrical Power Supply Plant.  

To date, only 22 of the 30 projects flagged by China’s State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for failing to conduct mandatory environmental impact assessments have adhered to the shutdown directive.

original: Man city 0-2 man utd manchester united reduced chelsea's premiership lead to nine points after a scrappy victory over manchester city. Wayne rooney met gary neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which went in via a deflection off richard dunne, to put united ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate dunne hooked a volley over david james' head and into his own net. Steve mcmanaman wasted city's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes united had looked unlikely to earn the win they needed to maintain any chance of catching chelsea in the title race. Their approach play was more laboured than patient and they managed to fashion just one chance - a paul scholes header over the bar.
polished:
Manchester United narrowed Chelsea's Premier League lead to nine points with a hard-fought 2-0 victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney opened the scoring by meeting Gary Neville's near-post cross with a low shot that deflected off Richard Dunne. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate Dunne inadvertently volleyed the ball over David James and into his own net. City's best opportunity came when Steve McManaman fired wide from close range in the first half.  

United had appeared unlikely to secure the crucial win they needed to stay in the title race during the opening 45 minutes. Their buildup play was more sluggish than measured, creating just one clear chance—a Paul Scholes header that sailed over the bar.

original: Wales 'must learn health lessons' the new health minister for wales says there are lessons to learn from england in tackling waiting lists. Dr brian gibbons, on his first full day in the job after jane hutt was sacked, admitted "big challenges" but insisted the "essentials" were in place. But both plaid cymru and the liberal democrats said dr gibbons needed to change policy. Meanwhile ms hutt defended her record, saying waiting times and lists were "only 10% of the health agenda. Dr gibbons, who was a gp in blaengwynfi, in the upper afan valley, before becoming am for aberavon, said nhs staff wanted a period of consolidation after "tremendous change and reform". One of the biggest problems which had faced ms hutt during her five-and-a-half years as the assembly's first health minister was the length of waiting lists in wales.
polished:
Wales 'must learn health lessons,' says the new Health Minister for Wales, who emphasizes the need to draw insights from England's approach to tackling waiting lists. On his first full day in office following Jane Hutt's dismissal, Dr. Brian Gibbons acknowledged "significant challenges" but maintained that the "fundamentals" were established. However, both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats argued that Dr. Gibbons must revise current policies.  

Meanwhile, Ms. Hutt defended her tenure, stating that waiting times and lists accounted for "only 10% of the health agenda." Dr. Gibbons, formerly a GP in Blaengwynfi in the Upper Afan Valley before becoming AM for Aberavon, noted that NHS staff sought a period of stability after years of "substantial change and reform."  

One of the most pressing issues during Ms. Hutt's five-and-a-half-year term as the Assembly's first Health Minister was the persistent challenge of lengthy waiting lists in Wales.

original: Ferguson hails man utd's resolve manchester united's alex ferguson has praised his players' gutsy performance in the 1-0 win at aston villa. "that was our hardest away game of the season and it was a fantastic game of football, end-to-end with lots of good passing," said the old trafford boss. "we showed lots of character and guts and we weren't going to lose. "i look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while arsenal and chelsea have yet to come and villa may have some players back when they do." ferguson also hailed senior stars ryan giggs and roy keane, who came off the bench for the injured john o'shea. "roy came on and brought a bit of composure to the midfield which we needed and which no other player has got.
polished:
Ferguson lauds Man Utd's resilience  
Manchester United's Alex Ferguson commended his team's determined performance in their hard-fought 1-0 victory over Aston Villa. "That was our toughest away fixture this season, yet it was a thrilling match—end-to-end action with excellent passing," remarked the Old Trafford manager. "We displayed tremendous character and resolve; defeat simply wasn’t an option."  

Reflecting on the challenge, Ferguson added, "I see this result as a statement—we’ve already conquered Villa Park, while Arsenal and Chelsea still have to face them, possibly with a stronger squad."  

He also praised veterans Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who stepped in after John O’Shea’s injury. "Roy’s introduction brought much-needed composure to the midfield—a quality unique to him.

original: Singer's film to show at festival a documentary which takes a candid look at the life of chart-topping singer george michael will be shown at this year's berlin film festival. A different story will screen in the panorama section of the festival, which runs from 10-20 february. It features the singer talking about both his career and his personal life, from his days in wham! through to more recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 february. Director southan morris and executive producer andy stephens will also attend the festival. The 93 minute film will see michael discussing his early days in wham! along with his later career, including his legal battles with record label sony and his stance against the iraq war and american politics.
polished: A documentary offering an intimate glimpse into the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will premiere at this year's Berlin Film Festival. *A Different Story* will be featured in the festival's Panorama section, running from 10–20 February. The film captures the singer reflecting on both his professional journey and personal experiences—from his early days in Wham! to more recent chapters of his life. Michael himself will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 February, joined by director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens. The 93-minute documentary delves into Michael's rise with Wham!, his solo career, his legal disputes with record label Sony, and his vocal opposition to the Iraq War and American politics.

original: Downloads enter us singles chart digital music downloads are being included in the main us singles chart for the first time. Billboard's hot 100 chart now incorporates data from sales of music downloads, previously only assigned to a separate download chart. Green day's boulevard of broken dreams is currently number two in billboard's pop chart, and tops its digital chart. Download sales are due to be incorporated into the uk singles chart later this year. Digital sales in the us are already used to compile billboard's hot digital sales chart. They will now be tallied with sales of physical singles and airplay information to make up its new hot 100 chart. Its second new chart - the pop 100 - also combines airplay, digital and physical sales but confines its airplay information to us radio stations which play chart music.
polished:
For the first time, digital music downloads are being integrated into the main US singles chart. Billboard’s Hot 100 now includes data from digital download sales, which were previously limited to a separate download chart. Green Day’s *Boulevard of Broken Dreams* currently holds the number two spot on Billboard’s Pop Chart while leading its digital chart.  

The UK singles chart is also set to incorporate download sales later this year. In the US, digital sales already contribute to Billboard’s Hot Digital Sales chart, but they will now be combined with physical single sales and airplay data to form the updated Hot 100.  

Additionally, Billboard’s second new chart—the Pop 100—merges airplay, digital, and physical sales but restricts its airplay data to US radio stations that feature chart music.

original: Anti-spam laws bite spammer hard the net's self-declared spam king is seeking bankruptcy protection. Scott richter, the man behind optinrealbig.com and billions of junk mail messages, said lawsuits had forced the company into chapter 11. Optinrealbig was fighting several legal battles, most notably against microsoft, which is pushing for millions of dollars in damages. The company said filing for chapter 11 would help it try to resolve its legal problems but still keep trading. Listed as the third biggest spammer in the world by junk mail watchdog spamhaus, optinrealbig was sued in december 2003 for sending mail messages that violated anti-spam laws. The lawsuit was brought by microsoft and new york attorney general eliot spitzer who alleged that mr richter and his accomplices sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised net addresses in 35 countries.
polished: Anti-spam laws have dealt a heavy blow to a notorious spammer, as the self-proclaimed "spam king" of the internet seeks bankruptcy protection. Scott Richter, the operator behind OptInRealBig.com and the source of billions of junk emails, claims lawsuits have driven his company to file for Chapter 11. OptInRealBig faces multiple legal challenges, most significantly from Microsoft, which is pursuing millions in damages. The company stated that the bankruptcy filing would allow it to address its legal issues while continuing operations. Ranked as the world's third-largest spammer by anti-spam watchdog Spamhaus, OptInRealBig was sued in December 2003 for violating anti-spam laws with its mass email campaigns. Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer led the lawsuit, alleging Richter and his associates sent billions of spam messages using 514 compromised internet addresses across 35 countries.

original: Arnesen denies rift with santini tottenham sporting director frank arnesen has denied that coach jacques santini resigned because of a clash of personalities at white hart lane. There had been newspaper speculation that santini had felt undermined by arnesen's role at the club. "it is absolutely not true," arnesen told bbc radio five live. "there is only one thing that made him resign and that is his own personal problems. "he has talked to me recently and said this matter is absolutely for himself." arnesen said he was unable to throw any light onto the problems that caused santini to quit after just 13 games in charge. He added: "jacques has never gone into exactly what it was. But i trust him in that; you have to accept it. I think we should respect it.
polished:
Tottenham Sporting Director Frank Arnesen has denied reports of a rift with former coach Jacques Santini, insisting Santini's resignation was due solely to personal reasons. Recent newspaper speculation suggested Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's influence at White Hart Lane.  

"These claims are completely untrue," Arnesen stated in an interview with BBC Radio Five Live. "Only one factor led to his resignation—his own personal issues. He has spoken to me recently and confirmed this matter was entirely his own."  

Arnesen admitted he could not elaborate on the specific reasons behind Santini's abrupt departure after just 13 matches in charge. "Jacques never disclosed the exact details, but I trust his word on this. We must accept and respect his decision," he added.

original: Ireland surge past scots ireland maintained their six nations grand slam ambitions with an impressive victory over scotland at murrayfield. Hugo southwell's try gave the scots an early 8-0 lead but scores from locks malcolm o'kelly and paul o'connell put the visitors in command by half-time. A third try from wing denis hickie and third penalty from ronan o'gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon petrie scored a second try for scotland but late scores from john hayes and gavin duffy sealed victory. After two hard-earned away victories, eddie o'sullivan' side can now look forward to welcoming england to lansdowne road in a fortnight. Scotland will try to give their coach matt williams a first six nations victory when italy come to edinburgh, but they again struggled to turn pressure into points.
polished:
Ireland surged past Scotland, maintaining their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions with a commanding victory at Murrayfield. Hugo Southwell's try gave the Scots an early 8-0 lead, but tries from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in control by halftime. A third try from wing Denis Hickie, along with Ronan O'Gara's third penalty—contributing 13 points in total—extended Ireland's lead. Jon Petrie crossed for Scotland's second try, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed the win.  

After two hard-fought away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side now turns its attention to hosting England at Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Meanwhile, Scotland will aim to secure their first Six Nations win under coach Matt Williams when Italy visits Edinburgh, though their struggles to convert pressure into points persisted.

original: Economy focus for election battle britain's economic future will be at the heart of labour's poll campaign, chancellor gordon brown has said. He was speaking after cabinet members held their last meeting at no 10 before the expected election announcement. He said voters would recognise that labour had brought stability and growth, and would continue to do so. Meanwhile the tories outlined their plans to tackle "yob culture" and the lib dems gave more details about their proposals to replace council tax. Earlier the archbishop of canterbury wrote to all three parties urging them not to fight the election by exploiting people's fears. In an open letter, he called on them not to turn the election into a competition about who can most effectively frighten voters about terrorism, asylum, and crime.
polished:
Economic Focus for Election Battle: Britain's economic future will be at the heart of Labour's election campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown has stated. He made these remarks following the cabinet's final meeting at No. 10 before the anticipated election announcement. Brown emphasized that voters would acknowledge Labour's role in delivering stability and growth, pledging to sustain this progress.  

Meanwhile, the Conservatives outlined their strategy to address "yob culture," while the Liberal Democrats provided further details on their plans to replace council tax. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury wrote to all three major parties, urging them to avoid exploiting public fears during the campaign. In an open letter, he appealed for restraint, cautioning against turning the election into a contest over which party could most effectively alarm voters regarding terrorism, asylum, and crime.

original: Brizzel to run aaa's in sheffield ballymena sprinter paul brizzel will be among eight of ireland's european indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's aaa's championships. Us-based alistair cragg and mark carroll are the only irish athletes selected so far for the europeans who will not run in sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title in the british trials. In-form james mcilroy will hope to confirm his place in the british team for madrid by winning the 800m title. Mcilroy has been in tremendous form on the european circuit in recent weeks. He is one of the fastest 800m runners in the world this winter and already seems assured of a place in madrid. Corkman mark carroll confirmed in midweek that he would join cragg in the european championships. Carroll is ranked number three in the world 3000m ranking at the moment with cragg occupying top spot.
polished:
Brizzell to compete in AAA's in Sheffield  
Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzell will be among eight of Ireland’s European Indoor hopefuls taking part in this weekend’s AAA Championships. US-based athletes Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish competitors selected so far for the Europeans who will not race in Sheffield.  

Brizzell will defend his 200m title at the British trials, while in-form James McIlroy aims to secure his spot on the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m event. McIlroy has shown outstanding performance on the European circuit in recent weeks, establishing himself as one of the fastest 800m runners globally this winter and virtually guaranteeing his place in Madrid.  

Meanwhile, Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed midweek that he would join Cragg at the European Championships. Carroll currently holds the world number three ranking in the 3000m, with Cragg leading the standings.

original: Robinson wants dual code success england rugby union captain jason robinson has targeted dual code success over australia on saturday. Robinson, a former rugby league international before switching codes in 2000, leads england against australia at twickenham at 1430 gmt. And at 1815 gmt, great britain's rugby league team take on australia in the final of the tri-nations tournament. "beating the aussies in both games would be a massive achievement, especially for league," said robinson. England have the chance to seal their third autumn international victory after successive wins over canada and south africa, as well as gaining revenge for june's 51-15 hammering by the wallabies. Meanwhile, great britain could end 34 years of failure against australia with victory at elland road.
polished:
England rugby union captain Jason Robinson is aiming for dual-code success against Australia on Saturday. Robinson, who transitioned from rugby league to union in 2000, will lead England against the Wallabies at Twickenham at 14:30 GMT. Later, at 18:15 GMT, Great Britain's rugby league team will face Australia in the Tri-Nations final.  

"Defeating the Aussies in both matches would be an incredible achievement, particularly for league," said Robinson.  

England have the opportunity to secure their third consecutive autumn international victory after wins over Canada and South Africa, while also avenging their 51-15 defeat by Australia in June. Meanwhile, Great Britain could break a 34-year losing streak against Australia with a triumph at Elland Road.

original: Warning over tsunami aid website net users are being told to avoid a scam website that claims to collect cash on behalf of tsunami victims. The site looks plausible because it uses an old version of the official disasters emergency committee webpage. However, dec has no connection with the fake site and says it has contacted the police about it. The site is just the latest in a long list of scams that try to cash in on the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is contained in a spam e-mail that is currently circulating. The message's subject line reads "urgent tsunami earthquake appeal" and its text bears all the poor grammar and bad spelling that characterises many other phishing attempts.
polished:
**Polished Version:**  

"Warning Issued Over Tsunami Aid Scam Website  

Internet users are being warned to steer clear of a fraudulent website falsely claiming to collect donations for tsunami victims. The site appears credible at first glance, as it mimics an outdated version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) webpage. However, the DEC has confirmed it has no affiliation with the fake site and has reported the matter to the police.  

This scam is just one of many attempting to exploit the public’s generosity following the tsunami disaster. The fraudulent website’s link is being spread via a spam email currently in circulation. The email’s subject line reads *"Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal,"* and its content—riddled with poor grammar and spelling errors—is typical of phishing scams.

original: Iraq to invite phone licence bids iraq is to invite bids for two telephone licences, saying it wants to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade. Bids have been invited from local, arab and foreign companies, iraq's ministry of communications said. The winner will work in partnership with the iraqi telecommunications and post company (itpc). The firms will install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax and internet services. The ministry said that it wanted to increase iraq's "very low telephone service penetration rate from about 4.5% today to about 25% within 10 years." it also hopes to develop a "highly visible and changeable telecommunication sector". Details of the bidding and tender process will be published on the ministry's website on 9 february. It also is planning a road-show for investors in amman, jordan.
polished:
Iraq to Invite Bids for Phone Licenses  

Iraq is set to invite bids for two telephone licenses, aiming to significantly expand nationwide coverage over the next decade. The Ministry of Communications stated that bids will be open to local, Arab, and foreign companies. The winning firms will collaborate with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC) to install and operate a fixed-line network, delivering voice, fax, and internet services.  

The ministry emphasized its goal to raise Iraq's "currently low telephone service penetration rate from approximately 4.5% to around 25% within ten years." Additionally, it aims to develop a "dynamic and adaptable telecommunications sector."  

Details of the bidding and tender process will be announced on the ministry's website on February 9. A roadshow for potential investors is also planned in Amman, Jordan.

original: More women turn to net security older people and women are increasingly taking charge of protecting home computers against malicious net attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women buying programs to protect pcs from virus, spam and spyware attacks rose by 11.2% each year between 2002 and 2004. The study, for net security firm preventon, shows that security messages are reaching a diversity of surfers. It is thought that 40% of those buying home net security programs are retired. For the last three years, that has gone up by an average of 13.2%. But more retired women (53%) were buying security software than retired men. The research reflects the changing stereotype and demographics of web users, as well as growing awareness of the greater risks that high-speed broadband net connections can pose to surfers.
polished:
A growing number of older adults and women are taking the lead in safeguarding home computers against online threats, reveals a two-year study. Between 2002 and 2004, purchases of antivirus, anti-spam, and anti-spyware programs by women increased by 11.2% annually. Conducted for the cybersecurity firm Preventon, the research demonstrates that security awareness is spreading across diverse internet users.  

Notably, retirees account for 40% of home cybersecurity software buyers, with this figure rising by an average of 13.2% over the past three years. Among retirees, women (53%) outpace men in adopting protective measures. These findings highlight shifting stereotypes and demographics among web users, as well as heightened recognition of the risks posed by high-speed broadband connections.

original: Podcasts mark rise of diy radio an apple ipod or other digital music players can hold anything up to 10,000 songs, which is a lot of space to fill. But more and more ipod owners are filling that space with audio content created by an unpredictable assortment of producers. It is called "podcasting" and its strongest proponent is former mtv host and vj (video jockey) adam curry. Podcasting takes its name from the apple ipod, although you do not need an ipod to create one or to listen to a podcast. A podcast is basically an internet-based radio show which podcasters create, usually in the comfort of their own home. They need only a microphone, a pc, and some editing software. They then upload their shows to the internet and others can download and listen to them, all for free.
polished: Podcasts signal the rise of DIY radio. An Apple iPod or similar digital music player can store up to 10,000 songs—ample space to fill. Increasingly, iPod users are populating that space with audio content produced by a diverse range of creators. This phenomenon is known as "podcasting," championed most notably by former MTV host and VJ Adam Curry. Though the term derives from the Apple iPod, an iPod isn’t necessary to create or listen to a podcast. Essentially, a podcast is an internet-based radio show, typically produced by individuals from their homes. All that’s required is a microphone, a computer, and basic editing software. Once created, these shows are uploaded to the internet, where anyone can download and enjoy them—completely free of charge.

original: Levy takes whitbread novel prize orange prize winner andrea levy has seen her book small island win the whitbread novel of the year award. She is now favourite to win the overall prize after beating booker winner alan hollinghurst's the line of beauty. Geraldine mccaughrean has picked up the children's fiction award for the third time for not the end of the world. All the category winners go through to compete for the whitbread book of the year title, which carries with it a £25,000 prize. A panel of judges including sir trevor mcdonald, actor hugh grant and writer joanne harris will meet up on 25 january to decide the overall winner, with the announcement being made later that evening. Bookmaker william hill has placed london-based levy's novel as the 6/4 favourite to win.
polished:
Levy wins Whitbread Novel Prize  
Orange Prize winner Andrea Levy has claimed the Whitbread Novel of the Year award for her book *Small Island*. She now emerges as the frontrunner for the overall prize after surpassing Booker winner Alan Hollinghurst’s *The Line of Beauty*. Geraldine McCaughrean secured the Children’s Fiction Award for the third time with *Not the End of the World*.  

All category winners will advance to compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which includes a £25,000 prize. A judging panel featuring Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris will convene on 25 January to determine the overall winner, with the announcement following later that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has positioned London-based Levy’s novel as the 6/4 favorite to win.

original: Yukos seeks court action on sale yukos will return to a us court on wednesday to seek sanctions against baikal finance group, the little-known firm which has bought its main asset. Yukos has said it will sue baikal and others involved in the sale of yuganskneftegas for $20bn in damages. Yukos' us lawyers will attempt to have baikal assets frozen after the russian government ignored a us court order last week blocking the sale. Baikal's background and its motives for buying the unit are still unclear. Russian newspapers have claimed that baikal - which bought the yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4bn (261bn roubles, £4.8bn) on sunday at a state provoked auction - has strong links with surgutneftegas, russia's fourth-biggest oil producer.
polished:
Yukos is pursuing legal action to challenge the sale of its main asset and will return to a U.S. court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the obscure firm behind the purchase. Yukos has announced its intention to sue Baikal and other parties involved in the $20 billion sale of Yuganskneftegas for damages. The company's U.S. legal team will also seek to freeze Baikal's assets after the Russian government disregarded a U.S. court order last week that attempted to halt the sale.  

The origins of Baikal and its motives for acquiring the unit remain uncertain. Russian media reports suggest that Baikal—which secured Yuganskneftegas for $9.4 billion (261 billion roubles, £4.8 billion) in a state-backed auction on Sunday—has close ties to Surgutneftegas, Russia’s fourth-largest oil producer.

original: Hearts 2-1 livingston hearts wrapped up their scottish cup quarter-final tie against livingston with two goals in the first 10 minutes. Lee miller scored inside the opening 60 seconds, heading over colin meldrum and into the net from a jamie mcallister free kick. Mcallister himself scored the second when he met saul mikoliunas' cross at the back post to put the game beyond the visitors. Craig easton headed in a controversial goal after an hour but hearts held on. The opening goal came after gus bahoken had clumsily fouled miller 35 yards from goal. Mcallister floated the free kick into the livi box and miller outjumped the static visiting defence to loop his header from 10 yards over meldrum. With just 10 minutes on the clock, the home side doubled their lead. Mikoliunas sprinted down the right, crossed to the back post where mcallister raced in to head past meldrum.
polished:
Hearts secured a 2-1 victory over Livingston in their Scottish Cup quarter-final clash, sealing the win with two early goals in the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller opened the scoring within the first minute, rising to meet Jamie McAllister's free-kick and looping a header over Colin Meldrum from 10 yards out. McAllister then doubled the lead, arriving at the back post to nod home Saul Mikoliunas' cross, putting the game out of Livingston's reach. Craig Easton pulled one back with a contentious header after an hour, but Hearts stood firm.  

The breakthrough came after Gus Bahoken's clumsy challenge on Miller 35 yards from goal. McAllister delivered a precise free-kick into the box, where Miller outjumped Livingston's static defense to direct his header over Meldrum. Just 10 minutes in, Hearts extended their advantage when Mikoliunas surged down the right flank and delivered a cross to the far post, where McAllister arrived to power his header past the keeper.

original: Sun offers processing by the hour sun microsystems has launched a pay-as-you-go service which will allow customers requiring huge computing power to rent it by the hour. Sun grid costs users $1 (53p) for an hour's worth of processing and storage power on systems maintained by sun. So-called grid computing is the latest buzz phrase in a company which believes that computing capacity is as important a commodity as hardware and software. Sun likened grid computing to the development of electricity. The system could mature in the same way utilities such as electricity and water have developed, said sun's chief operating officer jonathan schwartz. "why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?" he asked in a webcast launching sun's quarterly network computing event in california.
polished:
Sun Microsystems has introduced a pay-as-you-go service that enables customers in need of substantial computing power to rent it by the hour. Dubbed Sun Grid, the service charges users $1 (53p) per hour for access to processing and storage capabilities on Sun-maintained systems. Grid computing, the latest industry buzzword, reflects Sun's belief that computing capacity is as vital a commodity as hardware and software. The company draws a parallel between grid computing and the evolution of electricity, suggesting the system could mature similarly to utilities like power and water.  

"Why build your own grid when you can use ours for just a dollar an hour?" remarked Sun's Chief Operating Officer Jonathan Schwartz during a webcast announcing the company's quarterly network computing event in California.

original: Jamieson issues warning to bigots scotland's justice minister has warned bigoted soccer fans that she wants to hit them "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Cathy jamieson said exclusion orders are one of a series of measures being considered in the scottish executive campaign against sectarianism. She praised celtic and rangers for their work in tackling the problem. However, the minister said stopping sectarian abuse associated with old firm matches is a key objective. Ms jamieson was speaking ahead of the third round scottish cup clash between the glasgow clubs at parkhead on sunday. The sectarianism long associated with sections of the support from both clubs has become a significant target for the executive. Last week ms jamieson and first minister jack mcconnell met supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the issue.
polished:
Scotland's Justice Minister Cathy Jamieson has issued a stern warning to bigoted football fans, stating she intends to target them "where it hurts most" by imposing match bans. Jamieson highlighted exclusion orders as one of several measures under consideration in the Scottish Executive's campaign against sectarianism.  

She commended both Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in addressing the issue but emphasized that curbing sectarian abuse linked to Old Firm matches remains a top priority. Jamieson made these remarks ahead of Sunday's third-round Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow rivals at Parkhead.  

The long-standing sectarianism associated with segments of both clubs' fanbases has become a major focus for the Executive. Last week, Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell met with supporters' representatives from Celtic and Rangers to discuss the ongoing problem.

original: Home phones face unclear future the fixed line phone in your home could soon be an endangered species. Research by handset maker nokia shows that more and more people are using their mobile phone for every call they make or take. According to the study, more than 45 million people in the uk, germany, us and south korea now only use a mobile. It showed that people keep their fixed line phone because call charges are lower, but most of those questioned said the future was definitely mobile. The nokia-sponsored research showed that mobiles and fixed phones were used for different purposes. Home phones were used for longer calls but conversations on mobiles tended to be shorter, between mobiles and to friends. In the uk 69% of those questioned said they turned to their fixed phone because it was still cheaper to use than a mobile.
polished:
Home phones face an uncertain future, as the traditional fixed-line telephone in households may soon become a rarity. Research conducted by handset manufacturer Nokia reveals that an increasing number of people rely solely on their mobile phones for all calls, whether making or receiving them. The study indicates that over 45 million individuals in the UK, Germany, the US, and South Korea now exclusively use mobile devices. While some retain fixed-line phones due to lower call costs, the majority of respondents agreed that the future undoubtedly lies with mobile technology.  

The Nokia-sponsored research highlighted distinct usage patterns between mobile and landline phones. Fixed-line phones were preferred for longer conversations, whereas mobile calls tended to be shorter, often between mobile users or with friends. In the UK, 69% of participants cited cost savings as the primary reason for still using a landline, acknowledging that it remains cheaper than mobile alternatives.

original: Disappointed scott in solid start allan scott is confident of winning a medal at next week's european indoor championships after a solid debut on the international circuit. polished:
Allan Scott remains confident of securing a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships despite a slightly disappointing debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the José M. Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid.  

"It was certainly a learning experience, and I still believe I can challenge for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete.  

The race was won by Felipe Vivancos, who matched the Spanish record, followed by Sweden’s Robert Kronberg in second and Haiti’s Dudley Dorival in third.  

Scott, who won his heat in 7.64 seconds, expressed mild frustration with his performance in the final, where he ran 0.04 seconds slower in his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix circuit final.

original: Us woman sues over cartridges a us woman is suing hewlett packard (hp), saying its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a certain date. The unnamed woman from georgia says that a chip inside the cartridge tells the printer that it needs re-filling even when it does not. The lawsuit seeks to represent anyone in the us who has purchased an hp inkjet printer since february 2001. Hp, the world's biggest printer firm, declined to comment on the lawsuit. Hp ink cartridges use a chip technology to sense when they are low on ink and advise the user to make a change. But the suit claims the chips also shut down the cartridges at a predetermined date regardless of whether they are empty.
polished: A U.S. woman has filed a lawsuit against Hewlett-Packard (HP), alleging that its printer ink cartridges are covertly programmed to expire on a specific date. The unnamed plaintiff from Georgia claims that an embedded chip in the cartridge falsely signals the printer to prompt a refill even when ink remains. The class-action lawsuit aims to represent all U.S. consumers who purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's leading printer manufacturer, has declined to comment on the ongoing litigation. While HP's cartridges utilize chip technology to monitor ink levels and alert users when replacement is needed, the lawsuit asserts that these chips also deactivate the cartridges by a preset deadline, irrespective of remaining ink.

James Cridland, Virgin Radio's Head of New Media, remarked, 'This innovation positions radio at the forefront of the 3G revolution.' Virgin Radio will lead the rollout, followed by its digital counterparts, Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove.

original: Spirit awards hail sideways the comedy sideways has dominated this year's independent spirit awards, winning all six of the awards for which it was nominated. It also won acting awards for stars paul giamatti, thomas haden church and virginia madsen. Sideways is tipped to do well at sunday's oscars, with five nominations. The awards, now in their 20th year, are given to films made outside the traditional studio system, and are traditionally held the day before the oscars. polished:
The comedy *Sideways* triumphed at this year's Independent Spirit Awards, sweeping all six categories for which it was nominated. The film claimed Best Feature, while Alexander Payne earned Best Director and Best Screenplay, sharing the latter honor with co-writer Jim Taylor. The cast also shone, with Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen each securing acting awards. *Sideways*, a strong contender at Sunday’s Oscars with five nominations, continued its award-season momentum.  

Now in their 20th year, the Spirit Awards celebrate films produced outside the traditional studio system and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars. Among other winners, Catalina Sandino Moreno claimed Best Actress for her portrayal of a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama *Maria Full of Grace*—a role that also earned her an Oscar nomination. Joshua Marston received the Best First Screenplay award for the same film.

polished:
Prince was crowned the "top music earner" of 2004, surpassing renowned artists like Madonna and Elton John in *Rolling Stone* magazine's annual ranking. The iconic singer amassed $56.5 million (£30.4 million) from concert revenues, album sales, and publishing royalties, driven by his successful *Musicology* tour and album release. Madonna secured second place with earnings of $54.9 million (£29.5 million) during her *Re-Invention* world tour. Meanwhile, veteran duo Simon & Garfunkel claimed 10th place, generating $24.9 million (£13.4 million) from their much-anticipated comeback tour.  

*Rolling Stone* noted, "Prince reclaimed the spotlight after a decade on the commercial sidelines." His 2004 tour alone grossed $90.3 million (£48.5 million) in ticket sales, and his latest album, *Musicology*, sold an impressive 1.9 million copies.

original: Tories outlining policing plans local communities would be asked to go to the polls to elect their own area police commissioner, under plans unveiled by the conservatives. Party leader michael howard said the new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities. He said the new office would not supersede the job of a chief constable. The lib dems said the plan could let extreme groups run policing, while labour criticised "extravagant" tory promises on policing. Responding to the plans, the chairman of the police federation of england and wales, which represents rank and file officers, said it was essential operational independence was retained. Jan berry said: "it is a service, not a political football to be kicked around every time an election approaches. "these plans could result in those with extreme political views dictating what actually happens on the ground," she warned.
polished:
The Conservatives have outlined policing plans under which local communities would vote to elect their own area's police commissioner. Party leader Michael Howard stated that this new role would replace what he called "inconspicuous" police authorities, while clarifying that the position would not override the authority of chief constables.  

The Liberal Democrats raised concerns that the proposal could allow extreme groups to influence policing, while Labour dismissed the Tories' promises on policing as "extravagant."  

In response, Jan Berry, Chair of the Police Federation of England and Wales—which represents rank-and-file officers—stressed the importance of maintaining operational independence. "Policing is a public service, not a political football to be kicked around every election cycle," she said. "These plans risk enabling individuals with extreme political views to dictate operational decisions on the ground," Berry warned.

original: At a glance: tory health checks the uk' opposition conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's a guide to the plan: people coming to live and work in britain from outside the eu. If they plan to stay six months or more and are from a country with lots of tb, they would have to have a chest x-ray and further tests if appropriate. All people from outside the european union who want to stay a year or more will have to undergo a full medical. Tuberculosis, hepatitis b and hiv. A positive test for tb would automatically mean visa applications being turned down. All other conditions would be dealt with on a case by case basis.
polished:
At a glance: Tory health checks  
The UK's opposition Conservative Party has announced plans to implement mandatory health screenings for immigrants if they win the upcoming general election. Here’s an overview of the proposal:  

- Individuals relocating to Britain from outside the EU for work or residence would be subject to health checks.  
- Those intending to stay for six months or longer, originating from countries with high tuberculosis (TB) rates, would require a chest X-ray and additional tests if necessary.  
- All non-EU nationals seeking to remain in the UK for a year or more would undergo a comprehensive medical examination, covering conditions such as tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV.  
- A positive TB test would result in an automatic visa rejection.  
- Other medical conditions would be assessed individually on a case-by-case basis.

original: Paris promise raises welsh hopes has there been a better six nations match than saturday's epic in paris? and can the welsh revival continue all the way to a first grand slam since 1978? those are the two questions occupying not just wales supporters but rugby fans as a whole after a scintillating display in paris. Welsh legend mervyn davies, a member of two of three grand slam-winning sides of the 1970s, hailed it as "one of the great performances of the past three decades". Martyn williams, wales' two-try scorer on the day, called it "one of the most surreal games i have ever played in". A crestfallen france coach, bernard laporte, simply observed: "there was a french half and there was a welsh half".
polished:
Paris Promise Lifts Welsh Hopes: Was there ever a more thrilling Six Nations match than Saturday's epic showdown in Paris? And can Wales' resurgence carry them all the way to their first Grand Slam since 1978? These are the questions captivating not only Welsh supporters but rugby enthusiasts worldwide after an electrifying performance in the French capital.  

Welsh icon Mervyn Davies, part of two Grand Slam-winning teams in the 1970s, praised it as "one of the finest displays of the last thirty years." Martyn Williams, who scored two tries for Wales that day, described it as "one of the most surreal matches I’ve ever been part of." Meanwhile, a dejected French coach, Bernard Laporte, remarked simply: "There was a French half—and there was a Welsh half."

original: Cabinet anger at brown cash raid ministers are unhappy about plans to use whitehall cash to keep council tax bills down, local government minister nick raynsford has acknowledged. Gordon brown reallocated £512m from central to local government budgets in his pre-budget report on thursday. Mr raynsford said he had held some "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers over the plans. But he said local governments had to deliver good services without big council tax rises. The central government cash is part of a £1bn package to help local authorities in england keep next year's council tax rises below 5%, in what is likely to be a general election year. Mr raynsford said nearly all central government departments had an interest in well run local authorities.
polished:
Cabinet frustration over Brown's funding shift has been acknowledged by Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford, as ministers express discontent over plans to use Whitehall funds to curb council tax hikes. In his pre-budget report on Thursday, Gordon Brown redirected £512 million from central to local government budgets. Raynsford revealed having held "frank and robust discussions" with colleagues regarding the proposal. However, he emphasized that local governments must maintain quality services without imposing significant tax increases.  

The central government allocation forms part of a £1 billion package aimed at helping English local authorities limit next year's council tax rises to under 5%—a critical consideration in what is expected to be a general election year. Raynsford noted that nearly all central government departments have a vested interest in ensuring efficiently managed local authorities.

polished:
The Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin is turning to Africa, with four African players—including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro—set to feature for the team in the UEFA Cup. Bnei Sakhnin, the first Arab side to compete in European football, will face English Premier League outfit Newcastle United in the first round.  

Murambadoro, who rose to prominence during the Africa Cup of Nations in Tunisia, played a key role in Bnei Sakhnin's 6-1 victory over Albania's Partizani Tirana in the previous round. The goalkeeper recently joined the Israeli club after a short spell with South Africa's Hellenic.  

Last season, Bnei Sakhnin clinched the Israeli Cup and are based in Sakhnin, a town near Haifa. Known for their strong values, the club is a prominent advocate for peace and cooperation within Israel.

original: New drink limit 'would cut toll' more lives than previously thought could be saved by cutting drink-drive limits by a third, a report says. University college london research claims cutting the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would save 65 lives a year. The findings are being published by the parliamentary advisory council for transport safety as mps are due to vote on the government's road safety bill. The bill includes changes to speeding fines but not to the drink-drive limit. The research, carried out by transport expert professor richard allsop, says cutting the limit would also lead to 230 fewer serious injuries on the uk's roads compared with 2003. He estimates that this would save the country £119m a year. A previous estimate, contained in a 1998 department of transport document, suggested such a move could save 50 lives a year.
polished:
Stricter Drink-Drive Limit Could Save More Lives Than Expected"  

A new report suggests that reducing the drink-drive limit by a third could save significantly more lives than previously estimated. Research from University College London indicates that lowering the legal limit from 80mg to 50mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood would prevent 65 fatalities annually.  

The findings, published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety, coincide with MPs preparing to vote on the government’s Road Safety Bill. While the bill proposes changes to speeding penalties, it does not address the drink-drive limit.  

According to transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, who led the study, implementing the lower limit would also result in 230 fewer serious road injuries compared to 2003 levels, saving the UK approximately £119 million per year. This contrasts with a 1998 Department of Transport estimate, which projected only 50 lives saved annually under similar measures.

original: This paper presents a millimeter-scale cmos 64$\times$64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1$\times$1 $\mu m^2$ diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512$\times$512 $\mu m^2$. Instead of sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline. This obviates the need for using power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype asic is fabricated in tsmc 65 nm lp cmos process and consumes the average static power of 0.535 mw under 1.2 v analog and digital power supply. The functionality of the whole system is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 mev proton beam setting.
polished: This paper introduces a millimeter-scale CMOS 64×64 single charged particle radiation detector system designed for external beam cancer radiotherapy. The system employs a 1×1 μm² diode to measure energy deposition by individual charged particles within the depletion region, while the array configuration offers an expansive detection area of 512×512 μm². Rather than detecting voltage fluctuations induced by radiation, the proposed system quantifies pulse width—the duration required for the voltage to stabilize back to baseline—eliminating the need for bulky, power-intensive analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC, fabricated using TSMC's 65 nm LP CMOS process, demonstrates an average static power consumption of 0.535 mW under a 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The system's full functionality has been successfully validated in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam environment.

original: Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (avs) has been shown to reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that avs would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme that aims to incentivize avs to seek centrally controlled system optimal (so) routing by saving on tolls while user equilibrium (ue) seeking avs and human-driven vehicles (hvs) are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, in which dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, whereas the lower level is a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model considering mixed fleet of avs and hvs.
polished: Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been demonstrated to mitigate the adverse effects of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the presumption that AVs would willingly submit to external control by a central authority is impractical. This paper introduces a combined routing and pricing control framework designed to incentivize AVs to adopt centrally coordinated system-optimal (SO) routing by offering toll savings, while user-equilibrium (UE)-seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HVs) incur congestion charges. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization model, where dynamic tolls are optimized at the upper level, and the lower level consists of a simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model that accounts for mixed fleets of AVs and HVs under equilibrium conditions.

original: Optomechanics and electromechanics have made it possible to prepare macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, in quadrature squeezed states, and in entangled states of motion. In addition to coaxing ever larger and more tangible objects into a regime of quantum behavior, this new capability has encouraged ideas of using mechanical oscillators in the processing and communication of quantum information and as precision force sensors operating beyond the standard quantum limit. But the effectively linear interaction between motion and light or electricity precludes access to the broader class of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Indeed, early optomechanical proposals noted the possibility to escape this restriction by creating strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. Although there have been experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, these have not yet accessed nonclassical states of motion.
polished: Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the preparation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in quantum ground states, quadrature-squeezed states, and entangled motional states. Beyond pushing larger, more tangible objects into the quantum regime, this advancement has spurred proposals to utilize mechanical oscillators for quantum information processing, communication, and high-precision force sensing beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the predominantly linear interaction between motion and light or electricity restricts access to a wider range of quantum motional states, such as cat states or energy-squeezed states. Early optomechanical proposals highlighted the potential to overcome this limitation by establishing strong quadratic coupling between motion and light. While experimental realizations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems exist, they have yet to achieve nonclassical states of motion.

original: Online reviews provide product evaluations for customers to make decisions. Unfortunately, the evaluations can be manipulated using fake reviews ("spams") by professional spammers, who have learned increasingly insidious and powerful spamming strategies by adapting to the deployed detectors. Spamming strategies are hard to capture, as they can be varying quickly along time, different across spammers and target products, and more critically, remained unknown in most cases. Furthermore, most existing detectors focus on detection accuracy, which is not well-aligned with the goal of maintaining the trustworthiness of product evaluations. To address the challenges, we formulate a minimax game where the spammers and spam detectors compete with each other on their practical goals that are not solely based on detection accuracy. Nash equilibria of the game lead to stable detectors that are agnostic to any mixed detection strategies.
polished: Online reviews offer valuable product assessments to guide customer decisions. However, these evaluations can be compromised by fake reviews ("spams") created by professional spammers, who continually refine increasingly subtle and effective spamming tactics to evade detection systems. Capturing spamming strategies is challenging, as they evolve rapidly over time, vary among spammers and target products, and—most critically—often remain undiscovered. Moreover, current detectors primarily emphasize detection accuracy, which does not fully align with preserving the reliability of product evaluations. To tackle these issues, we propose a minimax game framework where spammers and detectors compete based on practical objectives beyond mere detection accuracy. The Nash equilibria of this game yield robust detectors that remain effective against any mixed detection strategies.

original: We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra high fidelity (uh-fidelity) population transfer on a 3-level quantum system in lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we use the lewis-riesenfeld (l-r) method to derive a family of solutions leading to an exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the l-r invariant. Among this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to control simultaneously the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We define a measure of the robustness of an uh-fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which the infidelity rises above $10^{-4}$. The robustness of our shaped pulses is found superior to that of gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.
polished: We designed single-shot shaped pulses to achieve ultra-high-fidelity (UH-fidelity) population transfer in a three-level quantum system with a lambda configuration.
