In our analysis of MRM's effect on mortality, we developed a more precisely matched control group and obtained a 95% confidence interval encompassing substantial adverse effects, no effect, and minor beneficial effects.

original: When constructing models to summarize clinical data to be used for simulations, it is good practice to evaluate the models for their capacity to reproduce the data. This can be done by means of visual predictive checks (vpc), which consist of (1) several reproductions of the original study by simulation from the model under evaluation, (2) calculating estimates of interest for each simulated study and (3) comparing the distribution of those estimates with the estimate from the original study. This procedure is a generic method that is straightforward to apply, in general. Here we consider the application of the method to time to event data and consider the special case when a time-varying covariate is not known or cannot be approximated after event time.
polished: When developing models to summarize clinical data for simulation purposes, it is essential to assess their ability to accurately reproduce the original data. This evaluation can be performed using visual predictive checks (VPCs), which involve three key steps: (1) generating multiple simulated replicates of the original study using the model being evaluated, (2) computing relevant estimates for each simulated dataset, and (3) comparing the distribution of these simulated estimates with those from the original study. This approach serves as a versatile and generally straightforward validation method. In this context, we specifically examine its application to time-to-event data, with particular attention to cases where time-varying covariates are either unknown or cannot be reasonably estimated after the event occurs.

original: Novel concepts, perspectives and challenges in measuring and controlling an open quantum system via sequential schemes are shown. We discuss how similar protocols, relying both on repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, can allow to: (i) confine and protect quantum dynamics from decoherence in accordance with the zeno physics. (ii) analytically predict the probability that a quantum system is transferred into a target quantum state by means of stochastic sequential measurements. (iii) optimally reconstruct the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalizing in the frequency domain the filter functions driving the designed quantum-sensor. The achievement of these tasks will enhance our capability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, thus bringing advances to quantum science and technologies.
polished: Novel concepts, perspectives, and challenges in measuring and controlling open quantum systems through sequential schemes are presented. We examine how analogous protocols, combining repeated quantum measurements with dynamical decoupling control pulses, enable: (i) the confinement and protection of quantum dynamics from decoherence, consistent with Zeno physics; (ii) the analytical prediction of quantum state transfer probabilities via stochastic sequential measurements; and (iii) the optimal reconstruction of environmental noise spectral densities by orthogonalizing frequency-domain filter functions in designed quantum sensors. Accomplishing these objectives will significantly improve our ability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, thereby advancing quantum science and technologies.

original: Palms sweaty, heart racing, stomach in knots. You can't cry for help. Not only is your throat too tight to breathe, but it'd be so embarrassing. No, you aren't being stalked by a monster, you're speaking in public, a fate some deem worse than death.see, when you're dead, you feel nothing; at a podium, you feel stage fright. But at some point we've all had to communicate in front of people, so you have to try and overcome it.to start, understand what stage fright is. Humans, social animals that we are, are wired to worry about reputation. Public speaking can threaten it. Before a speech, you fret, "what if people think i'm awful and i'm an idiot?"
polished:
Your palms sweat, your heart races, and your stomach twists into knots. You can’t call for help—not only is your throat too tight to breathe, but the humiliation would be unbearable. No, you aren’t being hunted by a monster; you’re speaking in public, a fate some consider worse than death. After all, when you’re dead, you feel nothing—but at a podium, you feel every ounce of stage fright. Yet at some point, we’ve all had to address a crowd, so you must learn to push through it.  

Start by understanding stage fright. As social creatures, humans are hardwired to care about reputation, and public speaking puts yours on the line. Before a speech, your mind spirals: *What if they think I’m terrible? What if they see me as a fool?*

original: I can't think of anyone who just has one interest in life, and that's all they want to do for the rest of their life. [the way we work]around 15 percent of american workers don't have traditional full-time jobs. They're half-time, part-time, contract workers or temps. The term "side hustle" just seems to fit with this ethos where people are putting together a few different things to make a living.the word "side hustle" has its roots in popular african american newspapers. In the 1920s, these papers used the word "hustle" to refer to some kind of scam. By the 1950s, they were using "side hustle" to refer to legitimate work, too. A side hustle is a little different than a second job. A second job is about necessity.
polished:
It’s rare to find someone with just one interest in life, content to pursue only that for the rest of their days. [The way we work] Approximately 15 percent of American workers don’t hold traditional full-time jobs—they’re part-time, contract workers, or temps. The term "side hustle" aligns perfectly with this ethos, capturing how people piece together multiple pursuits to earn a living.  

The phrase "side hustle" traces its origins to popular African American newspapers. In the 1920s, "hustle" often referred to a scam, but by the 1950s, "side hustle" had evolved to include legitimate work. Unlike a second job, which is often driven by necessity, a side hustle reflects a more intentional and varied approach to making ends meet.

original: Two twin domes, two radically opposed design cultures. One is made of thousands of steel parts, the other of a single silk thread. One is synthetic, the other organic. One is imposed on the environment, the other creates it. One is designed for nature, the other is designed by her.michelangelo said that when he looked at raw marble, he saw a figure struggling to be free. The chisel was michelangelo's only tool. But living things are not chiseled. They grow. And in our smallest units of life, our cells, we carry all the information that's required for every other cell to function and to replicate.tools also have consequences. At least since the industrial revolution, the world of design has been dominated by the rigors of manufacturing and mass production.
polished:
Two twin domes, two radically contrasting design philosophies. One is constructed from countless steel components, the other woven from a single silk thread. One is synthetic, the other natural. One imposes itself upon the environment, the other emerges from it. One is designed for nature, the other is nature’s own design.  

Michelangelo once remarked that within raw marble, he glimpsed a figure yearning to break free. His chisel was his sole instrument. Yet living beings are not carved—they evolve. Within our most fundamental units of life, our cells, lies the complete blueprint for every function and replication.  

Tools, too, leave their mark. Since the dawn of the Industrial Revolution, the realm of design has been shaped by the demands of manufacturing and mass production.

original: Hello. My name is simone. You know how people tell you if you get nervous when onstage, picture people in the audience naked? like it's this thing that's supposed to make you feel better. But i was thinking — picturing all of you naked in 2018 feels kind of weird and wrong. Like, we're working really hard on moving past stuff like that, so we need a new method of dealing with if you get nervous onstage. And i realized that what i'd really like is that i can look at you as much as you're looking at me — just to even things out a little bit. So if i had way more eyeballs, then we'd all be really comfortable, right?
polished: Hello. My name is Simone. You’ve probably heard the advice that if you’re nervous onstage, you should picture the audience naked—supposedly to make you feel better. But honestly, imagining all of you naked in 2018 feels a bit odd and outdated. We’re trying to move past that kind of thinking, so we need a better way to handle stage fright. Here’s what occurred to me: I’d love to look at you just as much as you’re looking at me—to balance things out. So really, if I had a lot more eyeballs, we’d all be perfectly comfortable, wouldn’t we?

original: "to do two things at once is to do neither." it's a great smackdown of multitasking, isn't it, often attributed to the roman writer publilius syrus, although you know how these things are, he probably never said it. What i'm interested in, though, is — is it true? i mean, it's obviously true for emailing at the dinner table or texting while driving or possibly for live tweeting at ted talk, as well. But i'd like to argue that for an important kind of activity, doing two things at once — or three or even four — is exactly what we should be aiming for.look no further than albert einstein. In 1905, he published four remarkable scientific papers.
polished: To attempt two things at once is to accomplish neither." This biting critique of multitasking—often credited to the Roman writer Publilius Syrus, though such attributions are notoriously unreliable—raises an intriguing question: Is it accurate? Certainly, it holds true for checking emails at dinner, texting while driving, or perhaps live-tweeting during a TED Talk. Yet I’d contend that for certain meaningful endeavors, pursuing two, three, or even four tasks simultaneously is precisely the ideal. Consider Albert Einstein: in 1905 alone, he published four groundbreaking scientific papers.

original: I know this is going to sound strange, but i think robots can inspire us to be better humans. See, i grew up in bethlehem, pennsylvania, the home of bethlehem steel. My father was an engineer, and when i was growing up, he would teach me how things worked. We would build projects together, like model rockets and slot cars. Here's the go-kart that we built together. That's me behind the wheel, with my sister and my best friend at the time. And one day, he came home, when i was about 10 years old, and at the dinner table, he announced that for our next project, we were going to build ... A robot.a robot.
polished: I know this may sound unusual, but I believe robots can inspire us to become better versions of ourselves. You see, I grew up in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania—the home of Bethlehem Steel. My father was an engineer, and during my childhood, he taught me how things worked. We often collaborated on projects, from model rockets to slot cars. This is the go-kart we built together—there I am behind the wheel, with my sister and my best friend at the time. Then one evening, when I was around ten years old, my father came home and made an announcement at the dinner table: for our next project, we were going to build...a robot. A robot.

original: Sustainability represents the what, the where and the how of what is caught. The who and the why are what's important to me. I want to know the people behind my dinner choices. I want to know how i impact them. I want to know how they impact me. I want to know why they fish. I want to know how they rely on the water's bounty for their living. Understanding all of this enables us to shift our perception of seafood away from a commodity to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. It allows for us to celebrate the seafood that we're also so fortunate to eat.so what do we call this? i think we call it restorative seafood. Where sustainability is the capacity to endure and maintain, restorative is the ability to replenish and progress.
polished: Sustainability defines the what, where, and how of what is harvested—but the who and why matter most to me. I want to know the individuals behind my meals, understand how my choices affect them, and how their lives intersect with mine. I want to learn why they fish and how they depend on the ocean’s abundance for their livelihood. Grasping these connections transforms seafood from a mere commodity into a chance to heal our ecosystems. It lets us appreciate the food we’re privileged to enjoy. So what do we name this? I believe we call it restorative seafood. While sustainability focuses on endurance and preservation, restoration embodies renewal and advancement.

original: The starving orphan seeking a second helping of gruel. The spinster wasting away in her tattered wedding dress. The stone-hearted miser plagued by the ghost of christmas past. More than a century after his death, these remain recognizable figures from the work of charles dickens. So striking is his body of work that it gave rise to its own adjective. But what are the features of dickens's writing that make it so special?dickens’s fiction brims with anticipation through brooding settings, plot twists, and mysteries. These features of his work kept his audience wanting more. When first published, his stories were serialized, meaning they were released a few chapters at a time in affordable literary journals and only later reprinted as books.
polished: The starving orphan pleading for a second portion of gruel. The lonely spinster fading away in her threadbare wedding gown. The cold-hearted miser tormented by the specter of Christmas past. Even a century after his passing, these remain indelible figures from the works of Charles Dickens. So powerful is his literary legacy that it spawned its own descriptive term. Yet what distinguishes Dickens's writing as truly extraordinary? His fiction overflows with suspense, crafted through atmospheric settings, unexpected turns, and enigmatic plots. These signature elements left readers yearning for each new installment. Originally, his tales appeared in serialized form—published chapter by chapter in inexpensive periodicals before being compiled into volumes.

original: Shah rukh khan: courage, determination, and a single-minded vision. These are the qualities the biggest achievers have in common. These are those brave hearts for whom failure is not an option. What looks to us an unconquerable sea, to our next speaker is an irresistible stage she was born to perform on. So let's dive straight into the story of our fearless speaker, bhakti sharma, who's making waves in the world of long-distance swimming. Bhakti sharma. (applause)bhakti sharma: imagine, in the scorching rajasthan heat, on a hot summer afternoon, a two-and-a-half-year-old riding on a moped behind her mom, not knowing where they were headed. And 20 minutes later, that two-and-a-half-year-old finds herself completely submerged in water.
polished:
**Shah Rukh Khan:** Courage, determination, and an unwavering vision—these are the defining traits of history’s greatest achievers. These are the fearless souls for whom failure is never an option. What may seem to us like an insurmountable ocean is, to our next speaker, nothing more than the stage she was destined to command. So without further delay, let’s immerse ourselves in the inspiring journey of Bhakti Sharma, a trailblazer in the world of long-distance swimming. Bhakti Sharma. *(Applause)*  

**Bhakti Sharma:** Picture this—a scorching summer afternoon in Rajasthan, where a two-and-a-half-year-old clings to her mother on a moped, oblivious to their destination. Twenty minutes later, that same child finds herself plunged into the depths of water, her life forever changed.

original: I'm going to talk about a technology that we're developing at oxford now, that we think is going to change the way that computer games and hollywood movies are being made. That technology is simulating humans. It's simulated humans with a simulated body and a simulated nervous system to control that body. Now, before i talk more about that technology, let's have a quick look at what human characters look like at the moment in computer games. This is a clip from a game called "grand theft auto 3." we already saw that briefly yesterday. And what you can see is — it is actually a very good game. It's one of the most successful games of all time.
polished: I'd like to discuss a groundbreaking technology currently under development at Oxford that we believe will revolutionize how computer games and Hollywood films are created. This innovation involves simulating humans - complete with virtual bodies and nervous systems to control them. Before delving deeper into this technology, let's briefly examine how human characters are currently portrayed in video games. Here's a clip from 'Grand Theft Auto 3,' which we glimpsed yesterday. While this is actually an excellent game - one of the most successful titles of all time - it demonstrates the current state of digital human representation.

original: Like a lot of people around the world, earlier this summer my friends and i were obsessed with the women's world cup held in france. Here we are, watching these incredible athletes, the goals were amazing, the games were clean and engaging, and at the same time, outside the field, these women are talking about equal pay, and in the case of some countries, any pay at all for their sport. So because we were mildly obsessed, we wanted to watch the games live, and we decided that one of the spanish-speaking networks in the us was the best place for us to start. And it wasn't until a few games into the tournament that a friend of mine talks to me and says, "why does it feel like everything i'm seeing is commercials for makeup and household cleaning products and diets?
polished:
Like many people worldwide, earlier this summer my friends and I became captivated by the Women's World Cup in France. As we watched these extraordinary athletes compete—marveling at their stunning goals and the clean, engaging matches—we simultaneously learned about their off-field battles for equal pay, or in some cases, any pay at all for their sport.  

Our growing enthusiasm led us to seek out live broadcasts, and we settled on a Spanish-language network in the U.S. as our preferred viewing option. However, it wasn’t until several games into the tournament that a friend turned to me and remarked, *"Why does it feel like every ad break is just commercials for makeup, cleaning products, and weight-loss programs?"*

original: I want to tell you about the future of money. Let's start with a story about this culture that lived in micronesia in the early 1900s, called the yap. Now, i want to tell you about the yap because their form of money is really interesting. They use these limestone discs called rai stones. Now, the yap don't actually move these rai stones around or exchange them the way we do with our coins, because rai stones can get to be pretty massive. The largest is about four tons and 12 feet across. So the yap just keep track of who owns part of what stone.there's a story about these sailors that were transporting a stone across the ocean when they ran into some trouble and the stone actually fell in.
polished: Let me share with you a fascinating perspective on the future of money. Our story begins with the Yap people, a Micronesian culture from the early 1900s, whose unique monetary system offers valuable insights. What makes the Yap particularly interesting is their currency: massive limestone discs known as rai stones. Unlike modern coins that change hands physically, these stones often remain stationary due to their enormous size—some reaching up to four tons and twelve feet in diameter. Instead of moving them, the Yap maintain an intricate system of ownership records for portions of each stone. There's even a legendary account of sailors transporting one such stone across the ocean when disaster struck, causing it to sink beneath the waves.

original: You’ve been accused of a crime you did not commit. It’s impossible to prove your innocence. If you insist that you’re innocent anyway, you’ll likely be found guilty and executed. But if you confess, apologize, and implicate others for good measure, you’ll go free. Do you give a false confession— or risk a public hanging?this was the choice facing those accused of witchcraft in the village of salem, massachusetts between february 1692 and may 1693. They were the victims of paranoia about the supernatural, misdirected religious fervor— and a justice system that valued repentance over truth.salem was settled in 1626 by puritans, a group of english protestants. Life was strict and isolated for the people of salem. Battles with their native american neighbors and groups of french settlers were commonplace.
polished:
You stand accused of a crime you did not commit. Proving your innocence is impossible. If you maintain your innocence, you’ll likely be convicted and face execution. But if you confess, express remorse, and name others, you’ll walk free. Do you falsely confess—or risk the gallows?  

This was the grim reality for those accused of witchcraft in Salem, Massachusetts, between February 1692 and May 1693. They fell victim to supernatural paranoia, misguided religious zeal—and a justice system that prized repentance over truth.  

Founded in 1626 by Puritans, English Protestants seeking religious purity, Salem was a place of rigid discipline and isolation. Conflicts with neighboring Native American tribes and French settlers were frequent, shaping a tense and fearful community.

original: There are currently hundreds of thousands of people on transplant lists, waiting for critical organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers that could save their lives. Unfortunately, there aren’t nearly enough donor organs available to fill that demand.what if instead of waiting, we could create brand-new, customized organs from scratch? that’s the idea behind bioprinting, a branch of regenerative medicine currently under development. We’re not able to print complex organs just yet, but simpler tissues including blood vessels and tubes responsible for nutrient and waste exchange are already in our grasp.bioprinting is a biological cousin of 3-d printing, a technique that deposits layers of material on top of each other to construct a three-dimensional object one slice at a time.
polished: Currently, hundreds of thousands of individuals remain on transplant lists, awaiting life-saving organs such as kidneys, hearts, and livers. Sadly, the supply of donor organs falls far short of meeting this urgent need. But what if, rather than waiting, we could engineer entirely new, personalized organs from the ground up? This is the vision driving bioprinting—an emerging field within regenerative medicine. While we cannot yet produce fully functional complex organs, we have already succeeded in fabricating simpler tissues, including blood vessels and nutrient-exchange conduits. Bioprinting operates on principles similar to 3D printing, building three-dimensional structures layer by layer—only instead of synthetic materials, it uses biological components.

original: Good afternoon, i'm proud to be here at tedxkrakow. I'll try to speak a little bit today about a phenomenon which can, and actually is changing the world, and whose name is people power. I'll start with an anecdote, or for those of you who are monty python lovers, a monty python type of sketch. Here it is.it is december 15, 2010. Somebody gives you a bet: you will look at a crystal ball, and you will see the future; the future will be accurate. But you need to share it with the world. Ok, curiosity killed the cat, you take the bet, you look at the crystal ball. One hour later, you're sitting in a building of the national tv, in a top show, and you tell the story.
polished:
Good afternoon, I'm honored to be here at TEDxKrakow. Today, I'd like to discuss a phenomenon that can—and indeed already is—changing the world: the power of people. I'll begin with an anecdote, or for Monty Python enthusiasts among you, a sketch reminiscent of their style.  

Here's the scene: It's December 15, 2010. Someone offers you a wager—you’ll gaze into a crystal ball and see the future, a future that will prove entirely accurate. But there’s a catch: you must share this vision with the world. Intrigued, you accept the bet and peer into the crystal ball. One hour later, you find yourself in the studio of a national television network, appearing on a flagship program, recounting what you’ve seen.

original: We're going to begin in 1964. Bob dylan is 23 years old, and his career is just reaching its pinnacle. He's been christened the voice of a generation, and he's churning out classic songs at a seemingly impossible rate, but there's a small minority of dissenters, and they claim that bob dylan is stealing other people's songs.2004. Brian burton, aka danger mouse, takes the beatles' "white album," combines it with jay-z's "the black album" to create "the grey album." "the grey album" becomes an immediate sensation online, and the beatles' record company sends out countless cease-and-desist letters for "unfair competition and dilution of our valuable property. "now, "the grey album" is a remix.
polished:
We begin in 1964. Bob Dylan, then 23 years old, stands at the peak of his burgeoning career. Hailed as the voice of a generation, he produces timeless songs at an astonishing pace. Yet a small but vocal minority accuses him of appropriating others' musical work.  

Fast forward to 2004. Brian Burton, known as Danger Mouse, merges The Beatles' *White Album* with Jay-Z's *The Black Album*, crafting *The Grey Album*. This remix quickly becomes an online phenomenon, only to draw relentless cease-and-desist orders from The Beatles' label, citing "unfair competition and dilution of our intellectual property." Here, too, the work in question is a remix.

original: Well, that's kind of an obvious statement up there. I started with that sentence about 12 years ago, and i started in the context of developing countries, but you're sitting here from every corner of the world. So if you think of a map of your country, i think you'll realize that for every country on earth, you could draw little circles to say, "these are places where good teachers won't go." on top of that, those are the places from where trouble comes. So we have an ironic problem — good teachers don't want to go to just those places where they're needed the most.i started in 1999 to try and address this problem with an experiment, which was a very simple experiment in new delhi.
polished: That’s a rather evident observation above. I began with that statement roughly twelve years ago, initially focusing on developing nations. Yet today, you’re gathered here from across the globe. Picture a map of your own country—you’d likely recognize that for every nation on Earth, you could mark small circles and note, 'These are areas where skilled teachers refuse to work.' Moreover, these very places often become sources of societal challenges. This presents a paradoxical dilemma: the educators we need most are the least willing to serve in these critical areas. In 1999, I launched an experiment in New Delhi—a modest initiative—to tackle this very issue.

original: Currently, most refugees live in the cities rather than in the refugee camps. We represent over 60 percent of the number of refugees globally. With the majority of refugees living in urban areas, there is a strong need for a paradigm shift and new thinking. Rather than wasting money on building walls, it would be better to spend on programs to help refugees to help themselves. (applause)we always have to leave behind all our possessions. But not our skills and knowledge. If allowed to live a productive life, refugees can help themselves and contribute to the development of their host country.i was born in the city called bukavu, south kivu, in the democratic republic of congo. I am the fifth-born in a family of 12 children.
polished:
Currently, the majority of refugees reside in urban areas rather than in refugee camps. We account for over 60 percent of the global refugee population. Given this reality, there is an urgent need for a paradigm shift and innovative approaches. Instead of squandering resources on building barriers, it would be far more effective to invest in programs that empower refugees to become self-sufficient. (Applause) While we are often forced to leave behind our material possessions, we retain our skills and knowledge. When given the opportunity to lead productive lives, refugees can not only support themselves but also contribute meaningfully to their host countries.  

I was born in Bukavu, a city in South Kivu, within the Democratic Republic of Congo. As the fifth-born in a family of twelve children, my early experiences shaped my perspective on resilience and community.

original: I have two questions for you. One: whose shoulders do you stand on? and two: what do you stand for? these are two questions that i always begin my poetry workshops with students because at times, poetry can seem like this dead art form for old white men who just seem like they were born to be old, like, you know, benjamin button or something. And i ask my students these two questions, and then i share how i answer them, which is in these three sentences that go: i am the daughter of black writers, who are descended from freedom fighters who broke their chains and changed the world. They call me. And these are words i repeat in a mantra before every single poetry performance. In fact, i was doing it in the corner over there. I was making faces.
polished:
I have two questions for you. First: Whose shoulders do you stand on? And second: What do you stand for? These are the questions I always open my poetry workshops with because, too often, poetry can feel like a relic—an art form reserved for old white men who seem as though they were born aged, like some Benjamin Button paradox. I pose these questions to my students, then share how I answer them—in three lines I return to like a refrain:  

*I am the daughter of Black writers,*  
*who are descended from freedom fighters*  
*who broke their chains and changed the world.*  

They call me.  

I whisper these words like a mantra before every poetry performance. Even today, I was murmuring them in the corner over there—making faces, lost in the rhythm.

original: (breathes in)(breathes out)so, i didn't always make my living from music. For about the five years after graduating from an upstanding liberal arts university, this was my day job. (laughter)i was a self-employed living statue called the eight-foot bride, and i love telling people i did this for a job, because everybody always wants to know, who are these freaks in real life. (laughter)hello.i painted myself white one day, stood on a box, put a hat or a can at my feet, and when someone came by and dropped in money, i handed them a flower — and some intense eye contact. And if they didn't take the flower, i threw in a gesture of sadness and longing — as they walked away.
polished:
*(Inhales deeply, exhales slowly)* So, I haven’t always made my living through music. For roughly five years after graduating from a respected liberal arts university, this was my daily routine. *(Chuckles)* I worked as a self-employed living statue—the "Eight-Foot Bride"—and I adore sharing this part of my past because, inevitably, people always wonder: *Who are these peculiar souls in real life?* *(Laughs softly)*  

Here’s how it went: I’d paint myself white, step onto a pedestal, place a hat or a can at my feet, and whenever someone dropped in a coin, I’d offer them a flower—along with a piercing gaze. And if they declined the flower? I’d linger with a wistful, longing gesture as they walked away.

original: On october 4, 1957, the world watched in awe and fear as the soviet union launched sputnik, the world's first man-made satellite, into space. This little metal ball, smaller than two feet in diameter, launched a space race between the u.s. And u.s.s.r. That would last for eighteen years and change the world as we know it. Sputnik was actually not the first piece of human technology to enter space. That superlative goes to the v-2 rocket used by germany in missile attacks against allied cities as a last-ditch effort in the final years of world war ii. It wasn't very effective, but, at the end of the war, both the u.s. And u.s.s.r. Had captured the technology and the scientists that had developed it and began using them for their own projects.
polished: On October 4, 1957, the world watched in awe and apprehension as the Soviet Union launched Sputnik, humanity's first artificial satellite, into orbit. This modest metal sphere, measuring less than two feet in diameter, ignited an intense space race between the U.S. and U.S.S.R. that would span eighteen years and reshape global history. Though Sputnik marked a pivotal milestone, it was not technically the first human-made object to reach space. That distinction belongs to Germany's V-2 rocket, deployed in desperate missile strikes against Allied cities during the final stages of World War II. While militarily ineffective, this technology—along with the scientists who created it—was seized by both American and Soviet forces after the war, laying the foundation for their respective space programs.

original: I am a cultural omnivore, one whose daily commute is made possible by attachment to an ipod — an ipod that contains wagner and mozart, pop diva christina aguilera, country singer josh turner, gangsta rap artist kirk franklin, concerti, symphonies and more and more. I'm a voracious reader, a reader who deals with ian mcewan down to stephanie meyer. I have read the twilight tetralogy. And one who lives for my home theater, a home theater where i devour dvds, video on demand and a lot of television. For me, "law & order: svu," tina fey and "30 rock" and "judge judy" — "the people are real, the cases are real, the rulings are final.
polished: I am a cultural omnivore whose daily commute is soundtracked by my trusty iPod—an iPod stocked with everything from Wagner and Mozart to pop diva Christina Aguilera, country crooner Josh Turner, gospel hip-hop artist Kirk Franklin, concertos, symphonies, and beyond. I’m also an insatiable reader, equally at home with Ian McEwan as I am with Stephanie Meyer—yes, I’ve even read the entire *Twilight* saga. And then there’s my home theater, where I indulge in a steady diet of DVDs, on-demand streaming, and binge-worthy TV. For me, it’s *Law & Order: SVU*, Tina Fey’s *30 Rock*, and the no-nonsense justice of *Judge Judy*—where "the people are real, the cases are real, the rulings are final.

original: [citizens of the world][we face a global crisis of unprecedented scale][please stand by for a message from ... ][the secretary-general of the united nations antónio guterres]the climate emergency is the defining crisis of our time. We are in a race against time, and we are losing. There is a growing tide of impatience, especially among young people, with global inaction. We need more ambition from all: governments, cities, businesses, investors and people everywhere. So i'm pleased you are launching ted countdown. Your influence and ideas can help accelerate momentum for a carbon-neutral world by 2050. That is the only way to avert the worst impacts of global heating. We have the tools, the science and the resources. Let us now get into this race with political will and energy.
polished:
Citizens of the world, we confront a global crisis of unparalleled magnitude. Please stand by for an urgent message from... the Secretary-General of the United Nations, António Guterres.  

The climate emergency represents the most critical challenge of our era. We are racing against time—and falling behind. Across the globe, frustration mounts, particularly among the youth, over insufficient action. Greater ambition is demanded from all: governments, cities, businesses, investors, and individuals alike.  

That is why I welcome the launch of TED Countdown. Your innovation and influence can propel us toward a carbon-neutral world by 2050—our only path to preventing the most catastrophic effects of climate change. The solutions exist: we possess the science, the tools, and the means. Now, we must channel political will and collective energy to rise to this challenge.

original: Menstruation. A simple word describing a natural biological process, weighed down by centuries of stigma, has been transformed into something most of us can only speak about in whispers. But why? as i speak to you right now, more than 800 million women around the world are having a period. None of us would exist without it, and yet it remains an "embarrassing" subject to broach. From my experience and that of the women around me, i can tell you that it's exhausting.it's exhausting to carefully take out a brown paper bag hiding a pad, stuffing it into your pocket in the middle of a class and rushing to the washroom as discreetly as possible. It's exhausting to sit through lessons and meetings pretending to be absolutely normal, while internally crying out from intense period cramps.
polished: Menstruation—a simple word describing a natural biological process—has been burdened by centuries of stigma, reduced to a topic many still discuss only in hushed tones. But why? As I speak to you now, over 800 million women worldwide are menstruating. None of us would exist without it, yet it remains an "awkward" or even "shameful" subject to raise. From my own experience and the stories of women around me, I can tell you it’s exhausting. Exhausting to carefully retrieve a pad hidden in a brown paper bag, tuck it into your pocket mid-lecture, and slip away to the restroom as inconspicuously as possible. Exhausting to sit through classes or meetings, outwardly composed while silently enduring the agony of cramps.

original: The world's largest and most devastating environmental and industrial project is situated in the heart of the largest and most intact forest in the world, canada's boreal forest. It stretches right across northern canada, in labrador, it's home to the largest remaining wild caribou herd in the world: the george river caribou herd, numbering approximately 400,000 animals. Unfortunately, when i was there, i couldn't find one of them, but you have the antlers as proof.all across the boreal, we're blessed with this incredible abundance of wetlands. Wetlands, globally, are one of the most endangered ecosystems. They're absolutely critical ecosystems, they clean air, they clean water, they sequester large amounts of greenhouse gases, and they're home to a huge diversity of species.
polished: The world's largest and most destructive environmental and industrial undertaking is located at the core of the planet's most extensive and pristine forest—Canada's boreal forest. Spanning northern Canada and extending into Labrador, this region shelters the world's last great wild caribou population: the George River herd, which once numbered around 400,000 animals. Though I failed to spot a single caribou during my visit, the antlers serve as tangible evidence of their presence. Throughout the boreal region, we're fortunate to host an extraordinary wealth of wetlands. Globally among the most threatened ecosystems, wetlands play a vital role—purifying air and water, storing significant quantities of greenhouse gases, and supporting an immense variety of wildlife.

original: Before the world of humans began, there was the world of the gods, made of fields, plains and gardens. Four brothers wandered this celestial realm. They had no family other than each other— they didn’t even know who their parents were. One of the brothers, deminan, looked different from the others. His skin was covered in painful scabs, and he wondered why he alone had been marked with this affliction.one day, while the supreme spirit yaya was out in his gardens, deminan and his brothers snuck into yaya’s house. After feasting and exploring, they spotted a giant gourd hanging in the corner. But as they tried to look inside the gourd, they dropped it.
polished: Before the world of humankind came into being, there existed the divine realm of the gods—a land of sprawling fields, open plains, and lush gardens. Four brothers roamed this celestial domain, bound only by their kinship, for they knew no other family, not even their own parents. Among them, Deminan stood apart, his skin marred by painful scabs, and he often pondered why he alone bore this cruel affliction. One day, while the supreme spirit Yaya tended his gardens, Deminan and his brothers stole into Yaya's dwelling. After indulging in food and exploration, they discovered an enormous gourd suspended in the corner. But as they attempted to peer inside, the gourd slipped from their grasp.

original: So, i had graduated seven years ago from berkeley with a dual degree in molecular and cell biology and linguistics, and i had gone to a career fair here on campus, where i'd gotten an interview with a start-up called theranos. And at the time, there wasn't really that much information about the company, but the little that was there was really impressive. Essentially, what the company was doing was creating a medical device where you would be able to run your entire blood panel on a finger-stick of blood. So you wouldn't have to get a big needle stuck in your arm in order to get your blood test done. So this was interesting not only because it was less painful, but also, it could potentially open the door to predictive diagnostics.
polished: Seven years ago, I graduated from Berkeley with dual degrees in molecular and cell biology and linguistics. At a career fair on campus, I secured an interview with a startup called Theranos. Back then, there wasn’t much publicly available information about the company, but what little existed was genuinely impressive. Essentially, Theranos was developing a medical device capable of running a full blood panel using just a finger-stick sample. This innovation was compelling not only because it minimized the discomfort of traditional blood draws but also because it held the potential to revolutionize predictive diagnostics.

original: My journey to become a polar specialist, photographing, specializing in the polar regions, began when i was four years old, when my family moved from southern canada to northern baffin island, up by greenland. There we lived with the inuit in the tiny inuit community of 200 inuit people, where [we] were one of three non-inuit families. And in this community, we didn't have a television; we didn't have computers, obviously, radio. We didn't even have a telephone. All of my time was spent outside with the inuit, playing. The snow and the ice were my sandbox, and the inuit were my teachers. And that's where i became truly obsessed with this polar realm.
polished: My journey to becoming a polar specialist—photographing and specializing in the polar regions—began when I was four years old, after my family moved from southern Canada to northern Baffin Island, near Greenland. There, we lived among the Inuit in a small community of just 200 people, where we were one of only three non-Inuit families. In this remote setting, we had no television, computers, or even a telephone; radio was our sole connection to the outside world. I spent nearly all my time outdoors with the Inuit, learning through play. The snow and ice became my sandbox, and the Inuit, my teachers. It was there that my deep fascination with the polar world truly took root.

original: We're seen as the organization that is the bucket for failed social policy. I can't define who comes to us or how long they stay. We get the people for whom nothing else has worked, people who have fallen through all of the other social safety nets. They can't contain them, so we must. That's our job: contain them, control them.over the years, as a prison system, as a nation, and as a society, we've become very good at that, but that shouldn't make you happy. Today we incarcerate more people per capita than any other country in the world. We have more black men in prison today than were under slavery in 1850.
polished: We are perceived as the institution that catches the fallout of failed social policies. I cannot determine who arrives at our doors or the duration of their stay. We receive those for whom every other solution has fallen short—individuals who have slipped through every remaining safety net. When other systems cannot manage them, we must. Our role is to contain and control them. Over time, as a prison system, a nation, and a society, we have grown exceedingly proficient at this—but that is no cause for pride. Today, we imprison more people per capita than any other nation on earth. There are now more Black men incarcerated than were enslaved in 1850.

original: I'd like to take you on the epic quest of the rosetta spacecraft. To escort and land the probe on a comet, this has been my passion for the past two years. In order to do that, i need to explain to you something about the origin of the solar system.when we go back four and a half billion years, there was a cloud of gas and dust. In the center of this cloud, our sun formed and ignited. Along with that, what we now know as planets, comets and asteroids formed. What then happened, according to theory, is that when the earth had cooled down a bit after its formation, comets massively impacted the earth and delivered water to earth. They probably also delivered complex organic material to earth, and that may have bootstrapped the emergence of life.
polished:
I'd like to take you on the remarkable journey of the Rosetta spacecraft—to guide and land this probe on a comet has been my passion for the past two years. To fully appreciate this mission, we must first understand something fundamental about the origins of our solar system.  

Rewind four and a half billion years, and you'd find a vast cloud of gas and dust. At its center, our Sun ignited into existence, while the surrounding material coalesced into what we now recognize as planets, comets, and asteroids. According to prevailing theories, once Earth had cooled somewhat after its formation, comets bombarded our planet in tremendous numbers, delivering water—and possibly even the complex organic molecules that may have jump-started the emergence of life.

original: Chris anderson: hello, ted community, welcome back for another live conversation. It's a big one today, as big as they get. You know, when we created this "build back better" series our thought was how could we address issues arising out of the pandemic, how could we imagine building back from that. But the events of this past week, the horrific death of george floyd and the daily protests that have followed, i mean, they provided a new urgency which we, of course, simply have to address. I mean, can we build back better from this? i think before we can even start to answer that question, we just have to seek to understand the immensity of this moment.whitney pennington rodgers: that's right, chris.
polished:
Chris Anderson: Hello, TED community, and welcome back to another live conversation. Today’s discussion is monumental—as significant as they come. When we launched this "Build Back Better" series, our focus was on addressing the challenges emerging from the pandemic and envisioning how to recover from it. But the events of this past week—the tragic death of George Floyd and the ongoing protests—have introduced a new urgency, one we absolutely must confront. Can we truly build back better from this? Before we even attempt to answer that question, we must first strive to grasp the profound gravity of this moment.  

Whitney Pennington Rodgers: That’s right, Chris.

original: In 1903, the president of the united states took a three-day camping trip in california’s yosemite valley. President theodore roosevelt slept in a grove of towering sequoia trees, camped in a snowstorm, and spent hours talking around the campfire with his host and guide, conservationist john muir. Roosevelt famously loved the outdoors, but muir had invited him there for more than just camping: yosemite was in danger.though yosemite became protected land in 1864, the valley was still at risk for overdevelopment in 1903. It was at the heart of a decades-old struggle to set aside land for both preservation and public use— two goals that were much easier said than done.the battle over yosemite began with the 1849 gold rush, when miners surged west, seeking gold in the sierra nevada foothills.
polished: In 1903, the President of the United States embarked on a three-day camping expedition in California’s Yosemite Valley. President Theodore Roosevelt slept beneath a canopy of towering sequoias, weathered a snowstorm during his stay, and spent long evenings conversing by the campfire with his host and guide, the renowned conservationist John Muir. While Roosevelt was famously passionate about the outdoors, Muir’s invitation extended beyond mere recreation—Yosemite was under threat. Although the valley had been designated as protected land in 1864, by 1903 it still faced the peril of overdevelopment. This struggle was central to a decades-long effort to preserve land for both conservation and public enjoyment—two ideals far more challenging to achieve than to proclaim. The conflict over Yosemite’s fate traces back to the 1849 Gold Rush, when prospectors flooded westward, scouring the Sierra Nevada foothills for gold.

original: Hello. This is my first trip, first time in life i'm outside of the walls of gaza. I'm so happy to be here. (applause)my ambition always was to be a pilot, to fly a plane, to feel free to fly the sky, to touch the sky. But that didn't happen. Simply, i live in gaza, there is no airport. All borders are closed on every side. We live in one of the biggest prisons in the world. The only thing i can do is just to look up to the sky. On some days, we are lucky if we have electricity for four or five hours. When it's cold, we make a fire on the front or on the roof of our homes.
polished: Hello. This is my first trip—the first time in my life I’ve stepped beyond the walls of Gaza. I’m overwhelmed with joy to be here. (Applause) My dream has always been to become a pilot, to soar through the skies, to feel the freedom of flight, to touch the heavens. Yet, that dream remains out of reach. The reality is, I live in Gaza, where there is no airport, and every border is sealed shut. We exist in what feels like one of the world’s largest prisons. All I can do is gaze up at the sky. Some days, we’re fortunate to have electricity for just four or five hours. When the cold sets in, we gather around fires lit outside our homes or on the rooftops.

original: I am sorry i cannot show you my face, because if i do, the bad guys will come for me.my journey started 14 years ago. I was a young reporter. I had just come out of college.then i got a scoop. The scoop was quite a very simple story. Police officers were taking bribes from hawkers who were hawking on the streets. As a young reporter, i thought that i should do it in a different way, so that it has a maximum impact, since everybody knew that it was happening, and yet there was nothing that was keeping it out of the system.so i decided to go there and act as a seller. As part of selling, i was able to document the hard core evidence. The impact was great. It was fantastic.this was what many call immersion journalism, or undercover journalism.
polished: I’m sorry I can’t show you my face—if I do, the bad guys will come after me. My journey began 14 years ago when I was a young reporter fresh out of college. That’s when I got a scoop. The story itself was quite simple: police officers were taking bribes from street vendors. As an eager journalist, I wanted to cover it differently to maximize its impact. Everyone knew it was happening, yet nothing was being done to stop it. So I decided to go undercover as a vendor myself. While pretending to sell goods, I gathered solid evidence. The impact was tremendous—absolutely fantastic. This is what many refer to as immersion journalism or undercover reporting.

original: One simple vitamin can reduce your risk of heart disease.eating chocolate reduces stress in students.new drug prolongs lives of patients with rare disease.health headlines like these are published every day, sometimes making opposite claims from each other. There can be a disconnect between broad, attention-grabbing headlines and the often specific, incremental results of the medical research they cover. So how can you avoid being misled by grabby headlines?the best way to assess a headline’s credibility is to look at the original research it reports on. We’ve come up with a hypothetical research scenario for each of these three headlines.keep watching for the explanation of the first example; then pause at the headline to answer the question. These are simplified scenarios.
polished: A single vitamin could lower your risk of heart disease. Chocolate consumption eases stress in students. A breakthrough drug extends lives for patients with a rare condition. Health headlines like these flood the media daily, often contradicting one another. There’s often a gap between flashy, attention-grabbing headlines and the nuanced, incremental findings of the actual medical studies they reference. So how can you avoid falling for misleading headlines? The most reliable approach is to examine the original research behind the claims. We’ve created hypothetical research scenarios for each of these three headlines. Stay tuned for the breakdown of the first example—then pause at the headline to test your understanding. These scenarios are simplified for clarity.

original: So, when i was 14, my family was in the process of adopting my little brothers from ethiopia. And one day my mom asked, "what day should we put for their birthday?" "uh, the day they were born, obviously?" ridiculous question. And then my mom said, "well, kristen, neither of your little brothers have a birth certificate, so how do you suggest we find out when that was?" mind blown. Now, 20 years later, i'm still working on it, except instead of trying to solve the mystery of my brothers' missing birth certificates, i try to solve this problem globally.so what do birth certificates have to do with international development?
polished:
When I was 14, my family was in the process of adopting my younger brothers from Ethiopia. One day, my mom asked, "What date should we list as their birthday?" I replied, "Uh, the day they were born, obviously?" It seemed like a ridiculous question—until she explained, "Well, Kristen, neither of your brothers has a birth certificate, so how do you suggest we find out when that was?" My mind was blown.  

Now, 20 years later, I’m still working on this issue—except instead of solving the mystery of my brothers’ missing birth certificates, I’m tackling the problem on a global scale. So, what do birth certificates have to do with international development?

original: Imagine if you could plug your brain into a machine that would bring you ultimate pleasure for the rest of your life. If you were given the choice to sign up for that kind of existence, would you? that's the question philosopher robert nozick posed through a thought experiment he called the experience machine. The experiment asks us to consider a world in which scientists have developed a machine that would simulate real life while guaranteeing experiences of only pleasure and never pain. The catch? you have to permanently leave reality behind, but you'll hardly know the difference. Your experiences will be indistinguishable from reality. Life's natural ups and downs will just be replaced with an endless series of ups. Sounds great, right?
polished: Imagine being able to connect your mind to a device offering boundless, everlasting pleasure. If presented with the opportunity to embrace such an existence, would you accept? This is the profound dilemma philosopher Robert Nozick explored through his renowned thought experiment, "The Experience Machine." The scenario invites us to envision a world where scientists have created a simulation indistinguishable from reality—one that delivers only joy and eliminates all suffering. There’s just one condition: you must abandon the real world forever, though the transition would feel seamless. Within this artificial paradise, life’s unpredictable highs and lows would vanish, replaced by an unbroken stream of euphoria. Tempting, isn’t it?

original: I would like to tell you about the most embarrassing thing that has ever happened to me in my years of working as a palliative care physician. This happened a couple of years ago. I was asked as a consultant to see a woman in her 70s — retired english professor who had pancreatic cancer. I was asked to see her because she had pain, nausea, vomiting ... When i went to see her, we talked about those symptoms and in the course of that consultation, she asked me whether i thought that medical marijuana might help her. I thought back to everything that i had learned in medical school about medical marijuana, which didn't take very long because i had learned absolutely nothing.
polished: I'd like to share the most embarrassing moment from my years as a palliative care physician. This occurred several years ago when I was consulted about a woman in her seventies—a retired English professor with pancreatic cancer. She was experiencing pain, nausea, and vomiting. During our consultation, while discussing these symptoms, she asked if I thought medical marijuana might help her. I reflected on everything I'd learned about medical marijuana in medical school—which didn't take long, because I'd learned absolutely nothing.

original: For the past 24 years, i have been a firefighter in huntington, west virginia. As firefighters, my team and i are tasked with saving lives and property from such disasters as car wrecks, house fires and also life-threatening medical emergencies. I am a woman leading a department in a male-dominated profession.and 10 years ago, i decided to increase my medical knowledge and i received a nursing degree. That was because it became clear that the next big threat facing not only my city, but other cities around the country, was not the one-and-done disaster, where you can ride in like the cavalry, as a firefighter, put out the fire and leave, feeling like you have made a difference and everything is ok.
polished: For the past 24 years, I have served as a firefighter in Huntington, West Virginia. My team and I are responsible for protecting lives and property from disasters such as car accidents, house fires, and life-threatening medical emergencies. As a woman leading a department in a male-dominated profession, I’ve faced unique challenges. A decade ago, I chose to expand my medical expertise by earning a nursing degree. This decision came from recognizing that the next major threat to my city—and communities nationwide—wasn’t the single, dramatic crisis where firefighters arrive, resolve the situation, and depart with a sense of accomplishment. Instead, it was the growing need for sustained medical care and preparedness.

original: Where does all the carbon we release go? carbon works in a natural cycle, present in all living things: in the soil, in the oceans, in the atmosphere and in rocks deep underground. When plants and other living things die, much of their stored carbon makes its way back to the atmosphere until new plants grow and reabsorb the carbon.but over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life becomes rock and some becomes fossil fuels: coal, oil and natural gas. Natural events like volcanic eruptions release some of the carbon trapped in rock. And human activities, like burning fossil fuels, also release some of that prehistoric carbon.today, humans release around 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet each year.
polished: Where does all the carbon we emit ultimately go? Carbon naturally cycles through ecosystems, existing in all living organisms, as well as in the soil, oceans, atmosphere, and even deep within Earth's rocky layers. When plants and other organisms die, much of their stored carbon gradually returns to the atmosphere, where it can be reabsorbed by new plant growth. However, over geological timescales spanning millions of years, portions of this carbon—originally stored in ancient forests and marine life—transform into sedimentary rock or fossil fuels like coal, oil, and natural gas. While natural processes such as volcanic activity release some of this sequestered carbon, human activities—particularly the combustion of fossil fuels—are now reintroducing vast quantities of this ancient carbon into the atmosphere. In fact, current human emissions exceed annual volcanic carbon releases by approximately sixtyfold.

original: Even nature's most disgusting creatures have important secrets, but who would want a swarm of cockroaches coming towards them?yet one of the greatest differences between natural and human technologies relates to robustness. Robust systems are stable in complex and new environments. Remarkably, cockroaches can self-stabilize running over rough terrain. When we put a jet pack on them, or give them a perturbation like an earthquake, we discovered that their wonderfully tuned legs allow them to self-stabilize without using any of their brainpower. They can go over complex terrain like grass, no problem, and not get destabilized. We discovered a new behavior where, because of their shape, they actually roll automatically to their side to go through this artificial test bit of grass.robust systems can perform multiple tasks with the same structure. Here's a new behavior we've discovered.
polished: Even nature’s most repulsive creatures hold vital secrets—but who would welcome a swarm of cockroaches advancing toward them? Yet one of the most striking contrasts between natural and human-made technologies lies in robustness. Robust systems remain stable in complex and unfamiliar environments. Astonishingly, cockroaches can self-stabilize while traversing uneven terrain. When fitted with a jet pack or subjected to disruptions like an earthquake, their exquisitely adapted legs enable them to maintain balance effortlessly, without relying on cognitive input. They navigate challenging landscapes, such as dense grass, with ease, never losing stability. We uncovered a novel behavior: their body shape allows them to roll automatically onto their side to maneuver through artificial grass obstacles. Robust systems can execute multiple functions using the same framework—and here, we’ve revealed yet another remarkable capability.

original: These are grim economic times, fellow tedsters, grim economic times indeed. And so, i would like to cheer you up with one of the great, albeit largely unknown, commercial success stories of the past 20 years. Comparable, in its own very peculiar way, to the achievements of microsoft or google. And it's an industry which has bucked the current recession with equanimity. I refer to organized crime.now organized crime has been around for a very long time, i hear you say, and these would be wise words, indeed. But in the last two decades, it has experienced an unprecedented expansion, now accounting for roughly 15 percent of the world's gdp. I like to call it the global shadow economy, or mcmafia, for short.so what triggered this extraordinary growth in cross-border crime?
polished:
These are undeniably grim economic times, my fellow TEDsters—grim indeed. Yet I’d like to lift your spirits by sharing one of the most remarkable, if largely overlooked, commercial success stories of the past two decades. In its own peculiar way, it rivals the achievements of giants like Microsoft or Google. Moreover, this is an industry that has weathered the current recession with remarkable composure. I’m speaking, of course, about organized crime.  

Now, you might argue that organized crime is nothing new—and you’d be absolutely right. But over the last 20 years, it has undergone an unprecedented expansion, now accounting for roughly 15 percent of global GDP. I like to refer to it as the global shadow economy—or, more succinctly, McMafia.  

So, what fueled this extraordinary surge in cross-border crime?

Here’s a list of problems that arise. One interesting issue is: how do we address health? Recently, I read an article where the author claimed that handshaking in the West is likely the leading cause of disease transmission.

original: What is a parent?what is a parent?it's not an easy question. Today we have adoption, stepfamilies, surrogate mothers. Many parents face tough questions and tough decisions. Shall we tell our child about the sperm donation? if so, when? what words to use? sperm donors are often referred to as "biological fathers," but should we really be using the word "father? "as a philosopher and social scientist, i have been studying these questions about the concept of parenthood. But today, i will talk to you about what i learned from talking to parents and children. I will show you that they know what matters most in a family, even though their family looks a little different.
polished:
What is a parent? It’s not a simple question to answer. In today’s world, we encounter diverse family structures—adoption, stepfamilies, and surrogate motherhood. Many parents grapple with difficult questions and complex decisions. Should we disclose the use of a sperm donor to our child? If so, when is the right time, and how should we phrase it? While sperm donors are often labeled as 'biological fathers,' does the term 'father' truly fit?  

As a philosopher and social scientist, I’ve dedicated my research to exploring these very questions about the nature of parenthood. But today, I want to share what I’ve learned directly from parents and children themselves. Their experiences reveal a profound understanding of what truly matters in a family—even when their family doesn’t fit the traditional mold.

(cheering)i see all of that and a man who spent a quarter of his life in state prison — six years, to be exact, starting as a teenager on rikers island for an act that nearly cost a man his life. But what got me from there to here wasn't the punishment i faced as a teenager in adult prison or the harshness of our legal system. Instead, it was a learning environment of a classroom that introduced me to something i didn't think was possible for me or our justice system as a whole.a few weeks before my release on parole, a counselor encouraged me to enroll in a new college course being offered in the prison.
polished: When I look in the mirror today, I see a justice and education scholar at Columbia University, a youth mentor, an activist, and a future New York State senator. (Cheers) I see all of that—and a man who spent a quarter of his life in state prison—six years, to be exact, beginning as a teenager on Rikers Island for an act that nearly took a man’s life. But what brought me from there to here wasn’t the punishment I endured as a teenager in adult prison or the brutality of our legal system. Rather, it was the transformative environment of a classroom that revealed possibilities I never imagined—for myself or for our justice system as a whole. Just weeks before my parole release, a counselor urged me to enroll in a new college course offered within the prison.

And i presumed that we just needed simpler, faster and more affordable sensors. I was wrong.
polished:
We must create a water-focused weather service. However, without collective demand for accountability, the necessary funding incentives will remain absent. My first conference presentation was here at TED eight years ago. Fresh from graduate school, I didn't realize those brief minutes on stage would define the questions I'd face for the next ten years. Like many in their twenties, I believed I could solve global challenges—particularly water issues—through technology alone. I had much to learn.  

It was tempting to think our most significant water quality problems persist because they're difficult to detect. I assumed the solution lay in simpler, faster, and more affordable sensors. I was mistaken.

original: Indeed, for 20 years, i worked in finance. I knew everything about finance, for sure. I knew the global economy because it was my life. All the topics that you could bring up about ecology, the end of the world, etc., that i knew like the back of my hand i didn't really believe in them. In 2007, an extremely unusual event occurred, you may remember, the subprime crisis, the collapse of big american banks. It was an electric shock. I had a fair few stormy conversations with my wife about the matter, about my job, on the limits of the model. Besides the crisis, i realized that i was completely wrong, that we were heading for disaster.
polished: Indeed, for two decades, I worked in finance. I was certain I knew everything about the field—the global economy was my life. Any topics you might raise about ecology, the end of the world, and so on—though I knew them inside out—I never truly believed in them. Then, in 2007, an extraordinary event occurred: the subprime crisis, the collapse of major American banks. It was a wake-up call. I had several heated discussions with my wife about it—about my career, about the flaws in the system. Beyond the crisis itself, I came to realize how profoundly mistaken I had been. We were, unmistakably, headed for disaster.

original: So, i'll be speaking to you using language ... Because i can. This is one these magical abilities that we humans have. We can transmit really complicated thoughts to one another. So what i'm doing right now is, i'm making sounds with my mouth as i'm exhaling. I'm making tones and hisses and puffs, and those are creating air vibrations in the air. Those air vibrations are traveling to you, they're hitting your eardrums, and then your brain takes those vibrations from your eardrums and transforms them into thoughts. I hope. (laughter)i hope that's happening. So because of this ability, we humans are able to transmit our ideas across vast reaches of space and time. We're able to transmit knowledge across minds.
polished:
So, I’ll be speaking to you using language… simply because I can. This is one of those magical abilities unique to us humans—the power to convey complex thoughts to one another. Right now, as I speak, I’m shaping sounds with my mouth while exhaling, producing tones, hisses, and bursts of air. These create vibrations that travel through the air, reaching your ears and striking your eardrums. Your brain then interprets these vibrations, transforming them into thoughts—at least, I hope so. (Laughter) I certainly hope that’s what’s happening.  

Because of this remarkable ability, we humans can share ideas across immense distances of space and time. We can transmit knowledge directly from one mind to another.

I like working with media and technology because a, i'm familiar with them and i like the power they hold. And b, i hate them and i'm terrified of the power they hold. (laughter)i remember watching, in 2003, an interview between fox news host tony snow and then-us defense secretary, donald rumsfeld. polished:
There’s a quote by activist and punk rock musician Jello Biafra that I really admire. He says, *"Don’t hate the media. Be the media."* As an artist, I enjoy working with media and technology for two reasons: first, because I’m familiar with them and appreciate their influence, and second, because I despise them and am deeply unsettled by the power they wield. *(Laughter.)*  

I recall watching a 2003 interview between Fox News host Tony Snow and then-U.S. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld. They were discussing the recent invasion of Iraq when Snow asked, *"We hear about our casualties, but never theirs—why?"* Rumsfeld’s response was chilling: *"Well, we don’t do body counts on other people."*

It’s 1988, and scientist James Hansen has just testified before the United States Congress that global warming trends are driven by human activity—and will become an escalating threat to humanity in the years ahead.  

Well, well. That’s remarkably prescient for a human.  

Looking for a wedding dress? Try a fresh twist on a timeless classic. It’s sleek, flattering, and modest—just like the traditional gown.  

Commercials. Could anything be more unbearable?  

It’s 1997, and the United States Senate has convened a hearing on global warming. Expert witnesses note that past eras in Earth’s history were warmer than the 20th century.

original: Someone once said that politics is, of course, "showbiz for ugly people." so, on that basis, i feel like i've really arrived. The other thing to think of is what an honor it is, as a politician, to give a ted talk, particularly here in the u.k., where the reputation of politics, with the expenses scandal, has sunk so low.there was even a story recently that scientists had thought about actually replacing rats in their experiments with politicians. And someone asked,"why?" and they said, "well, there's no shortage of politicians, no one really minds what happens to them and, after all, there are some things that rats just won't do." (laughter)now, i know you all love data, so i'm starting with a data-rich slide.
polished:
Someone once remarked that politics is essentially "show business for the unattractive." By that measure, I suppose I’ve truly made it. Another point worth considering is what a privilege it is, as a politician, to deliver a TED Talk—especially here in the U.K., where the standing of politics has plummeted so dramatically since the expenses scandal.  

In fact, I recently came across a story about scientists contemplating replacing lab rats with politicians in their experiments. When someone asked why, the response was: "Well, there’s no shortage of politicians, few people care what happens to them, and let’s face it—there are some things even rats refuse to do." *(Laughter)*  

Now, since I know this audience loves data, I’ll begin with a particularly data-rich slide.
